DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

REQUISITION FOR SUPPLIES

October 5, 1949

To The Departmental Purchasing Agent, Ottawa,

PLEASE FURNISH THE FOLLOWING SUPPLIES FOR USE OF Cecelia Jeffrey Residential School

No. 461

VOTE 516 PRIMARY 10 OBJECT 691 DATE REQUIRED at once

SHIP TO:
The Principal, Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.

MAIL INVOICES TO Mr. N. Paterson, Supt. Indian Agency, Kenora, Ont.

Purpose for which required:

| QUANTITY | UNIT PRICE | TOTAL |
|----------|------------|-------|
| 6160 sq. ft. heavy knoof paper | | |
| 62 gal. linseip glue | | |

NOTE: The above items should have been ordered on requisition of August 17th on which you issued P.O. 47921 for 685 sq. yds. of battleship linoleum. We would appreciate if you could arrange to have the above delivered at the earliest possible date.

I hereby certify that I have personal knowledge that all the above articles are required in the Department and for Departmental purposes only. The expenditure required by this requisition is strictly unavoidable and the public interest will suffer if it is not made.

SIGNED—

APPROVED—

Director

(1) Group requisitions for equipment, supplies, and material according to commodity, i.e., books, stationery, printing, electrical goods, hardware, machinery, provisions, transportation equipment, etc.
(2) Avoid listing requisitions for one item only, except in cases of emergency necessity.
(3) Furnish exact details of product required.
October 5th, 1949.

Mr. H. Peterson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Kenora, Ontario.

Re: Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School

We have your telegram of the 4th instant, and the Departmental Purchasing Agent is being requested to secure the other items required at the earliest possible date.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Voucher No. 641, Date 9-11-49
Municipality of Jaffray and Melick
Kenora, Ontario

November 5th, 1949.

Honourable J.A. McKinnon,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith copy of a resolution asking that Federal properties be transferred for electrical power purposes from the present town of Kenora services to the Ontario rural Hydro in our Municipality. The Cecilia Jeffery Indian School is under this heading as it is on a Highway which will be serviced by Hydro.

I would appreciate it if you would consider this matter and advise us at your early convenience.

Yours very truly,

MUNICIPALITY OF JAFFRAY AND MELICK

Per:

(Mr.) M.R. Baribeau,
Clerk.

COPY
MUNICIPALITY OF JAFFRAY AND MELICK

Kenora, Ontario.

Moved by: "J.E. Kelly"
Seconded by: "C.A. Paul"

"WHEREAS the Municipal Council of the United Townships of Jaffray and Melick have entered into an agreement with the Hydro Electric Power Commission of Ontario to become part of a rural Hydro area and WHEREAS owing to the broken nature of our Townships, settlers are scattered and WHEREAS it is essential that every user of Hydro in the Municipality sign a Hydro contract in order that all may benefit from this service, therefore we, the Municipal Council of the United Townships of Jaffray and Melick petition the Department of Transport to enter into a Hydro contract and become part of the rural area of Jaffray and Melick for Hydro purposes."

A copy of this resolution is to be sent to the Department of Transport, Department of Mines and Resources, the Hydro-Electric Power Commission and to W.M. Bentdickson, M.P.
Department of Mines and Resources

MEMORANDUM

November 10, 1946

PRIVATE MINISTER:

Attention - Director of Indian Affairs

I am attaching hereto a letter from Mr. W.R. Baribeau, Clerk of the Municipality of Jaffray and Hallock, Box 85, Kenora, Ontario, with which he encloses copy of a resolution which has been passed by the said municipality concerning Hydro Electric Power.

You will observe that they are asking that Federal properties be transferred for electrical power from the present Town of Kenora to the Ontario Rural Hydro, and that the Cecilia Jeffery Indian School would come under this category.

This letter has not been acknowledged. Please prepare a reply for Private Secretary's signature.

[Signature]

PRIVATE SECRETARY

For draft reply as requested.

[Signature]
Ottawa, November 17, 1949.

H.R. Peribon, Esq.,
Clerk,
Municipality of Jeffrey and Melick,
Box 86,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Peribon:

I have received your letter of November 5th with reference to transferring the electrical service at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School from the town of Kenora to the Ontario Rural Hydro. This letter has been brought to the attention of the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch and they are communicating with Mr. R.V. Paterson, Indian Superintendent, Kenora, Ontario.

Yours sincerely,

Private Secretary.

November 21, 1949.

Mr. M. Paterson,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Kenora, Ontario.

The Minister has received a letter from the Clerk of the Municipality of Jeffrey and Melick enclosing a petition with reference to electrical service at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

I enclose a copy of this petition and so far as we are concerned we have no objection to transferring the services from the City of Kenora to the Municipality if it will assist the latter.

However, there may be some objection on the part of the Principal or yourself. Please discuss the request with the Principal and advise us as soon as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
"To be returned to Indian Affairs Branch when signed".

13149

I have received your letter of November 5th with reference to transferring the electrical service at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School from the town of Kenora to the Ontario Rural Hydro. Yours sincerely,

J.G. Levy,
Private Secretary.

December 2nd, 1949.

Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

(ATTENTION: MR. MOONAN)

Our records show that on June 7th, 1949, we forwarded you Voucher 251 from the Kenora Agency. This Voucher was issued in an amount of $50.00 in favour of the Secretary, Women's Missionary Society, Presbyterian Church.

In a letter from the Secretary dated November 25th, she states that payment for the month of April has not been received. Please advise regarding the date the cheque was issued in payment of Voucher 251, and if possible, let us know if it has been cashed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
December 2nd, 1949.

Miss Frieda Matthews,
National Executive Secretary,
Women's Missionary Society of the
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
Room 300 - 100 Adelaide St. W.,
Toronto 1, Ontario.

Dear Miss Matthews:

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, in which you enquired regarding the salary for the night watchman at the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School for the month of April, 1949, our records show that a Voucher was forwarded to our Treasury Branch in June last.

Consequently, a cheque should have gone forward to you at that time. However, in view of the contents of your letter, we are making inquiries from the Treasury, and as soon as we have the necessary information, we will advise you further.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division
December 2nd, 1949.

Memorandum: 

Chief Treasury Officer 
(ATTENTION: MR. NOONAN)

Our records show that on June 7th, 1949, we forwarded to you Voucher 251 from the Kenora Agency. This Voucher was issued in an amount of $60.00 in favour of the Secretary, Women's Missionary Society, Presbyterian Church.

In a letter from the Secretary dated November 25th, she states that payment for the month of April has not been received. Please advise regarding the date the cheque was issued in payment of Voucher 251, and if possible, let us know if it has been cashed.

Philip Phelan, 
Chief, Education Division
December 7th, 1949.

Miss Frieda Matthews,
National Executive Secretary,
Women's Missionary Society of the
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
Room 500 - 100 Adelaide St. W.,
Toronto 1, Ontario.

Dear Miss Matthews:

With reference to official letter of
December 2nd, the Treasury Branch advises that
Cheque No. 62165 in an amount of $60.00 was
forwarded to your office on June 3rd, 1949, in
payment of the allowance towards the salary of
the night watchman at the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian
Residential School for the month of April, 1949.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
PP/T
Chief, Education Division

Kenora, January 10th, 1950

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario

Re: Electrical Service,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res. School.

Reference your letter dated November 21st, 1949, file 461-5(EL) relative to the petition received from the Clerk of the Municipality of Jeffrey and Melick regarding electrical service at the above school.

This matter has been discussed with the Principal of the school and we are now awaiting more particulars from the Municipality and the Ontario Hydro-Electric Power Commission regarding cost of transfer of service etc.

When this information is received we will render a report on this matter.

Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.
January 13, 1950.

Mr. W. Paterson,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Kenora, Ont.

Kenora, February 8th, 1950

H.A. Burleigh, Esq.,
Area Inspector,
The Ontario Hydro-Electric Power Commission,
203 First Street South,
Kenora, Ontario

Dear Sir,

We wish to thank you for your letter of the 1st instant in regard to the electrical service at our Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

In the penultimate paragraph of your letter you recommend that consideration should be given to the supplying of a weather proof enclosure for metering equipment and main service switch, in the event that the school should become a Hydro-Electric customer. Could you supply us with the specifications of the type of enclosure you would recommend.

In your letter you do not let us know the initial cost of the actual installation of Hydro Service, and before any decision can be reached this information has to be obtained.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) Norman Patterson
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration

All branch circuit lighting to be fused at not more than 15 ampere capacity.
February 1, 1950.

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Kenora,
Ontario.

Attention: Mr. Norman Patterson,
Indian Agent.

Re: Cecille Jeffrey Indian School,
Jeffrey Town., Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Please be advised that we have completed our general inspection of the electrical installation in the above mentioned premises prior to becoming a customer of the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario, Kenora Rural Operating Area and the following defects were found to be in evidence:

Remove all worn and frayed drop cords where they are used as line wire and switch legs over doorways, around molding and over dressers and beds in the dormitory as well as staff quarters replacing same with convenience receptacles and properly installed switches on the lighting circuits.

Replace broken light switch in hospital ward.

Reinstall the two bracket lights over the kitchen sink in the residence using proper materials.

Install proper convenience ironing receptacles along with pilot lights in the laundry.

Rewire all ceiling fixtures where fixture cords appear to be worn and frayed.

Exit lighting throughout the building to be installed at locations suitable to the Fire Marshall or his representative.

Barn, workshop, and chicken coop wiring were found to be in a hazardous condition. Same to be completely rewired using proper type materials.

All branch circuit lighting to be fused at not more than 15 amperes capacity.
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

The defects listed do not necessarily include any further dangers which may be discovered upon further examination but are a general guide to enable any competent wireman to estimate upon the work involved in placing the installation in good order.

As the above mentioned defects constitute a serious hazard to life and property it will be necessary for you to have them remedied by securing the services of a competent electrician and arrangements made with this office for another inspection.

In regards to the two existing 200 ampere lighting services, one being located in the laundry and the other located in the shoe storage room in the basement of the main building, we would recommend that some thought be taken into consideration for the necessity of installing a weatherproof enclosure on the new proposed transformer pole which will be erected near the rear of the building just off the garage driveway and in line with the new existing Rural line on the Rabbit Lake Road. This enclosure will house the main service switch and metering equipment for all buildings, also an additional weatherproof enclosure should be installed on an adjacent pole which will house the 240 volt, 3 phase service and metering equipment.

Should you require further information in regards to this matter kindly advise us at once.

Yours truly,

H. A. Burleigh,
Area Inspector.

cc: Mr. K. Tumilty,
S. R. Martyn,
Mr. Ross-Supervisor
Indian School.
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ontario,
Nov 30, 1949.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re: ELECTRICAL SERVICE

In reply to your letter dated November 24th, 1949:

I feel that this is a matter which requires expert opinion. It would be a pity if, because of an opinion voiced by me, a change were made in the electrical service for this school, this change proving later not to be beneficial. I feel sure that there must be men of your Department much better qualified than I to decide upon the relative merits of Hydro and other sources of power supply.

The copy of certain correspondence received by your Department from the Municipality of Jeffrey and Melick, forwarded to me by yourself, puts forward no suggestions as to possible advantages for this school which might result from this change. Reasons given refer only to probable advantages to the Municipality concerned.

The only possible considerations which might influence me in voicing an opinion would be the probable comparative cost, and the relative efficiency of service to be expected. Whatever expenditure might be involved in the actual change to be made would hardly be a relative consideration, when thinking of a long-term viewpoint.

I feel able to make no further comments.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re REQUISITION FOR SCHOOL SUPPLIES

Major Clark, during his recent visit to this school, drew attention to the need for new furniture in the classrooms of this school. I had not considered the need to be of sufficient priority to be included in our last requisition, but am grateful to Major Clark for having drawn this to my attention.

He has written me asking that I submit a requisition for these items. He suggests that there is a possibility that these might still be obtained from funds at present available if action is prompt. As I was away from the school for several days on business at the time Major Clark's letter arrived, there has been delay in submitting this requisition.

Thus I am submitting this requisition in hope that, if it should prove too late for the present fiscal year's business, it may receive prompt attention in the coming year. Anything you may be able to do to expedite this matter will be much appreciated.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Re: Disposal Bed, Cecilia Jeffrey
Indian Residential School, Kenora

A letter has been received from Mr. T.C. Ross, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School in connection with the disposal bed at the school.

A copy of Mr. Ross' letter is attached for your information.

Last year similar condition was noted and though the seepage cleared later in the Spring, it has again developed and it is suggested that possibly the Engineering Branch on one of their trips to Kenora could inspect the chamber and bed.

Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ontario,
March 7, 1950.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re DISPOSAL BED

The disposal bed for the sewage system of this school is again giving evidence that it is not functioning properly. For several days water to a depth of from eight to ten inches has been in evidence above the ground in the disposal field. It is without doubt seepage from the bed.

While there is no immediate cause for alarm, I thought it advisable to bring this to your attention. There is little doubt that the new toilets have relieved the system of a considerable portion of the volume of fluid which it used previously be obliged to carry. We have as a result had no difficulty at all with the sewage system this winter. The seepage in evidence may indicate only a break in one or more parts of the tile field.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Re: Vouchers No.'s 171, & 172, attached.

John Plaxton Company Ltd.

Reference your telegram of September 6th, 1949, authorizing the extra work on replacement of radiators and valves on the low pressure heating system, in the amounts of $325.00 and $125.00 respectively, at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

John Plaxton Co., Ltd., of Winnipeg gave the estimate on this job, and when the work was started on the pressure system it was found the cost was lower than estimated.

Regarding Voucher No. 171, in the amount of $416.45, we would advise that it was found necessary to replace our old water heater, which was cracked, then authorized. This was done without the firm receiving the approval of the Principal or this office. We would however point out that it would have been necessary to have the rad replaced before the heating season commenced at considerable more cost to the Department, as the men were on the job.

This firm has done a very satisfactory job at this school and therefore we would recommend that the attached Vouchers No. 171 and 172 be approved and passed for payment.

Superintendent,

It has been gratifying indeed to enjoy the comfort of a well-heated building throughout the past winter. Dear Mr. Peterson:

Re MIXER REQUIRED FOR SCHOOL KITCHEN:

When allowing for the purchase of a mixing machine for the school kitchen, at the time estimates for this year were submitted, I tried to plan for the most economical type of machine which could meet the requirements.

I have since been advised by those much more expert than I in the matter of kitchen administration that it is foolish to invest in a small size of mixing machine - such as I had in mind - as there are so many mixing processes for which something of greater capacity is needed.

The type of machine which I am asking for is the best I have heard of for the purpose for which it will be needed in our school kitchen.

Dear Mr. Matters,

Re: Water Piping,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School

cg/
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kemora, Ontario,
May 6, 1950.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

In our estimates for the present year, allowance was made for the necessity of replacing existing water piping in this building.

Present water pipes throughout this building are almost all the original iron pipes put in when the school was built. During the years which have elapsed since then, a great deal of corrosion has taken place. Also, a great deal of scale has built up on the inside of the pipes. In several places this has developed to such an extent that there is a serious threat that the water will soon cease to flow altogether. It can be understood quite readily how easily an emergency could be created if this happened in one of several places while school was in session.

May I request authority, please, to arrange for having all water piping which needs to be replaced removed and replaced during the coming holidays.

I believe that it is now considered economical to have copper pipe put in wherever possible. However, your Engineering Department will be much better informed than I, and will be able best to advise the proper procedure for putting our water system in first-class shape.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.
Kenora, May 9th, 1950

F. Matters, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Camp Chippewa, North Bay, Ontario

Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.S. School

Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ontario,
May 6, 1950.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re FIRE ESCAPES:

During my first term as Principal of this school I drew your attention to the hazards of fire in this school, with its present poorly-planned fire escapes. On the occasion of the first visit of the Regional Supervisor to this school, this topic was discussed quite fully.

It was pointed out that, since there is no direct exit from any one of the four large dormitories to a fire escape, the possibility of the occupants of one or all of these dormitories being able to reach safety in the event of fire is a slight one indeed. The fact was also stressed that, because there is only one exit from each of these dormitories, it is necessary to leave the one exit unlocked while the dormitories are occupied. This means that there is free passage between dormitories containing young people of opposite sexes, many of whom are physically capable of reproduction. That this fact is a constant threat to the morals of the pupils of this school should not need to be emphasized.

I am bringing this matter again to your attention with the sincere hope that your Department will not allow another school year to pass without having proper up-to-date escape equipment installed in this school. I do not feel that I can accept responsibility for the safety of children who are not supplied with a reasonable chance of safety in the event of fire.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.
Kenora, May 9th, 1950.

F. Matters, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Camp Chipewa, North Bay, Ontario

Dear Mr. Matters,

Re: Additional School Building,
Cecilia Jeffrey Res. School.

A letter has been received from Mr. T.C. Ross, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School outlining the need for a new school building at this school to take care of the proposed extension of physical education, and for the inclusion of an additional classroom and library.

A copy of Mr. Ross' letter is hereto attached for your information and consideration.

An item of $25,000.00 in the 1950-51 Estimates covers this proposed expenditure.

Mr. Ian Risenhardt, Supervisor of Physical Education and Recreation, discussed this matter with Mr. Ross this morning and will no doubt be reporting later.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

SUPERINTENDENT,
Kenora Indian Agency,
Dept of Citizenship & Immigration.

N/P/g
Geetina Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ontario,
May 5, 1950.

Mr. Herman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re ADDITIONAL SCHOOL BUILDING:

In our letter dated July 30, 1949, we mentioned the need for an additional building for this school, this building to contain a gymnasium, a classroom, a library and two reading rooms.

At present there is no part of this building (our present school) which is suitable for use as a gymnasium. Because of this there is inadequate program of physical education. Also, the lack of space for indoor sports results in disciplinary problems which could largely be avoided if there were proper facilities for recreation. The need for a proper gymnasium is great indeed.

We are sadly in need of an additional class-room, and there is no space available. We have no library, and because of this are losing a valuable chance to educate our Indian young pupils. There are no rooms in our present building where a pupil may retire to read or write. This is a tragic fact. Separate reading rooms for boys and girls are very, very necessary.

It is believed that these needs could all be met in one building. It is proposed that this building should contain a gymnasium (and possibly a swimming pool) on the lower floor. The second floor should contain the class-room, library and two reading rooms. It is expected that the cost of such a building would be $25,000.00.

May I request permission to have plans prepared for such a building, please?

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal.
P. Matters, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Camp Chippewa, North Bay, Ontario

MEMORANDUM FOR THE DIRECTOR

CIVILIA JEFFREY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

Reference is made to Major MacKay's memorandum of the 13th of May in connection with the above.

2. In December of 1946 one new steel fire-box low pressure steam heating boiler with sufficient capacity to heat the building was installed. This boiler was equipped with a blower fan operated by a pressure-trol to maintain reasonably steady steam pressure.

3. Assuming that a fully qualified fireman was on duty, normal hand firing, four times daily, would be sufficient to maintain the desired pressure if the fan were used as was intended.

4. In 1948 our heating engineer made an inspection at this school and discovered that the fireman had never used the blower and did not know what it was for. This man was over 70 years of age and appeared to be rather frail.

5. If the Indian Affairs Branch desire to install a stoker it would be necessary to fill the hopper with coal about three times a day and of course ashes would also have to be removed. With a stoker an increase in combustion efficiency would certainly result. Proper hand firing can only be expected from a qualified fireman possessing a reasonable amount of initiative and vigour. A stoker having a maximum capacity to burn ordinary stoker coal at a rate of 550 lbs. per hour would be required for this boiler.

6. We would recommend that an Iron Fireman or Volcano stoker having the above capacity be considered. Both of these stokers are nationally known and can be depended upon to meet the requirements. In addition to their satisfactory performance, both these stokers are backed by first class service attentions.

Major MacKay:
For your information.

[Signature]
Chief.

Re: Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential
Your File 129/6-1-161

We received your letter of May 8th enclosing a request from the Principal of the above school to be supplied with a stoker. These communications were submitted to our Engineering Branch, and they comment as follows:

1. In December of 1945 one new steel fire-box low pressure steam heating boiler with sufficient capacity to heat the building was installed. This boiler was equipped with a blower fan operated by a pressure-trol to maintain reasonably steady steam pressure.

2. Assuming that a fully qualified fireman was on duty, normal hand firing, four times daily, would be sufficient to maintain the desired pressure if the fan were used as was intended.

3. In 1948 our heating engineer made an inspection at this school and discovered that the fireman had never used the blower and did not know what it was for. This man was over 70 years of age and appeared to be rather frail.

4. If the Indian Affairs Branch desire to install a stoker it would be necessary to fill the hopper with coal about three times a day and of course ashes would also have to be removed. With a stoker an increase in combustion efficiency would certainly result. Proper hand firing can only be expected from a qualified fireman possessing a reasonable amount of initiative and vigour.

Philip [signature]
Chief, Education Division
June 13th, 1930.

MR. CHARLIE B. BUCK,
CHIEF ENGINEER

Re: Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School and Kenora Indian Residential School.

The Minister has received from W.M. Benidickson, M.F., a letter in which he reports regarding the visit of the Grand Jury to the above two schools.

In connection with the Kenora Residential School, they report on the condition of the roof. With regard to this matter, I attach for your information a copy of a memorandum received from Mr. Webb dated May 16th.

The Grand Jury's report also complains that the pressure tanks for the water system need replacing.

With regard to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School the report reads:

"Members of the jury strongly recommend that spiral fire escapes be installed at each end of the building; to make easy access from boys' and girls' dormitories. Present fire escapes are of the open grating and prove a hazard during the winter conditions. At the present time pupils have to cross stair-wells to gain access to the present fire escapes.

The jury also noticed plaster throughout the entire building in a deplorable state of repair. Classroom lighting was found to be very poor. It was also noted that seepage from the sewage system was appearing on the surface."
It would be appreciated if you could arrange to have one of your engineers visit the above two schools at an early date and submit a report regarding what he considers can be done to improve the conditions about which the Grand Jury have reported adversely.

Bernard F. Henry,

Dear Mr. Harris:

Re: Repairs at Indian Residential Schools, Kenora, Ontario.

I was disappointed to read in the Kenora Miner and News of May 30th a report of the Grand Jury of the district following visits to the St. Mary's and the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential Indian Schools, at Kenora, Ontario.

The references to these schools in the Grand Jury report are as follows:

"St. Mary's Residential School

The condition of the roof was found to be in a very bad state of repair and showed evidence of leaking into class rooms during our visit. We recommended that repairs be undertaken as soon as possible.

Accommodation for outdoor playgrounds very limited but could be extended with very little expense.

Pressure tanks for the water system need replacing. The washer in the laundry was also found in very poor condition."

"Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School

Members of the Jury strongly recommend that spiral fire escapes be installed at each end of the building to make easy access from boys' and girls' dormitories. Present fire escapes are of the open grating and prove a hazard during winter conditions. At the present time pupils have to cross stair-wells to gain access to the present fire escapes."
Hon. W.E. Harris

June 6th, 1950.

Accommodation for indoor recreation very limited. Approximately 140 pupils are residing in the school originally built to accommodate 135 pupils. The Jury also noticed water throughout the entire building in a deplorable state of repair. Classroom lighting was found to be very poor. It was also noted seepage from sewage system appearing on surface. We strongly recommend that the above conditions be attended to at an early date.

I would appreciate it very much if you could present this report to the appropriate officials of your Department and I would be grateful, in due course, to receive an indication of what remedial measures can be taken to remove the defects outlined.

Yours sincerely,

[signature] W.M. Benidickson

Dear Mr. Donaldson:

I am in receipt of your letter of June 6 in which you quote from an article in the Toronto Star and request my opinion with regard to the Grand Jury's report on their visit to the Indian Residential School at Cecilia Jeffrey Institute.

We are aware that extensive repairs are required to the roof of the former (now Cecilia Jeffrey) Residential School, and our engineering staff expects to proceed with this work in the near future.

A new manner was ordered for this school some weeks ago and should be delivered shortly. The official announcement is being written regarding the restoration of the building.

With reference to the recommendation of the Grand Jury that the present fire escape be replaced by a steel ladder escape, I may say that our engineers do not agree with this recommendation. However, an engineer from this Department will visit this school in the near future and assess the present fire escape, and will also take the necessary action in regard to providing better access to the building. At the same time, the engineer will inspect the building and report what additional repairs are necessary.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Ross of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora, was here recently discussing some of the work at the school. He mentioned to us some of the improvements which he thought should be made this summer.

One matter which gives us much concern is the lack of suitable fire escapes from the dormitories. You, of course, are familiar with the plan of the building and know that if a fire occurred in either stair well the children in the dormitory nearest the stair would have no means of exit.

There were other matters which Mr. Ross discussed with us but I am hoping to go to Ottawa to see you before many months. Some of the things he mentioned were milk pasteurization equipment and an inter communication system.

Mr. Ross feels very definitely that a secretary should be hired to take care of the office work but we feel that the present grant does not warrant hiring another member of staff.

We have been fortunate in securing a qualified Primary teacher for the primary room and also a teacher for the Intermediate classroom. I am sure you will be pleased to have this information. These teachers will replace Mrs. Highfield and Mrs. Coulter, who have been on our staff as teachers but who are not qualified.

I hope that the matter of the fire escapes will be given careful consideration.

Very sincerely,

Frieda E. Matthews,
National Executive Secretary.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: DISPOSAL BED

Fluid continues to lie above ground in this area.

There is no doubt that the installation of the new toilets has reduced the flow of water through this system; and seepage above ground in the disposal bed has consequently been reduced. But the situation referred to above is far from satisfactory, and suggests that we are apt to be faced with sewage backing up during the winter, when frost is apt to prevent seepage from getting away. Also, this condition presents a constant threat to the sanitation of the school.

I should not bring this matter again to your attention if I did not believe that it required immediate action. Not being an engineer, I do not know what the real difficulty is. It would seem to warrant prompt action on the part of those in charge of such matters within your Department.

I feel confident that I can count on your cooperation in remedying this most unpleasant condition.

Sincerely yours,

T. G. Ross,
Principal.
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ontario,
Aug 12, 1950.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re HOT WATER TANK:

Inspection of this tank while making a recent repair has shown that the metal has become very thin in a number of places. This suggests the necessity for early replacement of this tank.

A leak which appeared necessitated immediate repair. The metal in the vicinity of the leak proved to be so thin that it is a question whether or not the repair may be expected to hold for long. Further leaks may occur at any time, and it is quite possible that we may be without the use of this tank altogether. If this happens, we shall be in a precarious condition indeed. We depend on this hot water tank for all hot water throughout the building: laundry, kitchen, washing and bathing for both staff and children. Should this tank be out of commission, we would be without hot water in any and every part of the school. We have no reserve or auxiliary hot water jacket.

I could not feel justified in facing the possibility of being without hot water while school is in session. May I suggest therefore that either an engineer from your Department inspect the condition of this tank and advise concerning its replacement, or that I be authorized to get tenders from local firms at once for the cost of replacing it.

It seems important to consider the advisability of installing a tank of considerably greater proportions. The one at present in use does not hold sufficient hot water to provide a decent bath for half the children at any one time. With all other needs to consider, it is difficult indeed to manage satisfactorily with such an inadequate supply of hot water.

Sincerely yours,

T. G. Ross,
Principal.
Kenora, August 14th, 1950.

F. Matters, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Camp Chippewa, North Bay, Ontario

Re: Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ont.

The above named school was visited on Friday, July 31st, 1950, for the purpose of inspecting and reporting on the following:

1. Fire escapes.
2. Condition of plaster in entire building.
3. Lighting in classrooms.
4. Sewage from sewage system appearing on surface of ground.

1. Fire escapes.

The existing fire escapes are located on the outside of the building as marked on the attached plan and are of steel construction with landings at each floor level. Exits are through windows in each staircase well with a small window ladder placed at each window from floor level to sill. In winter the escapes are covered with ice and snow and would provide a very hazardous means of exit from the building in case of fire, particularly when used by small children. If fire occurred in either of the staircase wells the escapes would not be accessible.

The dormitories in this school are situated on the top floor of the building, one at each end, are the full width of the structure and accommodate approximately 75 pupils each. It would, therefore, appear logical, that the fire exits should be located in such a position that they can be easily reached from the dormitories in case of fire in the centre portion of the building.

It is recommended that, for maximum safety, two fire-proof stair case wells with fire-proof stairs should be constructed one at each end of the structure, in positions marked on the attached drawing. The stair walls should be provided with landings at each floor level and with fire-proof doors having automatic escape mechanism hardware, to give access to the stairs on each floor. The existing outside steel fire escapes could remain as they are to provide exit from the centre portion of the building.

2. Plaster.

An inspection of the condition of the plaster in the entire building revealed that, in general, it does not require attention. On the walls of the stair wells three or four places were noted on which a small repair job should be done.

3. Classroom Lighting.

The lighting in the three classrooms and sewing room is provided by fixtures of an obsolete type and they are too few in number. It is recommended that fluorescent lighting fixtures should be installed to provide sufficient foot candles for school room lighting in accordance with modern standards.
4. Sewage from Sewage System.

The original septic tank, constructed when the school was built, was remodelled and extended in October 1937 by the Winnipeg office of the Dept. of Mines and Resources in accordance with the attached drawing. No drawing of the layout of the distribution tile bed was available and whether or not the bed was extended at this time is not known.

The tile bed is laid in a field adjacent to the building and extensive seepage is visible. The Principal reported that, about a year ago, the tile was uncovered, examined and replaced or repaired in certain sections, but the trouble was not overcome.

In this case, it is recommended that advice should be obtained from some person experienced in sewage disposal systems.

Attached is a drawing showing the existing septic tank and, also, a drawing of Septic Tank Disposal System prepared by the Sanitary Engineering Division of the Dept. of Health of Ontario.

J. H. Boulter.
August 31st, 1950.

Mr. M. Paterson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Kanora, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Re STOKER? G. J. SCHOOL!

Further to your letter, file 129/6-1-46:

I am grateful indeed to receive the comments of your Engineering Branch, who are well qualified to decide upon such matters as this.

Paragraphs 1 to 3 refer of course to previous improvements made, and to the unfortunate situation in which we found ourselves while unable to obtain the services of a young man for this work. (I need not remind you that operating as we do on a very restricted budget, we are seldom able to offer wages which will attract first-class men.) I am at present trying out a younger man for the important job of firing the boiler referred to.

Thank you for drawing to my attention the fact that the ashes would still have to be removed, and that, with a hopper-fed stoker, it would require filling with coal about three times a day.

Thank you too for emphasising the fact that the combustion efficiency would certainly increase. Since receiving your letter, I have been told by others concerned with heating problems that the cost of installing a stoker is soon paid for by the reduction in fuel consumption due to increased combustion efficiency. If that is true, it would be well to have a stoker installed as soon as possible, would it not?

Is it possible that someone from your Engineering Branch could give me some idea of the probable saving which might be effected by the installation of a stoker in this school? There is about 400 feet of radiation, and, during cold days in the winter, our consumption of coal is often as much as two tons per day.
I am glad to have had expert opinion expressed on this subject. All too often we are prone to consider such installations only as they affect the comfort and well-being of the school, as we see it. The comments of your Engineering Branch have emphasized to me the one important practical consideration involved in this case; increase in combustion efficiency. If the cost of maintaining this school can be reduced by installing this piece of equipment, that is of course of even more interest to your Department than it is to me, is it not?

Could your Engineering Branch, please, give me expert advice as to the advisability of having a bin-fed or hopper-fed type of stoker installed. I should very much appreciate authoritative information on this question.

Sincerely yours,

T. O. Ross,
Principal.

P.S. If it is the wish of your Department that, in order to affect this saving as soon as possible, IF POSSIBLE, a stoker be installed with as little delay as possible, I should be prepared to put up with whatever discomfort was involved during the installation, even if it was necessary to have this done during the first few weeks of term.

I have just been offered a particularly good value in barn paint by Lindstrom & Wilson of Kenora. They have a quantity of a line which is going out of stock, and are prepared to let me have this for $1.95 per gallon. They would be able to sell about fifty gallons.

May I request that authority be granted for this purchase, please. Several of the farm buildings are sadly in need of paint.

Sincerely yours,

T. O. Ross,
Principal.

Ottawa, February 23, 1925.

Dear Mr. Addison:

I am hopeful that funds will be available this year to replace the present inadequate physical equipment of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. I am informed that suitable farm land can be secured west of Laughlin. A site on the mainland as close to Lake Nipigon as possible would place the institution in close touch with its Indian constituency in the summer months and would give it all year round contact with markets, mails, medical services, etc.

If you will arrange to submit a recommendation relative to a suitable farm, I will have the Department Architect select a proper building site.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. J. H. Addison, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
454 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Toronto, Ont.
Ottawa, April 23, 1926.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, with reference to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, and I note your recommendation that the new buildings be placed in the general locality of Kenora. Mr. Indian Agent Edwards also recommends a site near the main line of railroad, and the advantages of such a situation will not be overlooked. The Department Architect will proceed to Kenora in a few weeks, with a view to selecting a site for buildings. In the meantime, I should be grateful if you would have one of your officers call on Mr. Indian Agent Edwards and, in conjunction with him, endeavour to locate a suitable property. I am writing to Mr. Edwards, asking him to cooperate with your representative in this connection. If you will let me know who will act for you, I will send more definite instructions to Mr. Edwards.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General

Rev. J. H. Edmison, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
434 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Toronto, Ont.
Following the recent negotiations of the Secretary, Mr. James Edwards, the Indians have been asked to meet at a special meeting to discuss the possibility of building a new school in the neighborhood of Roosman having three requirements in mind: (1) to be connected with the railway and Roosman; (2) to be located near the town of Roosman; (3) to be situated on a piece of suitable land. The two days before the meeting, representatives from Ottawa came with us. Altogether I visited four days exploring various sections. All our inquiries were made of the people in view of the fact that many of the Indians who live in the school will be drawn from homes in the south in the case of the Indians who would come to go north would make representations on their behalf.

The Proposed Location - Nothing could be gained by a partiality of the different localities we investigated except to give assurance that we had pretty well covered the area. We visited some of the possible locations west side of the Roosman River both from east and west. We traveled on the Roosman Reserve Road to see what was along the river. We looked at some land at the top of Field Indian Road. Our investigations on this part also were not very extensive because we thought it best not to go too close to the Roman Catholic School if a site could be secured elsewhere. However, we knew that that side offers in the way of possibilities. Finally, after elimination of impossible areas, we settled on three possible ones. The best suitable on abandoned golf course about five miles from Roosman. It has road and water connection and some cleared land, but is deficient in good supply, very old, very close to other villages, and terribly muddy. There is no way such a place can be used. The second site is located at the top of Field Indian Road. This site seems to have road and water connection although the road runs up to about nine miles. The land here is very heavy clay, a sample of which I have shown to the Department of Agriculture. The third site is not much land to be had in any continuous piece although there could be several acres of it available. The first choice covers lots 68 and 70 P just north of the north boundary of Reserve No. 4. These lots are owned by Mr. Cardinal of Roosman. Our judgment and also the judgment of Mr. James Edwards is that the Cardinal property is by all odds the best location. Field Indian Road is a poor second, and the Golf Links a very bad third.

The Cardinal Property - Each lot has in it about 150 acres. The best land is a long strip extending in a westerly direction on either side of the boundary between Lots 68 and 70 P. The vegetation on it is not noticeably different from other parts of the country except that certain portions it is not so dense. There is Rogers, birch, a scattering of maple and in some places jack pine. There is some scrub growth also and grassy patches are scattered all over its surface. There is also a portion that would be a strip on the north side towards the boundary between Lots 68 and 70 P. This would be a strip of land which would be a little rocky strip, but between these two rocky formations and extending just far enough out to be a level piece of country. The soil is a light sand loam. I have had it analyzed and it is not the heavy clay soil and this sample of sandy soil was free from acidity and tests out almost neutral. Both are very distinctly deficient in organic matter and the sand more so than the clay. However, the opinion of the Professor at McGill and also of his field worker is that the sandy soil would be much better for the purposes of the school. It would need to be built up before it could yield the most satisfactory crops, but so would the soil. The sandy soil is much easier to work and much less expensive. It would grow potatoes very well nicely. It was a very good clump and would increase yearly under proper rotation for other crops and also. It is admirably adapted for hay culture.
The question of raising three year old cattle follows a little more closely or not.

There is no question about the road leading right into the property. A settler on the old gold line could easily get there by going just out of the town on the west side of the town road. By running about a quarter mile off the road across the top of the hill to connect with the trail, however, this will be avoided. On the other hand, there is a road leading down from Ford's creek. It is just over half a mile from the town back to the top and down into the Indian Reserve where it joins the old main passage and the old logging road.

The water connection is good. If connecting the creek to the railway station and there would be no drainage of freight and supplies from train to boat. There is no reason in this country that would lead themselves to the building of any other settlement. Water must be the main means of transportation for young, and the road will need at certain seasons for emergency work.

Considering this site from the point of view of the building, there are at least two very fair building sites on the lake.

This is the location of the former educational objective suitable for these Indians. The Indians have been known to demand it. It is central to good fishing grounds.

There will be good setting for years and so far as the school is concerned an opportunity is assured because of its proximity to the reserve as well as by the wood on the lake itself. It would enable the school to grow a good deal of its own food supply. To provide the possibility of a large poultry industry with an easy shipping point, and probably strawberries could be cultivated too. The possibilities of a berry industry in connection with the school should be investigated. Poveshell will never be a basic industry for these Indians. The country they live in will not permit it. Another possibility that ought to be thoroughly investigated is fur farming. If in the future, it is thought wise to establish a colony for the protection of the school, between berries, furs, fishing, timber and garden plots, they ought to be able to establish themselves either on the reserve property or on the reserve land have a fine chance to develop under supervision these and other occupations suited to the character of the country in a section that is suitable for every climate.

Some of the lands in this location is cleared, but clearing would be easy, and thin that ought to be greatly encouraged in clearing in the burning of brush in order that the fire would be destroyed by the fires and be as small as possible. Every bush of wood on top of this hill is of very great value.

If certain Indians, or the Indian Department settle through some representative, or even to this particular location, we feel that it will be the best possible.
Toronto, June 12th, 1925.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq., F.R.C.S., Litt.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Enclosed please find a memo re the new location for Cecilid Jeffrey Indian School that has been sent here by Mr. Freeman, Convener of our Indian Committee for Winnipeg Presbytery. The Sub-executive and our W.M.B. Board approve of the site as recommended by Mr. Freeman's Committee.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

JIR/TNS
WHO IS NEW LOCATION FOR GEORGE JEFFREY INDIAN SCHOOL.

S.G.D. Freeman, Convener Indian Committee for Winnipeg Presbytery

1. General - Following the recommendations of the Presbytery, Captain Edwards, the Indian Agent at Kenora and myself, have been trying to find a suitable location for the new school in the neighborhood of Kenora keeping these requirements in mind - (1) Road connection with the railway and Kenora; (2) A water lot giving us access to the lake of the woods; (3) A considerable amount of arable land. For two days, Mr. Orr, government architect from Ottawa was with us. Altogether I spent four days exploring various sections. All our inquiries were south of the O.P.M.'s view of the fact that most of the Indians for the school will be drawn from bands to the south in the lake of the woods and because to go north would make impossible any boat connection with the Indian constituency.

2. The Proposed Location - Nothing would be gained by a recital of the different localities we investigated except to give assurance that we had pretty well covered the area. We worked down the whole east side of Rat Portage Bay both from water and by land. We went out on the Indian Reserve 26 A. We went out along the new Winnipeg-Kenora highway as far as it is completed. We made one trip to the east of Kenora - rather to a little east of south and looked at some land at the top of said Indian bay. Our investigations on this east side were not more numerous because we thought it best not to go too close to the Roman Catholic School if a site could be secured elsewhere. However, we know what that side offers in the way of possibilities. Finally, after elimination of impossible areas, we settled on three possible ones. The least suitable an abandoned gold course about 15 miles from Kenora. It has road and water connection and some cleared land, but is deficient in water supply, very close to summer cottages, and terribly rocky. There is not very much good land to be had near it. The second choice is a piece at the top of said Indian bay. Again there is road and water connection although the road trip would be about nine miles. The land here is a very heavy clay a sample of which I have shown to the Department of Soils at Manitoba Agricultural College. There is not much land to be had in one continuous piece although there would be several pockets of it available. The first choice comprises lots 6 K and 126 P just north of the north boundary of Reserve 26 A. These lots are owned by Mr. Carmichael of Kenora. Our judgment and also the judgment of Captain Edwards is that the Carmichael property is by all odds the best location. Bald Indian Bay is a poor second, and the Wolf Links a very bad third.

3. The Carmichael Property - Each lot has in it about 180 acres. The best land is a wide strip extending in a westerly direction on either side of the boundary between 6 K and 126 P. The vegetation on it is not noticeably different from other parts of the country except that certain portions of it is not so dense. There is a peculiar thin, smattering of spruce and in some parts jack pine. There is some shrub growth also and gravel patches are scattered all over it. Taking these lots together there would be a strip on the north side towards the boundary between 6 K and 6 K which is owned by Mr. Wagon which would be rocky, and on the south boundary between 126 P and the Indian Reserve 26 A, there would be a high rocky strip, but between these two rocky formations and extending west for at least two miles is a level piece of country. The soil is a
light sand loam. I have had it analysed at M.A.C. Both the heavy clay sample and this sample of sandy soil are free from acidity and test out about neutrality. Both are very definitely deficient in organic matter and the sand more so than the clay. However, the opinion of the Professor at M.A.C. and also of his field worker is that the sandy soil would be much better for the purposes of the school. It would need to be built up before it would yield the most satisfactory crops but so could the clay, and the sand would be much easier to work and much less expensive. It would grow potatoes and vegetables nicely. It would grow sweet clover and would increase the regular proper rotation for other clovers and oats. It is admirably adapted for berry culture. They suggested a regular three year rotation as follows - oat, sweet clover or red clover, vegetables, and as much as possible each year in the way of fertilizer.

There is at present a rough road leading right into the property. A settler on J.C. 69 has used it this year. It is not a good road and will not be for some time, but portions of it are good. It leaves Keewatin and follows the shore of Keewatin through the old golf links. There is a very bad hill just out of Keewatin and this is the worst obstacle in the whole road. By turning about a quarter mile of new road across the top of Slider Lake to connect with the Winnipeg highway, this hill could be avoided. On the property itself there is a good road good enough for a Ford although it is just a bush road. It runs from the lake back to J.C. 69 and down into the Indian Reserve where it joins the McKenzie portage and an old logging road.

The water connection is good. At Keewatin the dock is at the railway station and there would be no draying of freight and supplies from train to boat. There are no roads in this country that would lend themselves to the hauling of supplies or freight. Water must be the main means of transportation for years, and the road will be used at certain seasons for emergency work.

Considering this site from the point of view of the building, there are at least two very fair building sites on the Lake.

From the point of view of the larger educational objective suitable for these Lake Indians the location has much to commend it. It is central to good fishing grounds. There will be wood cutting for years and as far as the school is concerned an ample supply is assured because of its proximity to the Reserve as well as by the wood on the lot itself. It would enable the school to grow a good deal of its own food supply. It provides the possibility of a large raspberry industry with an easy shipping point and probably strawberries could be cultivated too. The possibilities of a dairy industry in connection with the school should be investigated. Farming will never be a basic industry for these Indians. The country they live in will not permit it. Another possibility that ought to be thoroughly investigated is fur farming. If in the future, it is thought wise to establish a colony for the graduates of the schools between berries, furs, fishing, timber and garden plots, they should be able to establish themselves either on the school property or on the Reserve and have a fine chance to develop under supervision these and other occupations suited to the character of the country in a section that affords an easy market.
None of the land on this location is cleared, but clearing would be easy. One thing that ought to be carefully safeguarded is the burning of brush in order that the extent of mould damaged by the fires may be as small as possible. Every inch of mould on top of this soil is of very great value.

If Captain Edwards, or the Indian Department acting through some representatives, can secure this particular location, we feel that it will be the best possible.
Enclosed you will find a map re the location for the Cecilia Jeffrey School. I think we have a very good thing in view. Now it remains to be seen whether or not we can actually obtain it.

If there is anything more in the way of information that I can supply, please let me know. If we had gone about a mile further south than we did go the day we were at the old golf links we could have been in the heart of this place we are recommending.

I presume that you have a map of the Lake of the Woods with you or that you have easy access to one, so I am not sending one herewith.

My supply is limited.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Convenor of Indian Committee
Presbytery of Winnipeg.

P.S. - There are some suggestions growing out of a study of the plans for the new building which the Committee here is working on. Just now and I will forward them to you at the end of the week. There is nothing radical, but some small things that we think might be considered as possibly designed to add to the effectiveness of the plant.

[Signature]
A. McMEEKIN, M.E.
Ontario Land Surveyor
KENORA, ONTARIO

Kenora, Sept. 25th, 1925.

Capt. Frank Edwards Esq.,
Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont., Dear Sir,

According to your instructions, I have laid out a road from the north limit of Indian Reserve 38A and do not hesitate to recommend it as a feasible road which can be built at a reasonable cost. The land is not difficult piece of country to make a road. The grades are not so steep as those from Kenora to Kenwatin and not so much rock except on the last quarter of a mile where the rock enters but is not difficult to make into a good road. The cost will be less than the average road for this country. I shall be pleased to go over it with anyone if you wish any other opinion.

In order to connect with the Kenwatin road I ran a preliminary line from the north-west corner of 126P where the Kenwatin road ends to the point where I started just east of the small lake. I thought it would be no use having a road on the Reserve if it would not easily connect up with the Kenwatin road. This is a hard mile and can be constructed at one-quarter of the ordinary cost. Rev. Mr. Freeman started at the same point but he followed an old tote road to the south-east across a muskeg and then to get back to the west he had to cross a steep hill. Then the distance also would have been much longer. So I tried a road south-east from the Kenwatin road and found an easy level course as I have already stated. I have worked on Rev. Mr. Freeman's plan the course I followed. The saving in distance is evident and will provide a better road.

I am enclosing the field notes for the road. I have also completed the survey of the farm and will forward them in due time. Yours truly,

[Signature]

McMeekin,
Ontario Land Surveyor,
1925-09-25

August 6, 1958

(3) Land - The land lies on both sides of the portage from Red Portage Bay to White Cartridge Bay. The portage is short if all goes well. It is crossed by a road that runs east from the town of the road about ten minutes' walk east, and west of this road there is good land. We have three or four suitable sites for the school, one lying east of the road and north of the portage. There is probably good land extending for a long distance south of the portage. We will, however, have taken the area so that there is at least two acres of usable land available. The only thing I know we will want towards the west. The soil is clay with a very light overlay that the crops I had from Red Indian Bay, and there is a good depth of water on top of it. The timber is much heavier than on the Caribou property, and there would be no fuel problem facing the school.

(4) The building site - The site on which we thought the building might be placed is about perhaps one eighth of a mile long, and it rises as it approaches the main shore by gentle slopes. It also breaks down to lower than the shore line at the base of the two bays, but is well above the water. It gives a very fair view looking north and east. There are a few number of trees around it that would make a park around the school. The two islands sticking out east from the point are small, but together with the passage between them did make another fifth of a mile. Our idea was to fill in the passages between them and the area a point about five miles long. All told so that there would be plenty of room for expansion. The passage between the point and islands is wide enough to allow for boats when the water level is high. At all times the bridge would be drawn up by a little. The passage between island A and island B is practically filled in and would be perhaps another five yards. Between island B and the south shore there is a heavy reed bed. This means that the inner bay is practically land locked. Our plans are carried out except for the passage between islands A and B. This passage will give ten feet of water and the boat house could be set back on the inner bay where there is always good protection. There is good deep water in the outer bay, and with a slight tide there should be no trouble with intake or outlet. The two islands in front would very easily be fitted up as a special section for the staff and would provide excellent, easy access to the main school grounds, and the very finest view of the lake.

I would suggest the following:

(1) That we urge the securing of this location. The government might send in a surveyor who would be able to block out the best size and shape of lot to provide for the needs of the school. This would involve the buying of about fifteen acres of new land. The surveyor could find it. (2) There should be at least five or six acres chosen where the school opens to provide for the school and additional purposes. This house may sitting area.

I believe that the cost of clearing the land and building the required road will be much less than the cost of buying from Caribou and that we will have a very satisfactory property when it is completed. Captain Edwards and Mr. Hamill agree in this.

Please do all you can to secure action at the earliest possible moment, and I will be ready to cooperate from this end.

Yours truly,

Rev. E.O.D. Freeman
Chairman Indian Committee
"United Presbyterian."

August 4, 1925.

Dear Mr. Clark:

Following up the recommendations of our Proprietary Committee for a new location for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Captain Murray, the Indian Agent at Kempen, has been making enquiry, and I have a letter from him dated July 26th in which he states that on Caribouhead property, our Trustee, Mr. H. H. Murray, and the Old Salt Lake property at $4,000 per acre. Captain Murray has also said he will look into the matter, but both these prices are extremely high and Captain Murray suggested that another effort should be made to find a site by his own opinion is that there is quite something for the government or for anyone else to buy anything near the amounts mentioned for either property.

After receiving Captain Murray's letter, I made arrangements to see the new site on the Indian Reserve No. 8 which is just to the south of the Caribouhead property. Mr. Vanasse went with me. I knew there was good land there for it was first place we had investigated, but we did not report on it at all because it was in the Reserve. I think we can now recommend a site which is really on the Caribouhead property and which we ought to be able to secure without any difficulties.

(1) General Location - It is about 6 miles from Kempen, 1 mile from the school. It is about half a mile further than the Caribouhead property. This will give us the advantage of the easy drainage of Kempen, and yet be far enough away to avoid difficulties.

(2) Road - I have walked over the route several times and found that the boundary of the Reserve goes to the north boundary of the property. Through the road is in very fair condition and could easily be improved, and part of the way through the Reserve. Through the Reserve, the road from Kempen to the property could be traveled with a team right now if one were received. In other words, the road from Kempen to the property could be made passable with very little expense under the urge of necessity.

We spent two hours walking over the site we propose for the new school, today. We found a road would be put through without much difficulty, perhaps two miles, so that it is quite possible to get there, and it could not be at all an expensive road in a short time.

Dear Sir:

Have had a letter from our Committee in Winnipeg, who are working in conjunction with Agent Edwards of Kenora, re the securing of a site for the new Indian School at Kawatin. Owing to the owner of the Carnichael site asking an exorbitant price, making it prohibitive, the Committee and Agent Edwards have again gone fully over the situation and have found a location, which they consider an equally good site, on the Indian Reserve, 38.A., only a half mile farther from Kawatin.

From the drawing submitted it appears to have been carefully selected, having in view a building site, good water supply, a sheltered bay for wharf, easy drainage, with a fair amount of good land convenient for cultivation.

We regret that the purchase has been delayed owing to this hold up and hope that work will be begun without further loss of time. The W.M.S. heartily concur with the work done by Captain Edwards and our Committee in Winni-

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

I enclose herewith copy of a letter written by Rev. J. L. Freeman, Convener of the Presbyterian Committee in Winnipeg to Mr. A. Clark of Toronto re proposed site for the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School.

I agree with Mr. Freeman, the only doubt in my mind is as regards the disposal of the sewage and the water intake but Dr. A. D. Ferguson, our Medical Officer is also official officer here and I am arranging with him to visit the site with me and give me a report on same, which I think will be favorable.

The site is on the Indian reserve and before anything was done the land would have to be surrendered by the Indians. I do not think there would be any difficulty about this, but presume we should have to pay them something, until the Department decides to do this I would urge that we provide an indication that the money will be paid them as a cash distribution instead of keeping same in their trust funds.

Should the Department decide to go ahead with the matter I shall be glad to receive instructions so that the tenders be called to enable the Contractors to do a certain amount of work before the cold weather which would hamper the work.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
August 14, 1955.

Memorandum:

Survey Branch,

A site for the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School has been selected by Church and Department representatives and is entirely in Reserve No. A near Kenatin. It is necessary that a survey of the proposed property be made at once so that the proposed road through the reserve to it be made without any delay. Plans are ready and tenders should be called in the immediate future. Will you please secure the name of a surveyor (preferably a Kenora one), to whom this work could be given, and ascertain by telegram if he can undertake it immediately.

Sir,

I have to confirm the following telegram sent you this date:

"You may employ Mr. MacKenzie, O.L.S., to survey parcel approximately two hundred acres in Indian reserve thirty-eight A reserved for proposed school site TOP. Before surveying said parcel he should take road survey from south boundary nearest to proposed site in order to ensure suitable roadway could be constructed without excessive cost."

The surveyor is expected to survey and post a road from the proposed school site to the north boundary of the reserve, connecting at that point with the present road to Keewatin. This work should be undertaken before the actual survey of the parcel is made in order to ensure that the road will not cost an excessive amount for construction.

The surveyor will be paid at the current rates for surveyors in that locality, together with all reasonable expenses. His accounts should be submitted to the Department immediately, together with duplicateouchers covering all expenses. His return will consist of field notes only, report of first patrol surveyed and report on the roadway location together with recommendations regarding probable cost of construction of roadway. His survey will also require compilation of a plat or corner on the boundaries of the reserve and will be properly described and plotted on the departmental plans. I am enclosing a blueprint of R.R.O. No. 38-A for his information. Be good enough to notify the Department as soon as it is determined that road construction is feasible.

Your obedient servant,

F. Edwards Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

(A.F. MacKenzie)
For Assistant Deputy and Secretary.
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont

Indian Agent,
Sir,

Referring to your letter #129-3-9 of last ultimo, Mr. A. MacKeekin was instructed as ordered, and has reported as follows:

According to your instructions I have carefully examined the land on Indian Reserve 30A and find that a road can be made at nearly cost. I have visited other roads in the district and I find that this road will be easier to make than the usual ones in the District. I also had to find a new road to connect with this one that is one running North from Indian Reserve to connect with Keewatin Road. Do they wish this surveyed? This half mile can be made at nearly one third of the usual cost Mr. Freeman's proposed route would entail one mile extra at least, and a great part of it would run through muskeg. If you wish, I am willing to go over your road and you can readily see that this location is preferable by far. Shall submit notes in a few days. I think the site is fine and accessible by land and water.

A. MacKeekin

From the above everything appears to be very advantageous, and I have instructed Mr. MacKeekin to survey the two hundred or so acres required.

In connection with the road from Indian Reserve to Keewatin Road, I would suggest that it would be possible to have the Northern Development Branch do the necessary survey and lay out the road so that we should have no trouble with the owners of adjoining land through which we have to pass. There are several settlers on the route and Mr. Evans, the Ontario Government Representative has informed me that his Government might do the work for us providing we got the consent of Mr. Lyons, Minister of Lands and Forests. I believe they would put the road through without cost to us.

As soon as MacKeekin sends in his notes I will forward them to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary, Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Ottawa, 1st September 1925

The Department is about to erect a new Indian residential school on Indian reserve No.35-A, which is situated on Lake of the Woods, approximately four miles South of Keewatin.

It is reported to the Department that it would be necessary to have a roadway established in order to connect with the Keewatin road from the North boundary of the Indian reserve. As this roadway would also serve several settlements along the route, would you be kind enough to take advantage of the opportunity offered by the Northern Development Board to survey and establish this roadway? It has also been reported to the Department that the cost of construction of the road would be about one-third of the usual cost of road construction in that district.

The Department wishes to go on with construction during the present season and while transportation is simple during the period of open water, it is of course essential that land transportation should also be available. I would, therefore, appreciate it if you could give me an early expression of your views in connection with the establishment of the necessary road.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Lands and Forests, For Assistant Deputy,
Toronto, Ont., Secretary.

Ottawa, 2nd October 1926

Sir,

With further reference to departmental letter of the 1st ultimo and also to your reply of the 5th of the same month, I have to inform you that while it is not imperative to the Department that the road be constructed during the present season, it is essential that the Department be assured that there is nothing in the nature of the holdings between the Indian Reserve and the proposed road so located as would prevent the opening up of a roadway through such property as it would be necessary to cross. It is presumed the patent to these holdings, if issued, contains the usual reservation for roads and that there would be no danger or inconvenience to school children out of school on the occasion. It will be readily appreciated if you will give me an early expression of your views on the above.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Your ref. 108-13

I have received your letter of the 27th ultimo, relating to a surrender made by Mr. Nockskin in connection with the proposed school on Indian reserve No. 36-A. It is the intention of the Department to obtain a surrender from the Indians of the land required and it is hoped that the band will see the advantages of having the school erected on their reserve and will grant the surrender.

It is noted in your letter of the 5th August that you state you consider the Indians would require a certain amount of compensation. If this is necessary, it is hoped that the demand of the Indians will be within what might be considered very reasonable limits. It would be impossible to distribute to them more than fifty per cent of the amount which it was agreed upon to pay for the plot.

You are requested to forward to the Department a valuation per acre of the land involved; should you not have sufficient accurate information to make this valuation, you may consult with Mr. Nockskin. As soon as Mr. Nockskin's returns of survey are received, a description will be made of the property and surrender papers forwarded to you.

Your obedient servant,

The work I sent in relative to base line and distance across lake was a second shot. OTTAWA, 24th October 1926

Sir,

Regarding your returns of survey of school site on Indian reserve No.584, I beg to say we have endeavoured to plot the notes but there are apparently some errors. Your notes are returned for correction.

Your survey of the farm lot, page 3, bearing of course 1-2 has been omitted. The course 3-4 given as N.80 degrees E appears to be nearly N.10 degrees West. The angle off the base line on the point where the school is to be located, given as 90 degrees 45 minutes in your first note, and 131 degrees 17 minutes in your second note should appear, at 110 degrees 23 minutes, making the other angle 70 degrees 43 minutes. Your station 10, page 9, appears to use a point at 1.04 on station 9 to 0 but that is not clearly shown in your notes. Your North line of the school lot should show definite chaining connections to your road survey, the distance, station and angle should be given. This will enable the Department to check your work by closing the two parcels by latitudes and departures.

I am unable to make your road survey check with the crossing given on page 2; perhaps there is a clerical error in some bearing on the road course between the S. limit of 126 P and the N. limit of the school lot. Your notes do not show that a post was planted at each angle of the road as called for in your instructions. Kindly note another the 47 chains distance given on page 1 of road notes is from the N.E. corner of the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

(T.B.L. MacInnes)
For Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Renfrew, Ont.
