I must admit that I thought you harsh in your last letter but I know it is something not to be able to raise the man who is apparently apathetic. Everything he does seems to defeat me.

Even Caesar nodded and many a head as I came a little more time so I came to see the order from start to finish and assure my error. I sat a deal of patience puzzling over the plan but end sadly offered no flight.

Wishing you the compliments of the season.

Yours truly,

A. McFaddin
Box 576
I do not think our work and have been teaching boys to do what is right and thus serve God and other people's errors, but here I am in the same way plight for have a proper right to cut me off from further work, but I need the work and I do not do such work as affords the time. Now, I am at your mercy, I must run the instinct over all fit again and allow my ability to make a satisfactory survey. I have already been into these times, but I really must do it all over again.
not close with the Road Survey. They appear to be some distance off on my trail in their survey. I took an observation but do not know where it went, from memory in getting results, anyway. I sent the field notes. I did not run the instrument over the Reserve line, my west for 25 chain. It came in conformity with the few blazed trees that I thought it would be correct seeing you wished the results seeing you wished my first journey being my first attempt to do work for you, it was certainly rather an awful blame. There is nothing to the survey at all.
They do not fit in. I went over and checked over the Road survey and find distance and angles correct. I extended it on the ice to meet the east limit of farm northwest. I measured again the same distance and find them fairly correct. I checked over the course running over the ice and find that the corner is N18°27'W instead of N18°W. I also double checked the line from the N.E. angle running S45°E in to the ice and stick into my post at N.E. corner of farm. Then I plotted but still is loose.
Dear Sir,

Since receiving your last message through Capt. Edwards, I have endeavoured to straighten out my survey. I must apologise for not replying immediately when you returned my rolls for correction, but just about that time I had a great deal of work which I could not afford to pass by as survey work is very lucrative and has been disappointing for 1938 especially the earlier part of the year.

When making the farm survey I did not check up with the Road Survey.
January 4, 1926.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

A very serious situation will arise if the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School is not ready for occupation next fall. As soon as a proper description is made possible, the surrender should be taken immediately and clearing commenced. I wish to urge also, that tenders for the building be called within the next few weeks, so that the contractor could do considerable of his hauling over the ice or frozen roads. In the summer, his materials could go by water while the road is being made.

Memorandum:

Mr. Caldwell,

The Department is prepared to reconstruct the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School on a site selected on the Rat Portage Indian Reserve No. 38 A. You will note hereunder a description of the parcels required, which comprise 250 acres more or less, which our Surveys Branch considers satisfactory for the purpose of surrender. It is proposed to allow the Indians of the Band a compensation of $6 per acre.

Sir,

As you are aware, the Department proposes shortly to undertake the reconstruction of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School at Rat Portage Indian Reserve No. 38 A., and for the purpose has decided to request the members of the Band to sell 230 acres, more or less, of the reserve, at a price of $5.00 per acre, for school site purposes.

The necessary surrender documents to be submitted to the Band at a meeting to be called for the purpose are enclosed herewith. As the matter is somewhat urgent, you are hereby instructed to call a meeting of the Band for the purpose of considering this question of surrender at the earliest possible convenient date, and to report the result of such meeting immediately to the Department.

You will also find enclosed copy of Instructions to Agents for your guidance in taking surrender, and I have to call your attention particularly to the requirement for furnishing a voters' list and certifying to the number of Indians present at the meeting, the number voting for the surrender and the number against.

Your obedient Servant,

Dear Sir,

I have virtually resurveyed all the line. I took out a team and men and went through the north limit of Reserve for a distance of 3½ of a mile. Then I returned the line. They were the same as I had them.

Instead of the above two, I ran it over the ice. These lines are 86.32 Chs & 11.00 respectively.

I re-measured the Reserve line again and find that the distance is 45.87. I found a post marked Indian Reserve at rather 1.0 P. It is 6.28 chains east of my Road Post. 18° other marks were upon it. Before I measured with a 1.50 chain length and must have got mixed in the new length.

I took the measurement for the Road course and checked all the angles and measured them and found them all correct.
I also measured around the farm with a chain at feet and had placed in the note the chainages.

I also have instrumentation for the first corner of the farm and find the direction correct. Then the closing line of the farm the east limit run on a course N10° E.

I showed on the road corner where it cuts the north limit of the farm.

I could find no known post at the north-east corner. It is very difficult to say where the original post would be.

The corner of the farm is now definitely fixed so that you can build and prepare for the subdivision.

It has taken me longer to do this simple job than to subdivide the 40 acres.

Nothing will be left out and I will go over it all again.

A. W. Franklin

Sir,— 

Replying to your letter of the 8th instant

A Council meeting was held at the Agency yesterday at which were present 22 Indians of the Rat Portage and Dalles Band to consider surrendering part of Reserve 38A for the purpose of erecting a School. The object of the meeting was fully explained to the Bands and they were recommended to surrender which they were satisfied to do, but they wanted to get $10 per acre for the land, instead of $5 as suggested which in my opinion is a very fair price.

I had seen the Chief and some of the Indians previously and they seemed agreeable to let the land go at the price offered, but some advised them to hold for a high price, thinking the Department was compelled to buy at their price.

Rev. Mr. Sanderson was at the meeting and also Chief Redsky of the Shoal Lake Band (near where the present Cecilia Jeffrey School is situated, and these two also advised the Indians to sell.

We informed them that they had over 21,000 acres of land on their Reserves and that all we wanted was about 230 acres, of land that they did not occupy, and which was of no value to them, but an agreement was not reached.

There are about 44 male Indians entitled to vote, but we could only get 22 at the meeting as so many are away trapping.

If necessary another meeting could be called at a later date when more could be present, and the matter reconsidered, but I do not think we could get them together until Treaty time about 1st June.

I would therefore suggest that the Department take the land, which they have the power to do under Section #11A of the Indian Act, paying them at the rate of $5.00 per acre, which is the valuation as placed on the property by Mr. McKeen, the only surveyor we have in the Town.

If we wish to call for tenders right away the above will be the quickest way to get action.

Before the meeting broke up, the Indians were informed that the Department had power to take the land, without surrender, under Section #11, and that in all probability probably this was what the Department would do.

I am holding the surrender papers here and shall be glad to receive further instructions.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

129-3-9

Ottawa, March 5, 1926.

The Schools

Mr. Gordon Hudson and Mr. H. Westin, both of Kenora, Ont., may be asked for quotations for the clearing of the land required for the site of the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school.

J. J. T. A.
Ottawa, March 6, 1926.

Dear Mr. Edwards:

I have your letter of the 6th ultimo, concerning the 250 acre farm and site for the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. I note that 28 of the 44 Indians entitled to vote on the matter refused to surrender. The Department is prepared to take the land in question under Section II A of the Indian Act, if such action is found necessary. At Treaty time, you should make another effort to follow instructions of my letter of January 8th last. You should explain to the Indians that the property has been valued at $6 per acre by Mr. Maclean, and as it is intended to use it solely for the benefit of the Indian people, the Department is not prepared to pay a larger price.

In the meantime, I wish to arrange for an immediate clearing of some 15 or 20 acres of the point on which the school is to be situated. You should ask Mr. Gordon Hudson and Mr. H. Westin, both of Kenora, to quote on this work. It should be remembered, moreover, that the successful tenderers will engage Indian labour as far as possible. Have the work proceeded with at once, and when you are submitting an account, you should attach the written offers of the two contractors mentioned. The exact amount of clearing to be done should be determined by yourself.

Yours very truly,

Duncan L. Maclean
Deputy Superintendent General.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, 10th March 1926

Sir,

When checking Mr. McKeekin's account in order to remit the balance of $71.80 which is still due him, it was found that the receipts of the different men employed by him do not show the dates upon which they were employed and the Auditor's Office, in order that his main account marked may be properly adjusted require that these days be given on each receipt. It is also noted that although his account shows that two men were employed for half a day on the 9th September and although his total receipt shows men paid at $4.00 for 30 days, none of these receipts show any men receiving a half day's pay. This very evidently indicates an error in either the account or the receipt.

I am returning these for correction and I would request you to have them properly amended by Mr. McKeekin at an early date and you might point out to him that as the survey vote for the fiscal year expires on the 1st April, if the corrected accounts are not returned to the Department before that date, he will require to wait for his final settlement until the appropriation for next year is available. This might necessitate a delay in settling his account until May or June.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

(J.D. McLean)
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

A telegram has reached me from Mr. D.G. Scott, in which he asks me to submit tenders received from Messrs. Hudson and Westin of Kenora for clearing the site of the new school on the Clearwater Bay reserve, the award to be made from Ottawa.

We inspected the school site on Saturday the 29th inst., in company with Mr. A. McMeekin, O.L.S., who is satisfied that the site chosen is most suitable for the building.

No action has yet been taken regarding the clearing, since nothing can be built until the ice goes out.

I would therefore suggest that the matter of clearing be deferred somewhat, especially since the Rev. E.D.O. Freeman, convener of the school committee in Winnipeg, has promised to come and choose what he considers the best land for the garden, stable, etc.

The site for the actual school building is rocky and very lightly timbered, so that the clearing for it can be done in a short time.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edward
Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

R/A
Sir,

On the first inst., the Rev. E.D.G. Freeman came to Kenora and accompanied me to see the new Cecilia Jeffery School site. We decided it was inadequate to clear more than five or six acres, that being enough for the school building, the barn and a small playground, the remainder (to make up about 15 or 20 acres) to be cleared when the snow is gone and the most desirable arable soil can be seen.

Mr. J.H. Simons, who intends tendering for the building, was with Mr. Freeman.

Mr. Simons thinks the site is all right, although there may be some rock excavation and rather more concrete than usual owing to the character of the surface.

The site is not the extreme best, but a better could not be acquired in the circumstances.

Regarding the clearing, the actual place for the building is not heavily timbered, and I would suggest the employment of Indians for this, on the basis of day labour, since the property is not far from this office, and the work could be superintended from here. Failing your approval of this suggestion, which I think is a good one, I shall ask Messrs. Westin and Hudson for their respective tenders.

If you decide in favour of the day labour plan, I should be glad to get a cheque (accountable) for $250.00 for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Please call to the attention of the Minister.
The Indians of Keewatin have been petitioning the government for a school. The Indian Agent Edwards proposes building a school near Keewatin. They say that Agent Edwards has selected a site and intends utilizing 230 acres of their Reserve 38A on Clearwater Bay. He has asked the Band to let that portion of the Reserve for that purpose, and tells them that they will get $5.00 an acre for it. The Band objects. They say that it is worth $25.00 an acre. He tells them that the Department will take it anyway, and that they will get no compensation. The land is fairly well timbered and valuable even for cordwood. The land the property should be worth what they claim. At present and for years past wood sells here at $3.00, $9.00 and $10.00 a cord, and only 3 miles from Town of Keewatin.

Sir,

In reply to yours of the 8th inst regarding the clearing of land for the site of the new Cecilia Jeffery Indian School I am sorry there was any misunderstanding attending the invitation of tenders. However, Messrs. G.H. Hudson and H. Westin have now submitted their offers.

Mr. Hudson will cut, clean, and burn the brush on the land for the school site for $45 per acre, and will stump at $50.00 per acre.

Mr. H. Westin's price for clearing is $35 per acre and $45.00 for stumping and grabbing.

From the above you will observe that Mr. Westin's price is the lower, and if the contract be awarded to him I would suggest the employment of Indian labour as part of the contract.

We could get the work done by Indians, involving constant supervision, and I would therefore suggest the awarding of the contract to Mr. Westin with the above condition embodied.

I should be glad to know your decision in this matter, so that the successful tenderer may be notified from this office.

Providing the estimates have been passed, it would seem to be in order to request tenders for building as soon as possible.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.

Sir,

The Rev. E.D.G. Freeman was here yesterday after making a trip to introduce the Presbyterian Missionary to the Indians on Lake of the Woods.

In discussing the new Cecilia Jeffery Residential School he asked me what had been done about letting the tenders for clearing and construction, and was surprised that no action had so far been taken.

He is writing the Ontario Government Agricultural Representative for this district for advice regarding the best part to clear for gardening purposes.

He considers the exact site for the building should be cleared at once, and tenders called for at an early date for erection of the building to let this be done in summer and not left until fall, when building is more expensive and the concrete liable to damage by frost.

I expected Mr. Orr would have been down during May, but Mr. Bury says he does not think he will be down until July.

Kindly let me know what arrangements have been made so that I can inform the parties concerned.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In reference to the Department's letter No. 129-3-9 of Jan 8th, 1926, I enclose herewith documents duly completed for the surrender of part of Indian reserve #38A.

We had some difficulty in getting the band to surrender this property, since they felt that $5.00 per acre was insufficient. Personally I think they have got a good price.

To enable me to get the surrender I had to premise a cash distribution this summer, which can be done from the Interest Funds without interfering with the Capital Account. I would recommend, accordingly, that the Rat Portage and Dalles Band receive a distribution of $20.00 per head, which can be paid them about July 15th, when I return from paying the bands up north. I should be glad, therefore, if you would send me a cheque for $3,100.00 to arrive here not later than July 12th.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, July 12th, 1926.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned begs to submit herewith a surrender in duplicate, given on the 2nd day of June, 1916, by the Ojibwa band of Indians, whose reserve is situated in the District of Kenora, in the Province of Ontario, of all those parcels of land situate in the Rat Portage Indian Reserve No. A, containing together two hundred and thirty acres, more or less, described as follows:

"All those parcels of land situate in the Rat Portage Indian Reserve number Thirty-eight A in the District of Kenora, Province of Ontario and Dominion of Canada, containing together two hundred and thirty acres, more or less, being composed of that rectangular portion of the reserve fronting Rat Portage Bay of Lake of the Woods, surveyed by Mr. Macdonald, Ontario Land Surveyor, in 1925, for a school site, together with a right of way for road one chain in width from the north boundary of the reserve to the school site, the said road to be constructed where deemed most suitable."

The said surrender has been given in order that the said lands may be sold to the Department of Indian Affairs at the price of $5.00 per acre for school purposes.

MacKenzie, Ont. Land Surveyor, in 1905, for a school site, together with a right of way for a road one chain in width from the north boundary of the reserve to the school site, the said road to be constructed where deemed most suitable."

OTTAWA.
Sir—

I am informed by the principal of Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School that the Department contemplates the erection of the new school this year.

The proposed site on Res.39A was approved by Rev. R.D.G. Freeman, convenor of the Winnipeg Committee in charge of home missions, by Dr. Orr our district, by Rev. A.D. McKenzie of C.J. School, by Mr. Simmons who built the Sioux Lookout school, and myself. The Ontario Land Surveyor, Mr. Lukekin, also approved of it, and Dr. Ferguson approved of the facilities for obtaining water and disposing of sewage. The site was surveyed, and the Indians signed surrender forms.

However, since seeing the new school at Sioux Lookout, and in view of the fact that the Ontario Government are building new roads in this district, and considering that the new school will be built for the Presbyterians and not for the United Church, I feel that the question of the site should be looked into again, as I am not wholly satisfied that the site chosen is now the best available.

The site chosen for the building is a narrow point which would practically be covered by the buildings. This site is mostly rock, and as the playgrounds, kitchens, etc., are semi-basement, the cost of excavation would be very heavy, so much so indeed that I believe its abolition would reimburse us for the cost of surveying.

I have lately discussed the matter with Mr. Macdonald of Cecilia Jeffrey School, Mr. Robertson and Robertson of the Board of Education respectively, and Mr. Ordinarily, that since the Presbyterian Church will be the school, and has had no chance to give an opinion on the matter, its committee in Winnipeg be asked to inspect this site, and, if they think it unsuitable, to suggest another. For your information I may say that there is no church in Temora or Leamington representing the Presbyterians, these churches having been acquired by the United Church.

The matter might also be referred for an opinion.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Assistant Deputy
Dept. of Indians
Ottawa.

When the location of this school was agreed upon, I know, only two weeks ago. In one or two letters that I have had from the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School she has commented that it might be better if the site were somewhere in the vicinity of Kenora or Keewatin, and preferably on the lake. I do not know whether the location is such that it satisfies the Department, but when the new school is being erected it should be placed in the most suitable place to meet the needs of the children, and also where there could be sufficient land suitable for cultivation, to raise the necessary food for both the children and the animals. I just mention this to you because it is now a new Board under which the direction of this school lies, and we would like to hear if the Department and the Agent on the Reserve are fully satisfied as to the location.

Kenora, Ont.,
16th April, 1928.

Dear Mr Orr,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 12th inst., re your visit to pick out a site for the new Cecilia Jeffrey School.

The Lakes are full of ice yet and we do not expect to be able to go anywhere by boat until after the 10th or 12th of May, and we wish to start our Treaty payments about the 19th so there will not be much time in between. I do not know if you intend visiting the McIntosh and Sioux Lookout Schools, but if so I would advise we go there first, as we can get there even if there is ice on the lakes.

It is very difficult to get a good site that covers all the points the school want, and I would suggest you ask the representative of the Church to get in touch with their local men, and be in a position to suggest a suitable site when they come and meet you here.

I believe we can get anywhere by about the 13th May and would suggest this date for you to be here, but the weather is so uncertain it is hard to be sure.

The boats started navigation up the Lakes on the 8th May last year but they had to break ice.

Make your own date and let me know where you would like me to meet you and I will arrange it. I have not yet absolutely decided on my dates of Treaty payments, but when I start, it takes 6 weeks, as we go about 1500 miles, and if left too late, we have such a short summer in Kenora.

Kindest regards, and looking forward to seeing you.

Yours very faithfully

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 1st instant, re site for proposed Cecilia Jeffrey School.

It is very difficult to find a good site, but we have suggestions to put before the Representative of the Church and Mr Orr when they arrive, providing they decide the site originally decided on is not suitable. Two of the new suggested sites being on Reserve 38A, one at Joplar Bay and one at Clearwater Bay.

I have today received a letter from Mr the Rev. R. Peterson in which he states he is ready at any time to meet us here. I shall be glad to receive word when Mr Orr will be in Edmonton so that I can communicate with Mr Peterson, and arrange for Mr Peterson to be here when he arrives.

If Mr Orr could be here on the 13th inst., it would be the most convenient date for us as our Treaty payments start on the 19th, and after that date until the beginning of July we shall be out of town most of the time.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, May 21, 1920.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

I beg to report that on May 16th, in company with Mr. Edwards and the Reverend Mr. Patterson, representative of the Presbyterian Church, we made an inspection of the sites suggested for the proposed new Emma Jeffrey School.

We first visited the site selected two years ago by the Reverend Mr. Freeman of the Presbyterian Church located on Reserve 30A, a distance of approximately four miles by boat from Kenora. I examined the proposed location for the new building and found it would be impossible to erect a building on this site, owing to the lack of sufficient space, and also that the entire property was a rock formation.

We then visited the site on Poplar Bay, a further distance of about 1½ miles by water and also located on Reserve 30A. On this property there is a good building site; the land appears to be suitable for cultivation, but at the present time the entire property is heavily timbered and a portion would have to be cleared, also it would require the construction of a road to connect it with the road leading to Kenora.

We then visited several farms on the main land in the vicinity of Kenora in order to ascertain if a suitable property could be purchased as a site for the proposed new school. The most satisfactory property was one owned by Mr. Smith and located approximately two miles east of Kenora on a small lake known as Kenora Lake, which is connected to the Lake of the Woods by Lawrence Creek. This site consists of approximately 150 acres, 80 of which are clear and under cultivation. There is on the property a farm house, barn and several out buildings, and the farm consists of two cows, three horses, three poultry, together with the usual amount of farm machinery. Electric power is available on the property from Kenora. There are good springs available for a water supply system and a very desirable location could be selected on which to place the building.
Of the two sites above mentioned, the Gould property has many advantages. The cost of clearing 50 acres of land on the Poplar Bay site, and the building of a road would cost approximately $14,000.00, or $28,000.00 for clearing and $6,000.00 for the road, while on the Gould property 50 acres are already cleared and under cultivation, and there is a good road from the property to Kenora, and Mr. Gould offered this farm, including all buildings, stock, implements, etc., for $9,000.00.

If the buildings were erected on the Poplar Bay site, it would be necessary to install our own electric lighting plant, whilst on the Gould property, electric power is available. It is a great advantage to have electric delivery to the school, which eliminates the expense of installing electric plant and the high operating costs when the school is in operation. The Reverend Mr. Paterson and Indian Agent Edwards agreed with me that the Gould property was the best site available for the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey School, and I beg to recommend for your consideration that this property be purchased. Dr. Ferguson of Kenora who is well acquainted with the Kenora district considered that the price for the Gould property was fair and reasonable.

[Signature]

Department of Indian Affairs.
TORONTO July 10th, 1946.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I am wondering what is being done about the new Cecilia Jeffrey School. I had a letter from our Mr. Paterson after his visit to look over sites with the government architect, in which he said they favored a site near Kenora. I have not heard anything further.

I also wished to say that I have been elected President of our Women's Missionary Society and so will be giving up the secretariatship of the Indian work. Mrs. D. F. L. McKerroll, 19 Inns Street, Toronto, will be in charge of the department.

If you will let me know about the site, and then future communications can go to Mrs. McKerroll.

Yours sincerely,

(Helen M. Stinson)

Kenora, Ont., July 13, 1928.

Duncan G. Scott, M.P.,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

As instructed by you yesterday, I visited the Long property this afternoon with Mr. Ferguson, who kindly drove me out, and we went over the property together.

This property has a good clear-water lake from which water can be had for drinking and utility purposes. The owner informs me that he has about 10 acres, of which about 5 acres is cleared and a considerable quantity is under cultivation. There is a good barn on the property, but the residence and other buildings would not be of much use to us. It appears to us that the best site for the main school building would be on the side of the hill facing the rail-road and south behind the barn. There would be a certain amount of rock excavation, but I do not think this would be an expensive proposition. The land is good and fertile and we both think this would be a suitable property for the requirements of a school. The owner has some post-sets on the land but I think it would be more than the school requires. There is also a good gravel hill which the owner is willing to help himself, and he is willing to supply, free of charge, all the gravel which would be required in the construction of the school.

As regards the J. Gould property, there is slightly more land cleared, but about the same acreage of land to be sold. There is also a gravel pit on that property, but the main objection is that drinking water could not be obtained from the lake, and wells would have to be dug.

Irrespective of price, I think that the Long property would be a slightly better property for our needs.

On Mr. Orr's arrival, the doctor has kindly offered to take us out and we could look up the merits of both properties.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Deputy Minister of Justice,

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that in accordance with the instructions contained in your letter of the 22nd of August, I have today recorded the title to the property which the Department of Indian Affairs proposes to acquire from Mr. Long. The Indian Agent himself being away and a new clerk being in the office, I obtained the description from Mr. Long.

Unless he has inadvertently omitted one parcel the acres which the Department would obtain is considerably less than 160 acres. Mr. Long advises me that his proposed way to sell the north part at Location 1722 and Location 338. The south part of Location 1261 is Parcel 4518 containing 72 acres more or less covering the right of way of the C.P.R., across this north part which contains 611 acres more or less. This property is subject to a Charge No. 18081 dated the 12th of June 1927 registered June 27th, 1927 in favour of the Agricultural Development Board for $2800.00 at six percent interest and also subject to a Charge No. 18082 dated the 27th of June 1927, registered 27th of June 1927 in favour of the Imperial Bank of Canada for $2700.00 interest at eight percent, which was to become payable on June 29th, 1929. Neither of the above charges have been discharged.

Location 266P is Parcel 5927 on Round Lake in the Township of Jeffray containing fifty acres more or less and is subject to a Charge No. 13066 dated June 4th 1915, registered June 7th, 1915 in favour of Alexander A. Hall for $450.00 with interest at eight percent payable in equal annual instalments in the years 1916, 1917 and 1918. This mortgage has not been discharged.

I also searched in the Land Titles Office as to executions and found that none were registered as against Mr. Long. From information I have received, there is no possibility of a Mechanics' or Lien being filed as against the property.
I therefore beg to report that so far as these parcels are concerned, upon the release of the mortgages above described, which would be done before handing over the compensation money, that the state of the title is satisfactory and that there are no tenants to be settled with. I also beg to certify that apart from the current farm taxes, there are no arrears of municipal, school or other taxes against the property.

On the return of the Indian Agent which should be before the end of this week, I will endeavour to secure further information as to what other property is included in the transaction, and will report on that in due course.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, July 11, 1928.

Dear Dr. Scott:

With further reference to the Cassia Jeffrey Indian School at Emmaus, I beg to advise that the following is submitted as a site for this school:

Farm consisting of one hundred and sixty-eight acres (168), seventy cleared, fifty-five acres cultivated.

Fully modern dairy barn, 50 x 110 feet, accommodate 24 cows, a bull pen, a pen for sick cows and stables for 12 calves, 2 milk dairy rooms, stables for 6 horses. The loft will hold two hundred (200) ton of hay, equipped with sling and hay fork.

Hot Cellar 20 x 24 feet under barn.

Silo 16 x 36—east $1000.00.

A steam pumping station to tank in barn (tank 4000 gallons).

Ice House 10 x 20 feet.

Dwelling House, story and half 36 x 30 feet, with lean to kitchen 17 x 20 feet.

Bunk House 20 x 24 feet. Barn and house lighted by electricity. Barn equipped with electric conveyor for removing manure.

There is a good lake on farm from which water is pumped to barn. Lake is 50 feet deep, fed by five springs never known to freeze. A gravel pit measures one hundred thousand (100,000) yards. About 500 cords of fire wood of fair size.

Stock—Twenty (20) Milking Cows

Eight (8) Heifers Yearling

$1,700.00

Two (2) Bulls

Eight (8) Horses worth $1,000.00

Six (6) Brand cows

One (1) Boar

$200.00

One hundred (100) chickens.

Implements—Silo outfit complete, three ploughs, one set harrows, hay rake, mower, binder, cultivator, one roller, forks and hay knives, five wagons, three derricks, full set harness for each horse and all other implements required for ordinary farm use.
Terms—Farm, Twelve thousand ($12,000.00) without gravel pit. Fifteen thousand ($15,000.00) with gravel pit, or farm as it stands complete as a going concern, seventeen thousand ($17,000.00).

If farm is bought without gravel pit, gravel and sand will be supplied free for building purposes.

Yours very truly,

J.B. O'Neill,
Departmental Solicitor.

July 15th, 1928.

Dear Mr. O'Neill,

In Dr. Scott's absence I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant regarding the site for the proposed new Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School at Kenora.

Dr. Scott left for the West last Tuesday night and I understand that it was his intention to stay over at Kenora and look into this matter personally. I expect that we will receive word from him in due course.

Yours very truly,

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

September 5th, 1920.

Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In accordance with instructions given in your letter of the 17th ult., we have made a careful examination of the W. E. Long property comprising Locations 258 P., North part of 128 P., and South part 128 P., all in the Township of Jaffray adjacent to Kenora, and of the buildings, stock and equipment.

(a) We would place a value of $28,420.00 for the whole farm and buildings, including gravel pit on the property and stock and equipment.

(b) And for the farm and buildings, stock and equipment, exclusive of the gravel pit, $19,420.00.

We consider these values very conservative. The gravel pit is estimated by Mr. Long to be worth $3,000.00; which figure we have placed on it as he is prepared to deduct this amount from price he has given you for the whole farm. The gravel pit is, in our opinion, not necessary for farm purposes as there is gravel elsewhere on the farm.

This property is in our opinion nicely located for your proposed industrial school.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
September 10th, 1928.

Dear Captain Edwards,

I have received a valuation from Mr. George A. Toole and Mr. M. Desgagniers on the property which we propose to buy for the Cecilia Jeffrey school, namely, Location 256 P., 50 acres, N. part Location 123 P., 65.67 acres, and S. part Location 123 P., 67 acres, a total acreage of 183.67 acres. I have an interim report from Mr. H. F. Cooke, Esq., who made an examination of the title. In his letter he states—

"Mr. Long advises me that his proposal was to sell the northern part of Location 123 P., and Location 256 P."

He also says, "On the return of the Indian agent, which should be before the end of this week, I will endeavour to secure further information as to what other property is land used in the transaction and will report on that in due course."

It was our intention to purchase the property originally offered, which included the S. part of 123 P. Kindly interview Mr. Cooke and clear up this matter; also ask him to bring his report up to date.

It is our intention to purchase the property without the gravel pit and not to acquire the stock or implements.

Kindly let me know whether the services of a surveyor will be required for a proper description of the property.

Yours very truly,

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

The Deputy Minister of Justice,

Dear Sir:

Further in connection with my letter of August 26th reporting on the condition of title of Parcels 6068 and 5927. On the return of the Indian Agent, I again got in touch with him with Mr. Long and find that the sale proposal comprised land of which Mr. Long had failed to properly advise me included another portion of land.

Mr. Long's sale proposal includes in addition to the two already reported on, the south part of homestead lot 13 in the Township of Jeffrey, which is parcel 1100 containing 67 acres more or less, generally the south portion of the location lying south of Parcel 6068 and north of the old right-of-way of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company containing 67 acres more or less.

The title is in the name of Mr. Wilbert E. Long and is subject to charges 19021 reported on previously in connection with parcel 6068 and 19022 reported on in connection with the same parcel.

I might state that in conversation with the owner of the Imperial Bank, the bank's mortgage has been fully paid off. I have no information at present in connection with that of the Agricultural Development Board.

I also searched as to executions in my former letter and found none. I therefore urge to report that so far as parcel 1100 is concerned, the release of the mortgage above described that the status of the title is satisfactory, and that there are no tenants to be settled with.

I also beg to certify that apart from the current year's taxes, there are no amounts of municipal, school or other taxes against the said property. The addition of the parcel referred to in the latter will make approximately 100 acres of the land proposed to be sold to the Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa September 11th, 1928.

Hon. Peter Heenan,
Minister of Labour,
Kenora, Ont.
Replying to your letter "129-3-9" of 10th inst re new Scotia Jeffrey School.

I have seen Mr. Cooke who informs me that he has now sent in completed report on the property which includes the S. part of 1227.

Mr. Cooke informs me that he does not think a Surveyor is necessary for a proper description of the property unless the Department is not going to take the gravel pit, as the full description will be in the transfer. Well in case of our not purchasing the gravel pit it might be advisable to have this surveyed so that it could be excluded from the transfer, as we do not know exactly what area is meant to be excluded as being gravel pit, as this pit covers a fairly large area.

I have obtained a copy of Lessors Seagmiller and Toole's report and they give the area of the gravel pit as three acres.

Our surveyor Mr. Fairchild expects to be in Kenora next month and he could survey the property if you wish providing this is not too late. Find out if you desire it there is a local surveyor Mr. Heskin who could do the necessary work.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 18th September 1923

Sir,

A survey is required of a farm in the vicinity of Kenora, known as the Long property, in the Township of Jaffray, consisting of Location 269 P., 50 acres more or less, the N. part of Location 132 P., 63.82 acres more or less, and the S. part of Lot 41 in 27 P., 67 acres more or less, making a total of 181.69 acres, more or less. The Department contemplate purchasing the whole farm with the exception of a gravel pit said to contain about 3 acres, the limits of which are to be posted.

Your plan should show the limits of the property, with reference to the parcel to be excluded. Further details in connection with the property may be obtained from the Indian Agent, Mr. W. F. Cooke, K.C., Harbottle, Kenora. You will please commence at once on the basis of the limits area determined could be properly claimed. Your return should consist of a plan on tracing linen, accompanied by a list of all duplicates for all expenditures. For this service you will be paid at the rate of $15.00 per day.

It is necessary that the work should be undertaken almost immediately and if you are not in a position to undertake it at once, kindly inform the Department by wire.

Your obedient servant,

(A.P. MacKenzie)
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Agriculture Branch, O.L.S.,
Kenora, Ont.
Kenora, Ont.
16th September, 1928

Sir,

Whilst visiting the Long property (proposed site of the new Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School) today, the owner Mr Long informed me he had heard nothing definite as to whether the Department intended buying or not, and he would be glad to hear as soon as possible, and also what if any the Department was purchasing as if we did not purchase the stock and gravel pit, he would like to make arrangements for the disposal &c of same.

In the event of the Department not purchasing the gravel pit and stock, could he use the barn and buildings until the new school was ready to be taken over by the Church? This would mean a great deal to him, as he has winter feed and supplies put up, and he would also like to continue living in the house until needed.

His sunflower crop is not yet cut and this will be on the exact site of the buildings, and if Mr Long could be given definite information as to what we are purchasing, and when we would take possession, he would make arrangements accordingly.

Mr Long says should an Inspector be required on the building he would be willing to act, as he is living on the property, and belongs to the United Church. I do not know if Mr Long knows enough to be appointed Inspector, but I would like the Department to appoint someone as we are very busy in the office, and would prefer not to take on the position myself.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Indian Agent.

P.S. Kindly let me know what information I should give out to Mr Long.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the proposed site for the new Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School, I beg to advise you that a survey has been forwarded to the Solicitor through the Department of Justice for the purchase of the property. It is the intention to purchase the land and buildings at Mr. Lang's price of $12,000.00. Dr. Duncan J., Deputy Superintendent General,

Dear Sir,

I have received a letter from the principal of Cecilia Jeffrey in regard to the site chosen for the Indian School, which is to be built by the Department. It seems that this site is a very good one and in a place where it will be well seen from all directions. There is only one objection which has arisen, and to which I was asked to draw your attention, and that is that the barns are at a distance of half a mile from the projected site. This means that in winter the boys for carrying milk would have to go a distance of half a mile and back, and in the cold winters of that region this would mean real hardship. Could I ask if it had been the intention of the Department to build further barns nearer the School, or could the present barn buildings be moved should this site be the final site? I have been informed that the barns would be moved with difficulty to make such an idea feasible. I matter to your attention and await an early

Thanking you for all your trouble in regard to matter.

[Signature]

Lokeroll, Secretary, Indian Department.

Dear Sir:

-Res. Lands for Indian Department.

I am enclosing two plans in connection with the property to be acquired from Mr. Long. The larger of the two plans shows all the property which the Department is acquiring, particularly the north part of Location 122 P, with a portion of the reservation for gravel pit, and a reservation of twenty feet wide to allow access to the pit, and from it to the east boundary which crosses the C.P.R. at the western limit of Location 122 P.

The smaller plan shows the balance of the acreage of the gravel pit of the south part of 122 P as well as an outline of the reservation shown in the larger plan. If this is satisfactory to your Department, I will see that the proper description of both parcels which comprises the north part of 122 P and the south part of 122 P, less the reservation, according to the surveyor's description, is inserted in the transfer as well as that of 266 P.

I might state that a Cessation of Charge from the Imperial Bank to Mr. Long has already been registered, and that arrangements have been concluded with the Agricultural Development Board for the forwarding of the necessary Cessation of the Charge which they hold, and also the charge of Mr. A. A. Hall will be disposed of by the registration of a proper cessation.

Please be good enough to return both tracings as it is my intention to attach them to the transfer, and have them on record in the Land Titles Office here.

Has it been the practice of the Province of Ontario to charge the Dominion of Canada the usual one-fifth of one percent on the purchase price of transfers under the provisions of the Land Transfer Tax Act when the property is being acquired by the Dominion for Dominion purposes? I will be glad to hear from you in this connection.

Ottawa, December 13, 1928.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that the Department of Indian Affairs has negotiated for the purchase of lands required for the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian boarding school from Mr. W. E. Long of the township of Jaffrey in the Province of Ontario, as follows:

Farm land 250 P., containing fifty acres, more or less; the North part of 123 P., containing sixty-three acres and six hundredths of an acre, more or less, and the South part of 123 P., containing sixty-two acres and eighty-nine hundredths of an acre, more or less, in the vicinity of Round Lake in the district of Kenora, Province of Ontario, at a price of Twelve Thousand Dollars, which includes the buildings situated on the said lands comprising dwelling house, work house and bunk room, garage and chickenhouse, ice house, pump house, barn and silo.

The title to these properties has been investigated by an agent of the Department of Justice and has been found to be satisfactory.

The undersigned has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for the purchase by the Department of Indian Affairs of the said lands and buildings for the purpose herein mentioned, at the said price of Twelve Thousand Dollars which is considered fair and reasonable in accordance with a valuation made for the Department. Funds for this purpose are available in the Vote for Indian Education.

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22nd December 1928.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 16th December, 1928, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that the Department of Indian Affairs has negotiated for the purchase of lands required for the new Cecilia Jeffrey Indian boarding school from Mr. W. E. Long of the township of Jeffrey in the Province of Ontario, as follows:

Farm land 250 P., containing fifty acres, more or less; the North part of 182 P., containing sixty-three acres and six hundredths of an acre, more or less, and the South part of 182 P., containing sixty-two acres and eighty-nine hundredths of an acre, more or less, in the vicinity of Onion Lake in the district of Kenora, Province of Ontario, at a price of Twelve Thousand Dollars, which includes the buildings situated on the said lands comprising dwelling house, work house and bunk room, garage and chicken house, ice house, pump house, barn and silo.

The title to these properties has been investigated by an agent of the Department of Justice and has been found to be satisfactory.

The Minister therefore recommends that authority be granted for the purchase by the Department of Indian Affairs of the aforesaid lands and buildings for the purpose hereinabove mentioned, at the said price of $12,000 which is considered fair and reasonable in accordance with a valuation made for the Department. Funds for this purpose are available in the Vote for Indian Education.

The Committee advises that the requisite authority be granted accordingly.

[Signature]
Clerk of the Privy Council.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith a letter from Mr. Morgan John, landscape gardener, for Patmore Nursery.

Mr. John is an expert of wide experience, having worked in Paris and in England, and he is keenly interested in his work.

This service to me has been volunteered owing to his being a friend of mine, but I would like to have him out to ground where we could see the site so it is.

We have a magnificent site here and there are wonderful possibilities for the beautifying of the grounds and I would like to have the cooperation of such an authority as Mr. John.

I would ask to have authority to pay his whole expenses from Brandon to Winnipeg. I don't think he would charge for his time, but would expect his expenses. Enclosing you my reply.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

[Stamp: Jun 5 1929]

PERSONAL.

Sir,

Received your letter 129-3-9 of the 23rd inst., and in reply would refer to your letter of March 6th, and your telegram of March 20th, both referring to the clearing of land for the new Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School.

I understand from your letter of the 6th inst., that Mr. Gordon Hudson and Mr. H. Westin should be asked to tender, and I enclose copy of the letter sent to the local papers, because I did not know that tenders were limited to these two, there being other local firms just as well fitted for the work.

As soon as tenders are received they will be submitted to Ottawa so that you can make the award.

The Rev. E.D.G. Freeman, on behalf of the church, is coming to Kenora on Thursday April 1st, to inspect the school site and help me to pick out the most suitable part for the clearing.

Trusting my action meets with your approval

April 8, 1926.

Dear Captain Edmyns,

I have your letter of the 30 ultimo in reference to the steps taken by you to obtain prices for clearing the land in connection with the new Cecilia Jeffrey school.

I fail to understand your interpretation of Departmental letter of the 6th ultimo. You commence your letter to the local papers as follows:

"I have been instructed to invite tenders, etc."

whereas the instructions were explicit to ask Mr. Hudson and Mr. Martin to make prices and to award the contract at once to the successful tenderer and have the work proceeded with; there was no question of submitting the offers to Ottawa for an award.

Kindly submit the offers you receive for consideration.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Captain Frank Edmyns,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Winnipeg, Manitoba
July 6th 1928.

Dear Dr. Scott:

On my way through Kenora I saw Mayor Walker and others interested in the new Indian school. They advised me that Lawrence lake has been condemned by the medical authorities, and that it is not nearly as desirable as the one suggested in the enclosed memorandum. The site suggested by them is the same distance from Kenora but contains more improvements.

In order to get a speedy settlement of the whole matter I wish you would arrange to stop off between trains and visit the two properties as they are only about twenty-five miles from town. If this is agreeable to you I will request that you bring Mr. Orr along with you. I will notify Mayor Walker and other interested parties that will meet you with an automobile to take you out to show you the properties. Then you can come to a conclusion as to which is the most desirable for our purposes.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Sect. General,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

the book. Both gentlemen are held in high regard by the citizens of this district; one is Mr. George A. Cook who was mayor of Kenora for five years and is now in real estate. The other is Mr. J. Gaymiller who has been secretary of the board of education for many years. He is also now in the real estate and insurance business.

Mr. Geo. A. Cook, Kenora Ont.

Mr. C.H. Gaymiller, Kenora Ont.

I would suggest that the property be valued without the school grounds first which is on the property and also valued with the gravel pit.

Yours sincerely,

Kenora Aug. 14th

Dr. Scott
Indian Dept.
Ottawa Ont.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I understand that you have about decided on the site for the school at Kenora. (The long site) or as it will be known here (The round lakes site) is a beautiful place and the site chosen will show up the buildings to advantage from the railroad tracks.

If you could get the contract let soon so that the building could be advanced enough to enable us to do the interior during the winter months it would help out the unoccupied situation some during the winter. If you want someone to value the land farm for purchase, I can recommend two gentlemen who will I am sure undertake
November 8th, 1920.

Dear Mr. Keenan,

I have given consideration to the accounts presented by Mr. Beagmiller and Mr. Taylor amounting to $34.50 each, making a total of $69.00, for the valuation of Mr. Dong's property.

The charge for this valuation was pointed out to me as being excessive and I took occasion to look up the fees paid in connection with other valuations made where the Department has purchased property for school purposes. Using these as a basis I consider that the most that should be allowed in the case of the Kamara property would be something like $100.00 each. Then this would be considerably higher than we have paid in the other cases above referred to.

Before tendering this payment to these gentlemen I thought it well to advise you and I shall await word from you before forwarding the cheques.

Yours faithfully,

Hon. Peter Keenan,
Minister of Labour,
Ottawa.
November 9/28

Mr. Keenan telephoned this morning that he concurred.
Ottawa, June 15, 1929.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Representations have been made to me that John Gould's farm, which is in the vicinity of the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian School at Kenora, in fact just across the track, could be purchased at a reasonable price on account of this farmer being recently burnt out.

I am writing you so as to acquaint you with this in case you desire any more land in connection with the Cecelia Jeffrey School.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Minister of Labour.

To the Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re covering Sand & Building Walks.

I wish to state that I have tried out different methods for covering the sand and I have a plan which is working out satisfactorily and the most economically.

I hauled loam from the bush near by and after levelling the sand I gave it a light coat of loam. We have had a heavy rain on it and it is holding up well. I purpose seeding this with oats and grass and clover.

I am levelling the Lawn at the front for a distance of 50 ft. from the building and am making a gravel drive around the school. At the present time cars are getting stuck almost every day.

Mr. Paget inspected the work I was doing and he was well pleased with it. He considered I was working along the best line and he said he appreciated the great necessity for the work being done right away.

Mr. Paget advised me to ask the Department for a grant of $500 towards finishing the work. I can engage teams more easily now before the haying sets in.

I would greatly appreciate this grant as I would like to complete the work as soon as possible.
Ottawa, July 29th, 1923.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 4th ultimo, I regret being compelled to again return your labour returns for the week ending August 27th, 1923. The return shows that you paid $12.60 in wages for "Grading & Material", and the receipt shows "Work on lawn". The receipt should give the number of days and the rate per day paid to Mr. Gray, as well as details of the material supplied by him.

The return shows payments to M. Lajeunesse and A. Lajeunesse of $16.00 each for hire of team, 2 days at $8.00, while the receipts read: "A days labour hauling gravel at $4.00 per day, $16.00". The wording of the return should correspond with the wording of the receipts.

BOARD OF RAILWAY COMMISSIONERS FOR CANADA.

OTTAWA, August 10, 1929.

MEMO TO THE SECRETARY.

We inspected this crossing as directed by the Assistant Chief Commissioner. The sight lines approaching from the south are fairly satisfactory. Approaching from the north the view line to the east at 150 feet from the track is obscured by small trees and brush on the top of high land. The view to the west, while not so short, is somewhat obscured by a house and some trees.

An improvement in the view can be made on both sides of the highway in these angles and advance warning signs placed on the highway 300 feet from the track in either direction would be a help and we would recommend that this be done.

The Ry. Company installed a second Whistle Post as per Order 42169 and the Whistle Sign is given a second time which is a further help.

(SGD) Geo. Spencer,
Chief Operating Officer.
Dear Sirs-

File 26727.238 - Complaint of the Kenora Board of Trade re alleged dangerous condition of the C.F.R.S. at Round Lake Road, approximately one mile east of the roundhouse, Kenora, Ont.

By direction, I enclose herewith a copy of the Board's Chief Operating Officer's memorandum of the 10th of August, 1929, in this matter, for your information.

The Clerk of the Municipality of Jeffery and Mellick has advised the Board that the land along the north side of the railway, running eastward, belongs to the Dominion Government. The Jeffery and Mellick school on which no doubt the trees and brush, and that the Chairman of the Council of the Municipality would speak to the supervisor of the school with regard to having these removed; and suggested that the Board take this phase of the matter up with you.

The Board would be pleased to have the assistance of your Department to the safety which will be rendered by the removal of the trees and brush referred to.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Assistant Secretary and Registrar

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Ottawa, September 17, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the complaint of the Kamloops Board of Trade, re alleged dangerous crossing of the C. P. R. and the removing of trees and brush on the land along the north side of the railway, running eastward, belonging to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to inform you that the Department is requesting Mr. Frank Edwards, Indian Agent, Kamloops, to take the necessary action as soon as possible in having the trees and brush obstructing the view to the approach to this crossing removed.

Board of Railway Commissioners for Canada,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, September 17, 1929.

Sir:

The Board of Railway Commissioners for Canada have reported to this Department regarding the complaint of the Kenora Board of Trade, re dangerous crossing of the C. P. R. at Round Lake Road, approximately one mile east of the roundhouse, Kenora, Ont. In this connection I enclose, for your information, copy of the report of the Chief Operating Officer, who inspected this crossing. The Board were advised that the land along the north side of the railway, running eastward, on which there are trees and brush that obstruct the view in approaching the crossing, belongs to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

The Board of Railway Commissioners have requested that this Department will assist to overcome the difficulty mentioned by removing the trees and brush. I have to request that you will arrange to have this work carried out as soon as possible. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, but you should see that the required amount of trees and brush is cut down or removed, in order that the view approaching the crossing will be as clear as possible. Please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for the purpose. This matter should receive your prompt attention.

Yours obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Ass't Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

October 11th, 1929

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey School has handed me a letter he received from Mr. W.S. Carruthers, clerk of the Municipality of Jeffrey, Ontario. In this letter it states, "Mr. Henry Weiss, Chairman of the Roads, informs me that the school are obstructing the road to the north of the school property and wishes to have the obstruction removed." He states the road was laid out by the municipality some few years ago and some $300 has been spent. The properties in the district carry a clause in the titles reserving 5% for roads, and this road was agreed on by the original owner. He would be obliged if you would not obstruct it in future.

I got in touch with Crown Attorney Cooke, who acted for us in connection with the transfer of this property and whilst I was in the office he called up the previous owner, Mr. Long, who informed us the road was built about four years ago. The Council asked permission to put the road through as far as Adam Weiss' place and Mr. Long consented but the road was only carried through part of the way to Henry Weiss' and then stopped. The agreement was not carried out. There was no agreement made in writing which the Crown Attorney informs me is absolutely necessary and apparently not even a verbal agreement was fully carried out. Already more than 5% of this property has been taken up by roads, and there is a gate on this road which is not a public thoroughfare. Crown Attorney informs me that the road could be closed by us at any time as a road could easily be made on the property adjoining. I do not think, therefore, we should do anything further in this matter, but I shall be glad to get your views. I do not think the Principal has any objection to people using the road providing they keep the gate closed but the objection seems to be that we have built a pigsty close to the road. In my opinion this does not do any harm.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 22nd October 1929

Sir,

I have your letter of the 11th instant regarding the road on the school lands at Cecilia Jeffrey School and in reply I beg to say that no mention of this road appears to have been made in the title; therefore, the Department is not aware that such a road exists, and cannot consider it to be a public road. I may state further that the Department would be forced to object to the road being placed in the location mentioned as it might become a menace to the school property.

Your obedient servant,

(J.D. McLean)
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Smith, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Form No. 101
DESCRIPTION OF PROPERTIES

"A" Land adjoining on the East, owned by Adam Wise. Containing 160 acres. 60 acres well improved. 100 acres in all can be cleared. About 1000 cords of wood. Buildings valued at $5000. Good soil. Price asked $16000.

"B" Land adjoining on the North, Owned by Henry Wise. 60 acres well improved. Approximately 300 cords of wood. 1/4 mile frontage on Rabbit Lake. Beautiful lake, clear water, sandy beach. Price asked $12000.

"C" Land adjoining on the West. Containing 48 acres. 20 acres improved. About 1000 cords of wood. Land very suitable for pasture. Never failing spring in the centre of the property. Very fertile soil. Price asked $4000 but will accept now $3000. Owner forced to sell.
2

is well cleared of both stumps and stones. There is a part of this land adjoining the school property and cut off by the road and this would make a very suitable Hog Run.

Property "C" is a cheap property and admirably adapted for pasture. Our stock can have access to it by just crossing over the road. It is very fertile soil and has approximately 1000 cords of wood. The owner asked $4000 but finally agreed to accept $3000. He is obliged to sell.

We should have all the three properties to make a complete unit. We would then have sufficient land for pastures, hay, feed and vegetables. We would also have sufficient land to make it worth while to engage a competent Farmer.

I have numbered the properties according to the desirability of owning but "C" is the cheapest.

I hope the Dept. will see its way to purchase the three as the present school property has very little value as farming land.

I am enclosing a description of the properties.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ew. [Name] Principal.
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ont., Nov. 17, 1919.

To the Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re the purchasing of more land for school purposes.

I wish to state that there are three properties available and owing to the fact that so much land in this district has ridges of rock creeping out making a lot of the land unfit for cultivation it would require the three pieces to make a farm large enough so as to make it worthwhile to engage a farmer to run it.

The three properties which I will describe later are very desirable and are very conveniently located to the school. Property No. "A" is located on the East and has on it a Pine Woods which serves as a beautiful background to our property. It would be tragic should the owner ever cut it down. Also the owner has a private road running through our farm-yard which is very objectionable. It is very desirable that the school own this property.

Property "B" is owned by a brother of A's and I believe a better price could be arranged through a joint offer for the two properties. I believe $25000 would buy the two.

This property has a lot of good land and has a very valuable lake frontage all sandy beach. This frontage will be valuable for summer cottages. There is also a good gravel pit on this property within a quarter mile from the school. The land

Sir:

I have your 108-13 of the 16th instant, with enclosure from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, relative to the advisability of securing more land. I doubt if the Department could give serious consideration next year to the acquisition of the land purchased last year which was valued at approximately $15,000 and $12,000, respectively. It may be possible, however, to include an item of $3,000 in our Estimates for parcel No. C which, I note, may be thrown on the market immediately. This is the parcel adjoining the school on the west, containing 40 acres, 20 of which are improved. The Principal reports the land is very suitable for pasture, that there is a never-failing spring on it and approximately 1000 cords of wood. Mr. Byers states the soil is very fertile.

You might discuss this with the Principal and let me have your opinion about the advisability of securing this last mentioned parcel next year.

Dear Sir,

Re the Highway between the School and the Town of Kenora.

The above is not a safe road for travel. It is very narrow, has short curves, and hugs the lake shore in a way that makes it dangerous for travel.

On Wednesday a meeting was held in the office of the Northern Development Co. to see what could be done.

The Reeve of the Municipality was present also Mr. Lyons representing the Ont. Government, Capt. Edwards and myself.

Mr. Lyons thought the Provincial Govt. would do something towards the road and he was also going to ask the Dist. Govt. to assist. It was proposed to secure the Town Compressor and put on about 15 men from the Town and carry the work on for about 6 weeks.

By way of encouragement to the interested parties it was the opinion of the meeting that if the Dept. of Indian Affairs made some contribution towards it it would strengthen their hands. It will make a much better and a much safer route to the school.

The municipality promised to surface the road and maintain

Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ont. Jan. 29th, 1929.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re three pieces of land adjoining School Site.

I wish to state that I received some inside information which if it materializes will greatly enhance the value of the property # B", the land on the north owned by Henry Wise.

The Marcus Brooks, I am informed, have secret plans to erect a factory on Rabbit Lake so as to utilize this lake for a reservoir. The farm above has a half mile frontage on this lake and should a factory be built the land around the lake will be taken up as building sites.

Mr. Wise does not know of this scheme and I approached him yesterday for his lowest price. He quoted me $1800 but I feel an offer of $1000 would buy the land. At the rate land is selling around here this is a reasonable price.

I would like to state that there is a small piece of land on the south boundary of the school property which is isolated from the rest of the farm by a very high ridge of rocks. In order to reach this piece we have to go a distance of 2 1/2 miles and it does not pay to farm it. There is only 3/4 acre clear. John Gould made an offer of $100 an acre for it and is anxious to get it. I think probably the Dept. could realize $500 for the strip beyond the ridge. If so it would be well sold.

I hope the Dept. will favorably consider the purchasing of the Wise farm. We require it for feed and vegetables and it is very favorably situated for us. Should the above plans re factory materialize the property could not be bought.

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

January 29th, 1930

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter #129-3-9 of the 22nd November last relative to the advisability of securing more land for the Cecelia Jeffrey School. The Principal of the school is particularly anxious to secure parcel B, referred to in your letter. He thinks this could now be purchased for $1000 but has heard confidentially that there is a possibility of the Backus Brooks Company building a sawmill factory at Rabbit Lake in the neighborhood of this parcel. If so the property would be worth a very great deal more than is asked and if the owner heard of this there would be no possibility of purchasing at the present time. He therefore asked me to again inquire if this parcel could not be purchased for the school. He says if this is done it might be possible to get the school authorities to purchase parcel "C" and he also might be able to sell three or four acres of the present site which is not required for the school owing to it being mostly rock, for about $500. This could be applied, of course, to the purchase of any further property the Department would purchase for him.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

I have as yet no copy of the C.J. School Report. Kindly send one for myself the Principal.

INDIAN AGENT, KENORA, DATED JANUARY
27th, 1930.

Mr. Byers has also written you in connection
with the highway between the school and the town
of Kenora. The road is in very bad shape and I
understand was originally built by the Provincial
Government as the Municipality of Jeffrey and Melick
had no funds. They are in the same state now, and
the only way to get the road done is through either
the Provincial or Dominion Government. Mr. Byers
informed me this morning that Mr. Lyons, District
Engineer for the Northern Development Company,
informed him that the Province would pay 50% of the
work if the Department or the Dominion Government
would pay the other 50%. I understand the total
cost would amount to $6,700. I do not like to
recommend this matter myself as it might look as
though I were working politics in connection with
it, but there is no question that something should
be done as to make the road better. The
Municipality promised to surface the road and
maintain it. I shall be glad to hear further from
you in this connection.

OFFICE OF

January 29th, 1930

To the Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

With further reference to my letter of yesterday's date re expenditure on the road to the Cecelia Jeffrey School, a letter has been received from the District Engineer of the Northern Development Branch advising us that the Hon. Wm. Finlayson, Minister of Lands and Forests of the Department of Northern Development is quite agreeable to go ahead with the construction of the Round Lake road if the Indian Department will undertake half the cost.

In your letter #129-3-9 of the 25th instant to the Principal of the school you say there may be a possibility of doing something on this work later on. Before wishing to know if an amount could not be put in the estimates so that something could be done in the Spring as the road is in bad shape.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 6, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letters of the 27th and 28th ultimo, with reference to the highway between the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School and Kenora. I note that it will cost approximately $1,000 to put this road in good condition and that the Provincial Government will pay one-half the cost. I regret there are no funds available for this purpose this year. Our estimates, of course, have been closed for some weeks.

I have also your letter of the 29th ultimo, with enclosure, concerning Mr. Byers' wish to secure land to the north of the school owned by Mr. H. Wise and described in earlier correspondence as Parcel B. I note that this could be purchased for approximately $10,000 and that it would be advisable to secure it at an early date. In reply I regret to state that the Department has no funds for the purpose at the present time. Parliament, at this coming session, is being requested to vote $5,000 for the purchase of Parcel C. In connection with this last named lot, it might be advisable to have Mr. Byers secure an option on it without delay. If a better price than $5,000 can be secured, he should do so.

Concerning Parcel B., valued at $10,000, I believe that the Principal should ask the church authorities if they would finance the purchase.

I note that there is 5 acres in the southern part of the present school site, which is isolated from the rest of the farm. A very good range, that could be sold for approximately $100 an acre. Unfortunately, if this were sold, unless in a trade for other land desired by the school, the purchase price would go to casual revenue and be lost to Indian Education. In other words, it could not be applied on the purchase price of another parcel.

I am enclosing, for your office and for the Principal of the School, blue prints showing the property of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, tinted in pink.

Encl.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Macdonald,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

March 31, 1930.

Memorandum:

Principal Byers and Captain Edwards have both urged the acquisition of extra land for the Cecilia Jeffreys Indian Residential School. These properties have been mentioned and provision is made in the Main Estimates for two acres of the least expensive of these parcels. I have now to recommend the purchase of Mining Location 270 L., Township of Jeffreys, District of Kenora, comprising 47 acres. This parcel adjoins the school site on the west. Twenty acres of it is improved and the whole is very suitable for pasture. There is about 1000 cords of wood on the property and a never failing spring. The soil is very fertile. The original price was $4,000; but, as it is necessary for the owners to sell, they will now accept $3,000. An option has been secured by the Principal. The property is owned by Amelia Brinkman and her son-in-law, Herbert Wolfe.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

This Department proposes to purchase, for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, a parcel of land described as Mining Location 250 P, Township of Jaffray, District of Kenora. The parcel contains 47 acres more or less, and the consideration is $8,000. The vendors are Amelia Brinneman and Herbert White. I am enclosing certificate of title.

I should be grateful if you would have the agent of the Minister of Justice search title, and, if found satisfactory, prepare a conveyance to His Majesty as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
