Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey Indian School has asked for authority to purchase 2500 cedar posts for the purpose of completing the fencing around the school property. Arrangements could be made with the Indians to take out a number of cedar posts from the Rat Portage Reserve, #6B this Spring, at a price of about 18¢ or 20¢ if the Department will give the necessary authority and pay for the posts for the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Memo. Mr. Varner:

There would be no objection to authorizing Agent Edwards to issue a band permit for 2500 posts to be cut by the Rat Portage Indians from their reserve No.36B.

As the posts are for the use of the school, the Department would waive collection of the usual dues.

Perhaps you would prefer that the agent supervise the cutting of these posts under contract and deliver them at the school—the Department bearing the expense of cutting and hauling.

This in my opinion would be a better plan than merely approving of a contract made between the school principal and the Indians.

[Signature]

Supervisor Indian Timber Lands.

It is not likely that the Indians will be inclined to get these posts out until next fall or winter.
Ottawa, April 5, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to the request of the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School to be supplied with 2,500 cedar posts to complete the fencing around the school property.

In this connection I have to say that you may issue a band permit for the cutting of the above number of cedar posts from the Red Portage Reserve No. 35B and, as the posts will be used by the school, the department would waive collection of the usual dues. You should arrange to supervise the cutting of the posts under contract, and have them delivered at the school where required. This Department will bear the expense of the cutting and hauling. The total cost of the posts, delivered, should be kept within the estimate as mentioned in your letter.

If these posts are really required to have the fencing done this Spring, you may arrange to have them cut and delivered as soon as possible.

I have to request that you will inform the Department as to the quantity of fencing that it is intended to carry out, also the type of same, and the labour that can be performed by the school management in putting up the fencing.

Your obedient servant,

A. V. Macdonald,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

I enclose herewith a letter also a plan prepared by Mr. Morgan John, Landscape gardener for Patmore Nurseries.

Our grounds here are so favorably situated for the beautifying of them that I feel an amateur should not attempt to lay them out. I have consulted Mr. Morgan John also a local man in the person of Judge Dowler who has made landscape work a hobby. The Judge concurs with Mr. John's ideas and he thinks something should be done to complete the present site.

After interviewing these gentlemen also others I have decided to request the Department to advance $500 each year for three years to be spent on the preparation and planting. The Judge thought I should ask for more than this but I think with our own help we can do the work within the suggested grant.

It will be necessary to commence right away as the season is well advanced.

The above is along the line suggested by Dr. Scott. He suggested that we decide upon a definite plan and then place our suggestions before the Department.

I hope the Department will see its way clear to carry out the above. I shall appreciate any suggestions from the Dept.

I remain,

Sir

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find letter received from Mr. E.W. Byers the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School also a sketch from the Patmore Nursery Co., re beautifying the grounds of the Cecilia Jeffrey School Kenora.

You mentioned while you were here that you would probably be able to do something in this connection as the grounds can be seen both from the Hallway and from the Roads and this Institution should be a show place worthy of our Department.

The C.F.R.Ly. and the Rotary Club have had a Horticulturist here with a view to improving the looks of the town, and we would like if possible to bring the School up in line with the other Public Buildings.

Kindly return the Letter and Sketch and if you agree to the suggestions herein, please send the Principal of the School a cheque for $500.00 as soon as possible, to enable him to get this work under way.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
May 7, 1930.

Dear Mr. Edwards:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with enclosure, with reference to beautifying the grounds at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. The general scheme is approved by the Department, and I would like you and the Principal to keep the expenditure considerably lower than the total estimate, if at all possible. Much of the labour should be done by the school staff and the older boys, without cost to the department. Further, I consider that one tennis court would be sufficient. Could not a saving be effected by using a larger number of trees and shrubs that could be secured locally, without cost?

I wish the school to be a credit to the Department and the community, and £50 will be allowed this year for this purpose. An accountable cheque, to accomplish the work and prepare the ground, will be directed to the Principal as soon as our estimates pass the House. At the present time the Interim Supply is exhausted. The enclosures are returned.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has to report that it is necessary for the Department of Indian Affairs to acquire a certain parcel of land for the purposes of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School at Kenora, in the Province of Ontario, which may be described as follows:

Mining Location 250 P, Township of Jaffray,
District of Kenora.
Containing 47 acres more or less.

The title to the above mentioned parcel of land has been investigated by an agent of the Department of Justice and has been found to be satisfactory. The price is Three Thousand Dollars which is considered fair and reasonable by an officer of the department who made a valuation thereof.

Funds for this purpose are available in the Vote for Indian Education.

The undersigned accordingly has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for an expenditure of the said sum of Three Thousand Dollars for the purchase by the Department of Indian Affairs of the said parcel of land for the purpose above mentioned.

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
In further reference to your letter of May 13th, re fencing of the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

The Indians have now cut practically all the Cedar posts and the Principal now informs us that he requires woven wire for the fencing, 1500 to 1600 feet in length, which should complete the fencing of the whole property. We may say that the adjoining owners are doing part of the work between the two properties.

The Principal wishes to now get the authority to purchase the necessary woven wire and staples to get the work underway.

The last lot of wire was purchased from the Canadian Steel Co. of Winnipeg, Manitoba.

The Principal also wishes us to mention that the School cannot do much of the fencing themselves owing to the pupils being young and not having many on the regular staff.

As we will be away on the Treaty, we would be obliged if you will kindly reply direct to Principal, sending us a copy of your letter please.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy & Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ontario.

June 24th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey residential School, complains that White Boys are going along the shores of Round Lake, under the pretence of fishing, and are causing annoyance to the pupils and Staff of the School.

We have today, seen Mr. J. Smith the Crown Timber agent, here, and he says that there is a Road allowance reserved round this lake and the only way to prevent this trespass, is for the Department to purchase this allowance from the Ontario Government, and ask them to give us the exclusive lease of occupation.

Would you therefore, kindly look up the Deed of this property, and get in touch with the Department of Lands and Forests and purchase this property, if at all possible, for the School to prevent any further annoyance to the Residents.

Mr. Smith informs us that he believes the Department will sell at a nominal figure.

Dr. Ferguson, the Health Officer, also informs us that some of the townspeople are dumping garbage on the shores of the same lake, and we would like to have your authority to get boards painted and lettered, warning against this practice.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, 3rd July 1950

Sir,

In 1928 this Department acquired for the purpose of the Cecilia Jeffrey boarding school Lot 258 P and portions of 128 P, indicated on the enclosed blueprint and for the same purpose has just secured 219 P.

The school authorities complain that white boys going along the shores of Round Lake, ostensibly for the purpose of fishing, are causing annoyance to the pupils and staff of the school and I should like to be advised if the one chain road reservation along the shores of Round Lake is at the disposal of your Department or the Municipality of Jeffrey. If this real allowance is under your jurisdiction, kindly inform me if you would consider its sale to this Department or granting the Department an exclusive license of occupation.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 24th ultimo, I have to say that the Department is taking up with the Deputy Minister of Lands, Toronto, the matter of obtaining one chain road reservation along the shores of Round Lake, in order to prevent the trespass and the dumping of garbage which has been allowed by the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. Toronto, 9th July, 1930.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of 8th inst., regarding the one (1) chain reserve along the shores of Round Lake, adjacent to the above location, I may say that at the time this location was laid out and surveyed, there was left a one (1) chain reserve along the shore for road purposes. This was a statutory condition in making surveys of mining and farm locations at that date, and the patent to the location does not include this one (1) chain strip of land, although in the description in the patent, it calls for a reservation of one (1) chain along the shore, which in my opinion, was quite unnecessary, insomuch as the location itself did not include the same.

In organized municipalities this is dedicated as a road allowance, and is dealt with by the municipality in the same manner as other roads within their limits. The Municipal Act gives the municipal authorities authority to close up and dispose of any road or road allowance, but where the same border on a lake or river, the by-law is not in force until it has received the consent of the Lieutenant

(A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.)

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School has received pressing letters asking payment for the Shrubs etc. supplied by the Pittmore Nursery for the beautifying of the grounds of the School.

We shall be glad if you will forward to this Office the accountable cheque for the amount of $500.00 as per Mr. Scott's letter 129-3-9 of May 7, 1930 so that balance of the Accounts can be paid. We are asking that the cheque be sent to this Office as we expect that the Principal, Mr. Byers will be away on his vacation by the time this reaches you.

We are inclosing a letter from the Principal re the Fire at the School for information, also letter re Asphalt surfacing.

The Principal does not seem to be pleased with the job, but in our opinion, the work is as well done as at McIntosh School, with the exception of a few minor details, which the Foreman has promised to remedy.

The only question we think comes up is as to who is responsible for the cutting of the doors, down to fit now that the floor is laid.

The Foreman says he has no instructions to do this work, so we are asking Mr. Byers to get the work done and if the Contractor is liable, this can be charged against him when settling his account.

Municipality of Infray and Melick

OFFICE OF THE CLERK AND TREASURER

Kemora, Ont., Sept 25th, 30.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kemora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Further in reply to your letter of July 2nd, in which you wished to purchase or obtain a long term Lease of the 66 ft Reservation on the shores of Round Lake now adjoining the property of Cecilia Jeffrey school.

The Council on Sept 20th passed a resolution agreeing to the granting of a long term lease subject to cancellation at any time the Council may deem it advisable to do so, for all the portion of the 66 ft reservation excepting those portions now used as a Public Highway by the Municipality.

I am not sure if this Lease should be granted by the Ontario Department of Lands or if the Municipality have the power to grant one. You will know which one should make the Lease out. If it is the Ontario Department who should execute it this will be the Municipality's approval of the same.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Clerk,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter #129-3-9 of the 14th July last, re closing road allowance on shores of Round Lake.

Enclosed please find letter received from Mr W.S. Carruthers, the Clerk of the Municipality of Jeffrey and Mellick, in which he states the council passed a resolution agreeing to a long term lease, subject to cancellation. They are not sure if the lease should be granted by the Ontario Department of Lands, or if the Municipality have power to grant one. If the Ontario Department of Lands should execute it, this letter will be the Municipality's approval.

Kindly take the matter up with the proper parties so that the allowance can be closed for the benefit of the school.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

I incl.
Ottawa, 7th October 1930

Sir,

Your ref. No. 106-18

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant enclosing notification from the Clerk of the Band, Jeffrey and Valliott that the Council have passed a resolution agreeing to the granting of a lease to the Department of the gift road reservation on the shores of Lake Erie adjoining the property of the Cecilia Jeffrey school, it would appear that a copy of the Bylaw stopping up this road, for the purpose of leasing it to this Department should be forwarded by the Municipality to the provincial authorities with the request that it be approved by the Lieutenant Governor in Council as required by Sub-Sec. 3 of Sec. 485, Chap. 253, Revised Statutes of Ontario. When this approval has been received, it would then be in order for the Municipality to issue leases. Under Section 485 1C, the Municipality has the power to make this law and Sub-Sec. 3 sets forth that this action could take effect until it has been approved by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

Your letter does not state what terms the Company proposes to insert in the lease. Kindly forward this information.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Renor., Ont.

(A.Y. Wootenzie)
Secretary
Cecilia Jeffrey School,
Kenora, Ont. Sept. 30th,

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re the purchase of additional land for the school.

In a previous letter to the Dept. I referred to two parcels of land—one adjoining the school property on the North and the other on the East.

The parcel of land on the North was referred to as "B".
The parcel of land on the East as "A".

These two were valued at $12000 and $16000 respectively. I believe at the present time these could be bought at a much lower figure particularly parcel "B" as the owner's wife will not live on the farm. I would suggest an offer of $9000 for "B" and $14000 for "A".

These two parcels are owned by two brothers and probably an offer for both pieces could be reduced.

It would be a great advantage to the school to own these pieces as owing to so much land being covered with rock we have very little for cultivation. We have been compelled to go 7 miles to rent a piece. It is also a great advantage for the run of stock. Then too the owner of parcel "A" has been crossing our land and is very sore because I put up a gate. Every time I close the gate he comes along and opens it. There is also a beautiful setting of Pines on "A" just to the rear of the school property thus forming a beautiful back-ground. It would be a great loss to the school if this should be cut down.

From present indications these lands will increase in value.

I shall greatly appreciate the purchase of these two pieces.

I remain,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School. He wishes the Department to purchase more land. This matter has been taken up before but I am forwarding the letter to you for your consideration.

I also enclose letter from the Principal re Fordson Tractor for your consideration.

Also letter asking authority to exchange the old team of horses for a new team, at a cost of about $400.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 15th, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School in which he requests that the Department obtain two additional parcels of land, one adjoining the school property on the north and the other on the east.

In this connection, I have to say that we have no funds available at the present time to expend in the purchase of this land. This requirement will be noted in our estimates for the next fiscal year.

You will be advised in a separate communication regarding the request for a Fordson tractor and the exchange of the old team of horses.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Form No. 101
Mr. Byers the Principal at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School informs us that there is a small piece of land on the South East part of the School's property, about 2½ Acres, which he says is of no use to him, owing to the difficulty of getting there, and he wishes to know if he could sell it to Mr. John Gould.

Gould will be willing to pay a reasonable price and also will pay for the survey.

If this can be arranged, an early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, December 16, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the disposal of a piece of land, about 2½ acres, on the southeast part of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School property, which the Principal states is of no use owing to the difficulty in reaching same.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is not disposed to take any action regarding the sale of this parcel of land at the present time. The question of its disposal should be investigated by a headquarters officer at the first opportunity.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. McKechnie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Tecumseh, Ont.

Ottawa, 14th April 1931

Memorandum

My dear Sir,

In July last you referred me to Agent's letter of the 26th June in connection with the desire of the school authorities to acquire the road allowance affecting the Cecilia Jeffrey school property along the shores around the lake. The last action which appears to have been taken in this matter is set forth in my letter of the 7th October last to which the Agent has apparently not replied. Possibly the school authorities have not been receiving the same allowance and have allowed the matter to drop. However, should it be deemed necessary to obtain control of this road allowance, the final procedure is outlined in my letter of the 7th October last.

October

Robertson
Chief Surveyor.
Ottawa, April 17, 1931.

Sir:

I have to refer you to official letter dated October 7th, 1930, in connection with the desire of the school authorities to acquire the road allowance affecting the Cecilia Jeffrey school property along the shores around Rainy Lake. In letter above referred to the procedure to be taken in this matter was stated, and I should be pleased if you could inform the Department at an early date as to the action taken. It may be that the school authorities have not been having the same annoyance and there is not the necessity to obtain the lease of this road allowance. Your early reply, stating how this matter stands at present, is requested.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Kenora, Ont., June 4th, 1937

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re beautifying of School Grounds

Last year a Grant of five hundred dollars $500.00 was given by the Department for the beautifying of the grounds of this school, and it was suggested that a similar amount should be spent this year to continue the work commenced last year.

In order to protect what has already been done, it will be necessary to do some surfacing this year. Owing to the financial conditions I would like to secure at least three hundred and fifty dollars $350.00 for this year which will allow us to protect the work already done to enable carry out all he had planned for this year with this amount, but we will make it go as far as possible owing to present conditions.

I shall greatly appreciate the receipt of a check for this amount in order to pay for labor and teaming in connection with the lawn.

Captain Frank Edwards is away on treaty and will be away for some considerable time, and I am taking the liberty of writing you direct in connection with the above matter. I shall forward a copy of this request to Captain Edwards, so that he will have the same on file.

Thanking you in anticipation of your attention to the above,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Ottawa, June 9, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, requesting authority to incur an expenditure of approximately $500 in carrying out improvements to the grounds surrounding the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. In reply I have to say that we will have no funds available this year to carry out these improvements. Our appropriation has been considerably reduced, and it is possible, this year, to provide only the most urgent requirements at our Indian schools.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

E. W. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

E. W. Dyre, Esq.,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School,
Kemore, O.S.T.

Ottawa, July 8, 1951.

Dear Mr. McIlwain:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, with reference to the farm purchased by the Department of Indian Affairs from Mr. William Long, of Kenora, for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. The property is comprised of three parcels, containing a total of approximately 100 acres. One small parcel of three acres, which was a gravel pit, was not included in the transfer. The price paid was $13,000 and it included the farmhouse, the barn and other outbuildings. Mr. Long agreed to give the Department, free of cost, all gravel needed for building purposes at the school.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

P. J. McIlwain, Esq.,
Box 98,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find letter we have received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, Kenora, also letter from the Northern Development District Engineer to Mr. Byers, and copy of letter from C.H. Fullerton, Deputy Minister, Department of Northern Development to Mr. Lyons re. road through the Cecilia Jeffrey School property.

This road is a farmer's road and has been there some time, but owing to difficulties the Principal of the School had gates put on it. The matter was taken up with Ottawa and the Department wrote us that they do not recognize this road as a public highway, but we notice that the Deputy Minister, Department of Northern Development, Toronto considers it a public road.

We do not consider our Department should go to the expense in constructing a new road, but if the Department of Northern Development Branch, or the Municipality of Jaffray like to construct a new road, where it would not interfere with the School, we do not consider we should object, even if it had to go through school property.

We shall be glad to receive a reply, so we can reply to the Principal's letter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ontario.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS OF CANADA

Cecilia Jeffrey School

KENORA, ONT. Nov. 14th, 1931

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re Adam Weiss Road Across School Property.

I have today received a letter from Mr. Lyons, District Engineer, which letter I am enclosing herewith.

It is not practical for us to carry on our farm operations without a gate on this road. It is also unsafe both as regards fire protection and the safety of our stock. When this road was without gates cars were frequently parked behind our farm buildings and were there until late hours of the night. We had a large number of hens stolen and had a hog killed with a car.

This road runs right through our farm-yard and we are unable to keep our stock within bounds.

Mr. Lyons went over the situation here and he agrees with me that the road is impractical so far as farming operations are concerned.

Furthermore Mr. Lyons went over the ground with me and he finds that a road could easily be built to the rear of our property with a comparatively small outlay.

I hope you will deal with this matter as early as possible as it is a very bad situation.

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Re - Machin Municipality - Jeffery Township -

This is in answer to yours of the 20th ultimo. I have looked up the matter and find that there is five per centum reserved for roads and that there is also sixty-five feet perpendicular width around Round Lake so that the Indian School has no right to put rates on this road; it is a public road; their alternative is to build a new road and you may make that clear to them.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) C.H. Fullerton,

Dear Sir,

Reply to Letter April 20th, 1932.

Re selling of 2 1/2 acres to Mr. John Gould.

When I wrote the Department re the above sale I considered this land of little value to the school owing to its being situated on the south side of a rock ridge and in order to reach it with an outfit we were obliged to go into Kenora and then take the road east. This made a distance of almost 4 miles.

After receiving the Department's reply I cleared out a road through the bush and by so doing were able to reach this piece of land from our own property. I had intended clearing more of this road this summer so we could have easy access to the land. I have this piece all cultivated and had purposed sowing it with alfalfa this spring.

In view of the above I would like to have this piece retained as part of the school property. With clearing it would give us approximately 5 acres additional tillable land and thus be an added asset.

As we now are able to reach this piece of land by going through our own property I shall appreciate it if the Dept. will retain it for the school.

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

KENORA, ONT.

COUNCIL DEALT WITH IMPORTANT BUSINESS ITEMS

Heard Two Delegations—Approved Revised Board of Education Estimates—Approved Amendments to Traffic By-Law.

The Town Council dealt with a considerable volume of business at their regular meeting last night, and heard two delegations representing various business organizations in connection with the revised estimates of the Board of Education for the coming year. A number of amendments to the traffic by-laws will go into effect immediately, approved by the Department.

A delegation of citizens assembled at the Council Chamber early Friday morning to present their views regarding the proposed changes in the traffic regulations. They stated that the proposed changes would be detrimental to the interests of the community and requested that they be reconsidered.

The Council also approved the recommendation of the Board of Education to increase the school budget by $10,000. This increase will be used to improve facilities and provide additional equipment for the schools.
May 15th 1933.

Mr. Luke Ryan,
Lenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have received orders from the Department that I must have the house you are occupying on the school property vacated at once so as to be made available for use either a married couple employed by the school or for a stopping place for Indians visiting their parents.

You are therefore notified to vacate the above property within thirty days from the date of this notice.

Yours truly

Principal.
200. We had a big house built near the river. Now it is more than double the size of about 300. We had land of 10 acres and 30 acres sold for $200 each. He told me that we should be able to sell as much as $5000 worth. He has helped me to find a new source in thirty days. Now we have made arrangements for a big piece of land and we will be able to get it started and move our things to move there soon. We will be able to pay for the summer as I have our share of 9 and on credit and we will be able to pay. Let me know what you think and if there is a place to find. 

I am sure you will be able to help us out. We would put up here for our summer wood and also use for the winter. 

I love how we are not going to be able to stay here anymore. 

Yours Truly,

M.J.
Department of Indians

Dear Sir:

Just a few lines to let you know that I have been living in the house on the Indian School property for nearly two years and when I took the place over there was cedar post stumps all over the house and about half of them had to be dug up before I could get started. I have got the house all fixed up and the land around it is in good shape. I have also planted a garden and have a lot of food stock to eat during the winter. I would like to sell all my stock in order to stay on this place so I told Mr. Smith I would sell if he would take it at $250.00 for my three cows and $300.00 going to keep. One cow is worth $150.00 and she is only 8 weeks old. I am also a partner in a trading post.
Mr. and the school plowed up the land for their own use, and I believe it is now seeded.

The cedar posts on the property were placed there by the School when they purchased them for the fence and were removed and used as required by the school, they were not moved by Ryan.

The thrashing was done at the old barn near Ryans house, and a small amount of feed and sheaves were left there, but mostly later used for feed.

Then Mr. Byers allowed Ryan to use the house, he informed him he could not use the house if he kept stock, so Ryan said he would like to sell what he had. Byers did not wish to purchase, but as Ryan was up against it and also needed the money to defend himself in the hay case Byers paid him $200 for the stock, which Ryan first asked $500 for. The stock was in very poor shape, as they had run outside all winter and had practically no care, also Byers did not wish Ryans stock to run with the school stock as our herd was registered tested stock, and Ryans had not been tested for T.B.

Mr. Byers later told Ryans boy that if his father wanted to get the stock back, he could have it for what was paid.

Mr. Byers also informed me that he allowed Ryan to keep hogs as he said he wanted them for killing, but he still has them, and it was Ryans pigs that destroyed the sheaves in the barn and spoiled the feed and bedding.

Ryan has a small amount of wood about 10 cords piled near the house, but this could easily be moved if Ryan is removed.

There is no building in which ice could be stored unless he has put it in the barn or outside under some old sawdust, and in any case it could only be a small amount.

Ryan and his boy got permission to cut wood on a farm last winter and have been hauling this to town and selling it during the winter, this has been done in the boys name, as Ryan has been receiving relief and fuel during the winter.

Most of the above information has been got from Mr. Byers but I believe it to be correct, and I would suggest you write Ryan confirming Mr. Byers lettering and asking him to vacate, if you think another letter is necessary, and if he does not remove from the premises by the date mentioned, I should be glad to receive definite instructions to take what action may be necessary to get possession.

Mr. Byers informs me he is afraid of what Ryan may do if he is forcibly removed, and we would have to give the police instructions to see he did not set fire to the buildings or do other damage, and if we do not remove him now, it will perhaps be more difficult later on.

I will be away on treaty payments until the 16th June, but mail will be kept here for my return.

Awaiting your instructions.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

P.S. Provincial Constable Wright informs me Ryan is an old C.P. Railway man, but that he owes so many people round Kenora, if he went back to work he would be garnished, so finds it better to stay on relief.

Ryan is chairman of the Kenora unemployed association.
Assistant Deputy and Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter 129-3-9 of 20th inst., I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter received from Mr. W. J. Ryan of Kenora, which is returned herewith.

Provincial Police T. Wright of Kenora, informs me it is well known that Ryan is a Communist, but they wish to keep this information confidential for their own purposes, although everyone knows it.

Mr. Dan McLeod Manager of the Essentia Lumber Company informed me a short time ago that his Company had great difficulty in removing this man from their premises at Herman, a Village near Kenora.

Some time ago Ryan asked Mr. Byers the Principal of the School to purchase three cars of hay, he had shipped down. Mr. Byers did not want it and refused, however later, out of sympathy after a hard luck story, Mr. Byers bought the hay and paid for same by cheque, later he received a sharp letter from people who claimed they owned the hay, that the hay was not paid for. Mr. Byers refused to pay again and does not know how the matter was settled, but does not believe Ryan paid anything.

Last fall Ryan borrowed Mr. Byers hay bailer took it out to another person's property, bailed the hay, took it to town and sold the hay, he was eventually brought up, and tried by Judge Dowler and given two years but the sentence was suspended, owing to his large family and hard luck story. Mr. Byers had a great deal of trouble in getting his bailer back.

Mr. Byers has been using the old house on the school property for Indians when visiting the school, and also for some workmen on the farm, but a year ago last fall allowed Ryan to use the house for the winter, and did not turn him out in the spring, and also allowed him to use a small plot of ground under a tree adjoining the house to plant vegetables, and also allowed him to use the house last winter.

During the winter Mr. Byers complained to me that Ryan was taking wood from the property, and that he was afraid to say anything to him, and asked me to see Ryan, he said he had no wish to remove him in the winter. I went and saw Ryan, he said he had only picked up a few fallen timbers and promised not to repeat the offence so at Mr. Byers request nothing further was done.

A short time ago at a meeting of the Board of Trade Ryan came up with a delegation of unemployed men and informed us they had just come from a Council meeting of the Town Council where they had requested land and land for the unemployed to plant gardens, and Board of Trade appointed a man to look into the matter make collections and see what could be done, and a number of the unemployed were helped in this way. Mr. Byers informed me at this meeting he had about four acres of land he could plant. The next day I saw Mr. Byers and informed him of this and he said Ryan had no land unless he figured on the school property, which the school needed for themselves, I advised him to give him a month's notice and tell Ryan he could not use the school land, Mr. Byers informed me he did
Ottawa, May 30th, 1933.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. MacMillan,

The attention of the Minister has been called to the case of Mike Ryan, who, with his wife and seven children, has been occupying, without permission from the Department or from any other source, a farm house on Indian property near the Presbyterian Indian Residential School, just east of Kenora.

The house is reported to be in a somewhat dilapidated condition, and has been occupied for at least two years by the Ryan family. Ryan does not have a very good reputation, and while the Principal of the Indian School is understood to be adverse to him continuing in the house, he is somewhat indifferent in the matter of moving to secure Ryan's eviction. The house is understood to be wanted for the use of an Indian couple.

The matter, it appears, was taken before Judge Dowler, and September 16th was set as the time limit for Ryan's removal. The Crown Attorney submitted an account for $25.00, which, according to the Minister's informant, the Department is not disposed to pay.

The Minister would appreciate a report from you, and any recommendation you may see fit to make as to the removal from the house of Ryan and his dependents.

Private Secretary.
October 5, 1933.

Mr. DICKARD,

I have your memorandum of the 2nd instant, with reference to Mike Ryan and family, who have been occupying a house on property belonging to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

This matter was first brought to the attention of the Department in May last, by Mr. J. Ryan, who wrote stating that he had been requested to vacate the house on the school property. The Indian Agent, Mr. Frank Edwards, Kenora, Ont., was requested to report. His reply showed that permission to live in the house had been granted to Ryan by Mr. Myers, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. Mr. Edwards further stated that Mr. Myers had notified Ryan to vacate the house on June 15th.

The Department then advised Mr. Agent Edwards that Mr. Myers had exceeded his authority in granting permission to Ryan to use the house on the school property and he was further informed that it was expected no such permission would be granted in future.

Later, Mr. Edwards again wrote the Department, stating that Ryan had not yet vacated the house, and Mr. Edwards was instructed to apply to a Judge for a writ of ejectment and have him removed from the school premises by process of law. A final report had been sent to the Deputy Superintendent regarding the matter, but, early in August, Mr. H. P. Cook, K.C., forwarded an account for legal services. This account was returned to Mr. Agent Edwards and he was informed that, as Mr. Myers exceeded his authority in the first place, in allowing Ryan to use the house, it was considered that Mr. Myers should settle Mr. Cook's account.

The information received by the Department from Mr. Edwards indicates that Ryan is a troublesome character and he should be removed from the property as soon as possible.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, October 7, 1933.

Dear Capt. Edwards:

Re Col. Cooke's Account.

I wish to state that I all along moved into the vacant house on the farm at the time was without a family of small children, and at that time was a respectable citizen. I also assumed that it would be possible to have someone occupying this house, as both the house and barn were situated very close to the railway and had been frequently used at night by transients, and I feared that this might result eventually in a fire.

Some time after Ryan had been in possession of the house, the Mayor of Kenora, Mr. Carruthers, learned that I was going to have Ryan removed from the property and he prevailed upon me to leave him in peaceful possession. Subsequent to this I thought that I could be doing an act of kindness to permit Ryan to remain, and while there was difficulty in removing him I feel that he has rendered some service in keeping transients away from the place. Furthermore, Ryan has left sufficient windows in the house to almost cover the amount of the bill for eviction.

As it was merely an attempt to keep the buildings of the Department from being used as property, I feel that I should not be held responsible for payment of the above account, and I shall appreciate it if the Department will settle the claim, as all court transactions were instituted and carried out by the Department.

Awaiting the decision of the Department,

I remain,

[Signature]

Yours sincerely,

October 28th, 1933.

Mr. W. Byers, Esq.,
Principal Cecilia & Jeffrey Indian School,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Mr. Byers,

Re: School Property

I understand from information reaching me that in carrying on your school in an efficient manner you have found it necessary from time to time to rent additional property largely for the purpose of providing forage crops for the livestock used at the school. As you are aware John George who owns that part of Location 256 P lying to the south of the road through the location and has been carrying on there what is probably the most efficiently operated dairy business around Kenora. For personal reasons, however, he finds that he will have to give up his business and has instructed me to place his property and herd on the market. As you are aware George has bought this land to a very high set of fertility and I feel sure the land would probably be of more value to you than to any one else. I say this particularly in view of his exceptionally favourable results with alfalfa which should provide you with your necessary forage crops. This property also has the additional advantage of lying between the Town of Kenora and the new airport and the highway to be constructed to the airport together with the power lines etc., will pass the door. As to the property itself Mr. George made an application to the Agricultural Development Board of Ontario and was granted a loan of $4500.00 on the security of this property. As to the herd itself it is an exceptionally high grade herd for this District and if you have any contemplation of adding to your live stock might I suggest your consideration of these animals.

Mr. George has placed a price of $9000.00 on the property itself and a price of $10,000 for the whole plant including the herd as a going concern. This however, would appear to be more than justified by the valuation apparently placed on the property by the Agr. Development Board for loan purposes. Looking at the matter from your point of view this amount would appear justified as I am given to understand you are at the present time paying approximately $120.00 in cash rental of properties and a further property rented on shares which would
EARLE C. POPHAM
BARRISTER & SOLICITOR
KENORA, ONTARIO

Represent about another $100.00. This expenditure capitalized at 5% would mean $13000.00 and as I feel satisfied that the George farm with its greater fertility would probably provide you with more forage than you are obtaining from all these other properties, the purchase of the property should I believe effect a direct saving. As Mr. George must know very quickly as to the prospects of sale of his property in order to make his arrangements for the winter months I would appreciate it if you would advise me as soon as possible whether you would be interested in acquiring the place.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

[Signature]

February 9, 1924.

Mr. BICKARD,

Referring to your memorandum of the 6th instant, with reference to acquiring a farm of 130 acres owned by Mr. John George, for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, I have to say that the Department received a previous request for the purchase of this property.

When the school was erected, in 1922, the Department purchased 176 acres, at a price of $15,000. Subsequently, in May, 1930, a further area of 47 acres was purchased for the sum of $2,000. Besides this, the school authorities rent other land for which, it is understood, they pay an annual rental of $500.

The farm which Mr. John George wishes to sell is composed of part of Location 286 P., lying north of the Canadian Pacific railway. Mr. George has placed a price of $9,000 on the land and an additional $1,000 for the plant and herd. He has been engaged in a dairy business. He obtained a loan of $1,000 on this property from the Agricultural Development Board of Ontario.

No funds to purchase this land are available in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year and no provision has been made in the Estimates for the ensuing fiscal year. The school has now a fairly large acreage, purchased by the Department, besides the rented land, and there should be a sufficient area for the use of the institution, until such time, at least, as it is possible to provide funds for the purchase of an additional amount.

Deputy Superintendent General.
MEMORANDUM

September 26, 1954.

The Minister has received additional correspondence urging the purchase of what is known as the George farm, for the use of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

You will find the previous correspondence and also your memorandum of February 9th last, on your File No. 129-54. According to the latest information obtained by the Minister, only 80 acres of the property owned at present, is tillable, and this is said to be insufficient to provide the milk required for 150 children. It is also stated that the Department has been obliged to rent each year, three different farms with scattered areas of tillable land; that the rental amounts to $750., which sum if placed towards purchasing the George farm would nearly pay for the same in ten years.

The George farm is said to comprise over one hundred acres which can be cultivated, and that owing to its close proximity to the school, it would be a valuable asset.

The Minister asks that you furnish him with a further report on this matter.

Private Secretary.

KENORA, ONT. March 25th, 1935.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re Sale of Strip of Land To Dept. Northern Development.

I wish to state for your information that the piece of land asked for is the best piece of arable land that the School owns. It is very fine, level and fertile. Further the field from which it is taken is small - approximately 5 acres, and a strip of this size is very important.

I do not wish to put any difficulty in the way of this purchase but I do feel that it should command a pretty good price.

If the proceeds of this sale could be used to acquire another piece of arable land we would not feel the loss so much but we have such a small amount of tillable land that an acre and 1/4 acre quite different.

I seek your assistance in his opinion of the valuation and he stated that in view of the location of this particular piece and the loss it meant to the field that it should be worth $800 per acre. You will probably recall that about a year ago Mr. Gould offered $500 for an acre situated over 1 mile farther out.

If this price could be realized and the proceeds used to purchase some land adjoining us on the east boundary which I am informed can be purchased I would from our interest in the transaction be in favor of this sale.

Providing a sale is effected I am anxious to secure from the Northern Development an undertaking to give us free use of the siding for loading purposes and also provision for an entrance of at least 25 ft. in width on the North side of the strip, this entrance being to the part of the field left after the strip has been taken off.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, January 28, 1937.

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

I am enclosing, for your information, copy of a letter addressed to Mr. R. W. Byers, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. This letter, I may state, was sent forward to me by Mr. Hugh McKinnon, M.P., Federal member for the district.

In view of the prevailing economic conditions, I am not at all sure that the Government will be prepared to seriously consider the purchase of these additional holdings at the moment, nor am I convinced that this additional acreage is necessary. I am anxious, however, to secure all the information I possibly can, in respect to the matter. I do not know that it will be necessary for you to make an inspection of the property, but I do want you to feel free to comment upon the subject matter of this communication very frankly. You might state definitely what your opinions are in respect to the need for this land; the price suggested and any other information you may consider helpful. You will note that Mr. George is anxious to obtain a decision from the Department at the earliest possible date.

Yours very sincerely,

Enc.

R. A. Hoey,
Dept. of Welfare & Training.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Winnipeg, Man.
though additional land were secured.

"The children attending the school are mostly from the bush country where farming, as we know it, is impossible. If these children can be taught to grow good gardens they will be a big step towards supplying their daily food. Some will learn to care for poultry and cattle, but I doubt if a home represented by the children have stock of any kind. The Indians are trappers and hunters. I am doubtful if a further investment of $10,000 can be justified and I am more and more convinced that the Department should not only limit the size of the farm, but also the number of stock. The interest of the pupils is often lost sight of by the desire of the Principal to operate a large farm with show stock. He aims to show a revenue, but unfortunately it is often on the wrong side of the ledger.

I have already discussed this proposal with the Deputy Minister, but, in view of the limited funds at our disposal this year and in view of what Inspector Hamilton states in his report, it is not at all likely that the Government will consider the purchase of this land. If, however, you require additional information, I shall be glad to discuss the matter with you more fully any time at your convenience.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Reay,
Supt. of Welfare & Training."
Ottawa, February 1, 1937.

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

I have before me, for consideration, a report submitted to the Department by Inspector Hamilton, in respect to the purchase of property adjoining the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School at Kenora. Mr. Hamilton's report reads in part as follows:

"I note the price is $2,000, and that Mr. George has obtained a loan of $4500. If this loan was taken some years ago during the high prices, it is perhaps now nearer the value of the land than the sum asked. The number of acres is not given, but personally I did not see a quarter or half section of land in the vicinity of Kenora I would consider purchasing for farming at such a price.

"I do not know what has been done in connection with the dairy herd at the school, the condition of which I reported on this past fall. However, I am of the opinion a small herd of from 10 to 15 good cows would supply sufficient milk for the school. I would suggest, rather than to increase the school's operation, there might be better to raise only the whole beef herd in this way keep the herd reduced to a minimum. If this is done, the land now belonging to the school could perhaps produce most of the rough feed required. The beef necessary can, I am sure, be purchased for less than it could produced, even

WINNIPEG, MAN. January 27th, 1937.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I wish to refer to your letter dated January 22nd, and to state that without inspecting the land and stock in question, it is difficult to decide what action should be taken.

I note the price is $9,000, and that Mr. George has obtained a loan of $450. If this loan was taken some years ago during the high prices, it is perhaps now nearer the value of the land than the sum asked. The number of acres is not given, but personally I did not see a quarter or half section of land in the vicinity of Kenora; I would consider purchasing for farming at such a price.

I do not know what has been done in connection with the dairy herd at the school; the condition of which I reported last fall. However, I am of the opinion a small herd of from 10 to 12 good cows would supply sufficient milk for the school. I would suggest, rather than to increase the school property, that it might be better to raise only the choice heifers and in this way keep the herd reduced to a minimum. If this is done, the land now belonging to the school could perhaps produce most of the rough feed required. The beef necessary can, I am sure, be purchased for less than it could be produced, even though additional land were secured.

The children attending the school are mostly from the bush country where farming, as we know it, is impossible. If these children can be taught to grow good gardens

OTTAWA.
Dear Sir,

A short time ago Councillor Albert Kent of the Irlington Band informed me that he was going to start and build a house on the property of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School; I asked him if he had seen the Principal, and he said the Principal had given him permission.

I interposed the Principal and informed him it was not advisable to allow any buildings to be erected on the school property without permission from the Department, and called to his attention the trouble we had before in evicting a man he had allowed to live in one of their houses.

I have now received a letter from the Principal in which he states: "Number of Indians have approached me with a view of obtaining permission to erect a log house on the school property in which they might stay when they visit their children. There is a location well removed from the school, and not in view from the building, which would be very suitable for their building. It is a level slope and cannot be used for farming purposes. A building would be a great convenience to the Indians and is needed to prevent the nuisance of being compelled at night to send them to the school overnight, which is not advisable from a sanitary standpoint. There is an Indian house situated near the Catholic school but it is four miles from here and is often filled when the Indians reach it. It also means the expense of a taxi to go back and forth. They are willing to do the labour among themselves and are anxious to commence work on it. I hope you will succeed in obtaining authority from your Department for the erection of the aforesaid buildings."

I discussed the matter with Inspector Hamilton today, and he agrees with me it would not be advisable to erect an Indian house on the school property. I may state we have not allowed one to be erected at McIntosh or Sioux Lookout. Most Principals do not wish the Indians to stay so close to the school, it would probably be hard to keep them away.

The R.C.S. School at Kenora has permitted some Indians to erect houses on their property (school) but I think they should be instructed to gradually get them away. Dr. McMillan saw these houses when he was at Kenora adjoining the property leased to the Town of Kenora.

I shall be glad to receive your instructions.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 17, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 13th instant with reference to the suggested erection of a house on the property of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, in order to enable Indian parents to have some place to stay when they come to visit their children. Experience of Principals of Indian Residential Schools all over Canada show that erection of such houses encourages the Indians to come to the schools more frequently and stay for longer periods when they do make a visit. Such procedure, of course, is nearly always a considerable trouble to the school staff.

Please inform Mr. Byers that the Department does not approve the erection of the house mentioned in your letter.

You should also inform the Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School that the houses now being used near that school should be gradually torn down.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 14 together with plan, both having reference to the proposed relocation of the road through the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School property.

In view of the fact that it is the view of the principal of the school that no compensation is required from the Department of Highways, we do not propose making any demand in that regard. However, it should be definitely understood that following the relocation of this road, the lands comprising the old roads will become a part of the school property.

Further, in due course, it would be advisable for the Department of Highways to supply this Department with a proper plan of the relocated road.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
T. R. MacInnes
Acting Director

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Memorandum.

This will acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of January 5th, your file 129-3-9, concerning the matter of a highway through the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School Property at Kenora, Ont., and directing attention to certain letters dealing with the question.

The copy of plan bearing Ontario Department of Highways No. P.2317-1 which accompanied Indian Agent Edwards' letter of December 30th, has been detached from the file and has been placed in your file number No. 2777 pending receipt of the usual plan on tracing linen. When the latter has been received, blue prints will be prepared for your file and for the records of the Indian Agent.

It is noted that in departmental letter of July 21st addressed to Agent Edwards no compensation will be required from the Province for the roadway and that it should be definitely understood that following the relocation of this road, the lands comprising the old roads will become a part of the school property.

It is considered that in due course the Province will submit a plan on tracing linen and that it will make application for transfer of the right of way. It is also considered that no further action will be necessary at this time.

Your file 1F9-3-9 is returned herewith.

[Signature]

Surveyor General, and
Chief, Hydrographic Service.

October, August 22nd, 1899.

Dear Sirs -

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 4th ultimo with reference to the Great Lakes Reserve. You state that it is essential that some form of relief be provided for Indians of this band. It is regretted that you did not submit with your letter a requisition indicating what supplies would be needed, so that they might have been bought and shipped in and so avoided the necessity of local purchases.

If there will be time for you to submit a requisition so that shipment can be made before the last boat leaves for Toronto, these plans forward and immediately, but if not you may make local purchases from time to time as required but these should be kept to a minimum and only actual necessities should be bought.

Yours truly,

P. A. Reid,
Supt. Welfare and Training.

P.O. Longley, Jr.,
Indian Agent,
Huron River, Ont.
TO HIS RIGHTENESS

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Province of Ontario has made application to the Department of Mines and Resources, for certain parcels of land in the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school property, in the Township of Jaffray, Ontario, which are required for road purposes.

THAT an officer of this Department has reported that the proposed new roads will not detrimentally affect the school property, and has recommended that the lands applied for be granted to the Province without compensation.

The undersigned therefore recommends that the lands as hereinafter described be transferred to His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Highways for the Province of Ontario, under the provisions of Section 48 of the Indian Act.

Description

All those portions of Mining Locations 2597 and 2592, Township of Jaffray, District of Kenora, Province of Ontario, Dominion of Canada, containing together 3,765 acres more or less, shown coloured red on a plan of survey by W.J. Laird, Ontario Land Surveyor, dated November, 1938, of record No. M-2777, in the Indian Affairs survey records, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, and bearing Ontario Department of Highways No. P.2217-1.

THE HONOURABLE

HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

WHEREAS the Province of Ontario has made application to the Department of Mines and Resources, for certain parcels of land in the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school property, in the Township of Jeffrey, Ontario, which are required for road purposes;

AND WHEREAS an officer of the Department of Mines and Resources has reported that the proposed new roads will not detrimentally affect the school property, and has recommended that the lands applied for be granted to the Province without compensation;

NOW THEREFORE His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, is pleased to order that the lands as hereinafter described be and they are hereby transferred to His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Highways for the Province of Ontario, under the provisions of Section 46 of the Indian Act.

Description

All those portions of Mining Locations 258P and 259P, Township of Jeffrey, District of Kenora, Province of Ontario, Dominion of Canada, containing together 3,755 acres, more or less, shown coloured red.

Dear Sir:

Re: Mining Locations 256P and 259P,
Parcels 10001 and 10290, Township
of Jeffrey, Ontario.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 16th, 1940, addressed to the Chief Hydrographic Service of this Department, with which was enclosed a print from your plan P.2317-7, showing a parcel of land required for highway purposes in the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School property in the above Mining Locations.

The parcel in question forms a portion of the area of 5.755 acres which was transferred to the Province by Order-in-Council P.C.2796, dated 21st September, 1938. A certified copy of this Order-in-Council was forwarded to you with my letter of May 14, 1940.

A comparison of the portion of the roadway shown on the print from your plan P.2317-7 with the same portion shown on your plan P.2317-1 discloses appreciable differences. Since your plan P.2317-7 represents a survey of later date it would appear that a new Order-in-Council will be necessary to correct the matter; please advise me with regard to this.

It will be noted that it was considered that the new roads would not detrimentally affect the school property and that the lands were granted without compensation.

It is understood that the lands in the abandoned portions of the roads will now become part of the school property.

Yours very truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch.

Dear Sir:

No Mining Locations 289P and 309P,
Parcels 1000A and 1030A,
Township of Jeffery,
Your File 129-58.

Thank you for your letter of June 17th, in connection with the above property.

The original plans, namely P.2317-1 were forwarded last year to your agent at Kenora in error, and it appears your Order in Council was not passed before we had an opportunity to advise you of the change, as per Plan P. 17-7.

The latter plan was drafted in order to correct an error in the original survey, and it appears necessary that a new Order in Council be passed to correct the error and keep the records in order.

I note our remarks regarding the compensation and also your reference to the abandoned portions concerning school property. I shall be glad to give your assurance that it will not be necessary for this Department to take any action with regard to the abandoned portions, because it appears the old road was never transferred to the Province, therefore, the province did not have title, in other words, I believe the old road was Dominion Crown Lands and they never actually transferred to the Province.

We shall be glad to receive a new Order in Council covering our Plan P.2317-7.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

For Chief Property Valuator

H. H. Macdonald.

Dear Sir:

Re: Mining Locations 258P
and 259P, Parcels 10001
C.R.I. 10220, Township of Jeffray.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 24th, concerning the plans of survey of roads through the above property.

The portion of the road in question having been transferred to the Province, in accordance with your plan P.2317-1, it will be necessary for the Province to revest it in this Department before it can be re-transferred in accordance with your plan P.2317-7. I would ask you therefore to be kind enough to take the necessary action on the part of the Province, and to forward to this office a certified copy of your Order-in-Council. This Department will thereupon prepare a memorandum to Council recommending transfer to the Province of this portion of the road as shown on your plan P.2317-7.

We do not appear to have a copy of your plan P.2317-7 on tracing linen for our permanent records. This should be forwarded in order that it may receive our record number, and in order that it may be referred to in our description.

With regard to the abandoned portions of the old road, I concur in your opinion that since the old road was not transferred to the Province, no action affecting them will be necessary.

Yours very truly,

T.R.J. MacInnes,
Secretary,
(Indian Affairs Branch.)

TO HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT by Order-in-Council P.C.2796, dated 21st September, 1939, certain parcels of land in the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school property, in the Township of Jeffrey, Ontario, containing together 3.765 acres, more or less, were transferred to the Government of the Province of Ontario, for road purposes.

THAT in consequence of an error which was subsequently found in the survey of the said parcels, the said parcels are incorrectly described in the said Order-in-Council.

THAT in order to effect the necessary correction, the province has, by Order-in-Council, approved by His Honour the Lieutenant-Governor, dated the 1st day of January, A.D. 1941, reconveyed the said parcels to this Department, and has requested that the lands as shown on provincial road plan P.2317-7 be transferred to the Province for the said road.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that the parcels of land hereinafter described and are hereby transferred to His Majesty in the Right of Ontario, as represented by the Minister of Highways, for the purpose of a road, under the provisions of Section 48 of the Indian Act, Chapter 96, R.S. 1937.

Dear Sir:

This Branch has received representations on behalf of Mr. Ernest L. MacGowan, who desires to lease or purchase a small parcel of land, indicated on plan appended hereto as P.1866, for the purpose of establishing a mink farm. It is stated that the land in question is of little value and is not used or likely to be used for school purposes. It appears that Mr. MacGowan is a young man of good education, a University graduate, who had intended following a professional career, but has been prevented from doing so by health conditions.

I should be obliged if you would be good enough to let me have your views on the subject at your early convenience. Kindly return the enclosed plans.

Yours very truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Douglas S. Pitts, Esq.,
Principal,
Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ontario.
Dear Mr. McKinnon,

I am writing you concerning a piece of land which lies alongside our property and which is a part of the property belonging to the Cecelia Jaffray Indian School. As you know, our property lies in a narrow strip between a large mass of rock on the north and the old C.P.R. right-of-way on the south. Most of this is stony and does not even make good pasture land.

The piece of land which I would like to procure lies in a strip between our property and the mass of rock and varies in depth from about 20 ft. to about 300 ft. It is mostly bush but there is one field of approximately 5/4 acre. This land is not being used, and has not been used, by the Indian School as it is so far from the Residence. As I mentioned above, most of the land is in bush and it is really in this portion that I am most interested.

As you may know Mr. McKinnon, I had to drop my plans to go through Manitoba Medical College, due to a permanent though somewhat erratic illness. My physician advised me to take up mink raising or some such occupation for a livelihood. I have chosen the mink ranching, but there is no suitable place on my father's land to raise them, due to complete lack of the shelter which they require. The bush west of the Indian School property would form an ideal location for the mink enclosure. If I do not obtain this property, I shall have to move further out beyond the reach of electricity, thus preventing me from enjoying the convenience of electricity in my future home, or on the ranch.

I understand our neighbour, Mr. John Gould, is negotiating with Mr. Pitts, the Principal of the Indian School, for the purchase or lease of this land. As investigation will show, Mr. Gould already owns over 200 acres of the finest farm land in this district. We have less than 3 acres of arable land.

I spoke to Mr. Edwards, the Indian Agent about this property. He stated that he was perfectly familiar with the piece in question, and realized how little value it was to the School, but that it was entirely up to Ottawa.

I trust, Mr. McKinnon that you will find time to attend to this matter in the near future as I should like to get settled somewhere before fall.

Very truly yours,
signed - Ernest L. McCammon, B.Sc.
August 19, 1941.

This particular piece of land is at a distance from the School and so is awkward to get at. It would be of considerable more value to either Mr. Johnson or Mr. Smith.

But we are in great need of farming land. Of our 250 acres, only 150 acres can be used to rent land every year. At present of a farm of 150 acres which we rent, only 45 acres are arable. (About 30 acres are used for crops.)

This past week I have approached neighbors to see if they have any small pieces of land to sell. Unless we can get extra land elsewhere and nearer to the School we will not be able to use our 150 acres (pasture, woods, etc.) in selling this land.

One neighbor who is willing to sell, has a parcel of 60 acres including pasture. He is prepared to sell part of south part of property but does not know what price he wants, because it is the balance of an estate with several heirs.

You see my views, Sir. We need land. Therefore if we sell any (even if awkward to get at,) we should purchase more nearer to the School.

An alternative suggestion would be that we rent a small piece of land to Mr. Johnson keeping the school and part of the pasture. As basis for this suggestion may I submit the following information:

The Municipal Assessor thinks that the land would be assessed by him for $250 and $350 depending on what it is to be used for. It might be worth about $500. Therefore if rented should bring us the rent of $250 (or $350) and the land would be worth $500. This would somewhat offset our present rental of $125. (One hundred and twenty-five dollars) for the above mentioned 45 acres which we rent.

Hoping that this information may be of some assistance to you in reaching your decision,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal
Dear Sir:

I regret that my delay in answering your letter of Aug. 25th necessitated your letter of Aug. 30th. The latter was received by me while I was away on a visit to the Reserve but mainly on my desire to investigate carefully every angle of this request.

Here follows my report and views:

First of all, I should like to clear up some mistakes which were too flagrant to overlook, in the representations to your office.

1. The part he seems to put in question (in the section upon which the School and all our buildings are built), but the South part of S.pt. 12PP consists of 46 acres.

2. The small field shown in his diagram (hand-drawn) is not the same as the field I have more than 15 acres of good soil (comparatively).

3. We have used it every year since I have been here and find that it was used every year before. Any cleared land is used for firewood here.

4. No-called land in diagram is fertile soil (not cleared and not used). It is a good pasture line and will be used which may be cut in future years. At present it serves as pasture. It is also productive.

5. North Base. Useless for farming but does grow some pine and no far for fire wood.

6. South Base. Useless for farming but does grow some pine and no far for fire wood.

7. Small field adjoining our S.pt. 12PP with S. pt. 12PP.

I also think that you would be interested in his opinion. This opinion is: Should we have just acres from the small field tried and planted this place for pasture or for farm and for garden. I enquired and found that your department had already decided that this place was useless and of the same mind. (Department letter 129-3-3 of March 27th.)

McKennon is a brother-in-law of J. Boyd and knew his strong desire for a school and was willing to give anything toward it. (McKennon did attend University but was not a graduate.)

Supt'd Pg. 8.
Mr. Pitts mentioned that Mr. MacCannan is a brother-in-law of Mr. J. Gould, the other applicant for the same property. It is noted that Mr. Gould applied in 1905, but the application was refused as the school management was unwilling to part with any land.

Mr. Pitts advises an alternative suggestion that a parcel of land might be purchased by the school and that the revenue might go to the benefit of the school. This, however, would not be feasible as under Government Finance regulations the school cannot purchase land and the school would not benefit by it. The same rule, of course, would apply to the proceeds of any sale.

In the circumstances I fear that any action on our part to assist Mr. MacCannan would give rise to strong suspicions from the Presbyterian Church authorities who oppose the sale of land to non-Church members. Therefore, perhaps you will agree that it would hardly be opportune to pursue the matter further at the present time.

Yours very truly,

T. H. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Hugh D. MacKinnon, Esq., M.P.,
Toronto, Ontario.
September 5, 1941.

Dear Mr. MacKinnon:

I am in receipt of a reply from Mr. Pitts, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, regarding land he agreed to sell to the school board to purchase a parcel of land mentioned in his letter to you of July 31, which is returned herewith.

His report covers the various points involved by numerous paragraphs which I quote for your information as follows:

1. The part he seeks is not acreage. This is the section upon which the school and all our buildings are built, but the south part of LTP.

2. Site of LTP consists of 68 acres.

3. The small field shown in his diagram (hard-drawn) is not cleared, but is slightly more than 3½ acres of good soil (comparatively).

4. His statement that we never use this field is wrong. We have used it every year since we have been here. It has always been very good before. Any cleared land is scarce and therefore valuable here.

5. So-called buck in diagram is fertile soil (not cleared and not yet building). But it contains good crops and will be used in future years. At present it serves as pasture. It may be improved.

6. Pine Mass. Useless for farming but does grow some pine and poplar for firewood.

7. Road, 8 miles. There is a seldom-used but passable buck road joining our S. plot with S. plot LTP.

[Signature]

[Stamp]
I am very much obliged to you for your kindness in writing me such a long letter. I have been very busy since my last letter, and have not had much time to write. I hope you are well and happy.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

October 1, 1941.

Dear Sir:

The Department has received an application of Mr. E.H. Macomber to purchase or appropriate sufficient acres of land now held by the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

The Department is not prepared to sell any land but we are willing to consider allowing Mr. Macomber to rent some of the acres mentioned above at a reasonable yearly rental.

While we have communicated with the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, Mr. Pyle, and Mr. Macomber, we have not yet been able to reach a satisfactory conclusion of the transaction. We therefore urge Mr. Macomber to proceed to London at the earliest possible date and, in company with Mr. E.H. Macomber and Mr. Pyle, visit the Cecilia Jeffrey School land which the former wishes to obtain. I feel certain that he will be able to reach an agreement with Mr. Macomber and Mr. Pyle. When reporting your visit to London, please inform me regarding the extent of the land which Mr. Macomber will use and the terms upon which he proposes to pay. You consider would be a reasonable yearly rental.

Please advise me by wire when you will be here.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Mr. A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Stanley, B.C.

[Signature]

Y.M. Macomber,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

As it is somewhat difficult for the department to take cognizance of the various points involved in the matter, it has been decided to have the Inspector of Indian Agencies, Mr. J. Hamilton, meet with representatives of all parties concerned in order to reach a satisfactory settlement.

Mr. Hamilton will be at Toronto for the purpose Monday June 10th, 1941, and you may see him then.

Yours very truly,

T.H.L. Macdonald,
Secretary.

to be satisfied, and for a few feet of rock together with the small corner of bush land, one could hardly set a higher price.

Mr. Macdonald would also wish to retain the right to take off all his buildings and mink fence should the lease at any time be terminated.

Mr. Plante felt that the rent should be paid to the amount that it is actually worth in lands. He thought that he was obliged to rent other land for school purposes, and the $15.00 yearly would enable him in selling the land. Mr. Plante thought that there was a case shown to the Department and perhaps they could be given consideration.

In closing I would say that in my opinion $15.00 per year is reasonable rent, and all concerned would be pleased to know as soon as possible if the lease is approved.
