Dear Sir:

With reference to Departmental letter 129-5-9 dated October 1, I would report as follows.

Mr. E. L. McConnon wished to purchase the parcel of land outlined on the attached sketch. With him is the owner of the adjoining land who will take further action if necessary.

The area marked "fresh" has good soil but the balance is solid rock formation. The height of the rock is from 6 to 8 feet high in places, varying from 10 to 30 feet in height and extending back hundreds of feet.

Mr. McConnon will, however, be pleased to receive a lease for a period of ten years or twenty-five years with the option to release or purchase. The amount of land desired is clearly noted on the sketch and probably amounts to about 4 acres. The land is about 5 acres of bush and the balance rock. The land is located a distance of at least 1 mile from the nearest school and is fairly accessible by road in a direct line about 1 mile. The corner of bush has yielded little to the soil and the trees have been cut down. In my opinion the leasing of this parcel of land will not materially affect the school, nor will it inconvenience the school in any way.

The Department will name what Mr. McConnon marked as "Mink Run" as his property, which property at this point is rock formation. The run is perhaps 50 x 100 feet.

Mr. McConnon is prepared to pay a yearly rental of $15.00 for the parcel he claimed. Mr. Pitt claimed to be.....

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
October 10, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your letter of October 7 regarding an application by Mr. E.L. McCannan to use a parcel of land near Seville, near the school property in connection with his mine farm.

In view of the circumstances and your recommendation, Mr. Pitts, Principal of the School, is being authorized to grant Mr. McCannan a lease of land, subject to the terms of your report above mentioned, being part of that parcel of land assigned as the south part of field, subject to an annual payment of $5.00 per acre, payable in advance.

I have accordingly written a letter to Mr. Pitts of even date, copy of which I enclose.

Yours very truly,

T.E.L. Macdonald,
Secretary.

A.G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
Please let me hear further from you on the subject at your early convenience.

Yours very truly,

T.C. L. Macdonald,
[Signature]

[Address]
Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School,
Kegonse, Ontario.
October 10, 1942.

Dear Mr. Fisher,

Please refer to previous correspondence concerning the application by Mr. R.L. McGowan to use a parcel of land near Carville Jeffrey School property in connection with his milk farm.

I am now in receipt of Inspector Hamilton's report on his recent investigation of this matter. According to the Inspector's report, the proposed location, comprising some four and a half acres is of very little benefit to the school. However, the loss of revenue would be experienced by granting Mr. McGowan's request. On the other hand, certain revenue would be obtained from other sources.

In the circumstances, therefore, you are hereby authorized to enter into an agreement with the said Mr. R.L. McGowan to grant him a permit of occupation for a period of ten years commencing January 1st, 1943, on an area not exceeding five acres, as indicated in red on a rough sketch map attached herewith. The area is enclosed herewith, being part of that parcel of land designated as the south park of Pike. In consideration of the payment annually of $50.00, payable in advance.

Kindly, therefore, communicate with Mr. McGowan and if he is prepared to accept the terms above mentioned, please complete the necessary forms and forward a copy to the department when it is signed by yourself and Mr. McGowan and properly witnessed.

The question of an extension, beyond the period of ten years, might be explained to Mr. McGowan, in so much as it is not the policy of the department to enter into such agreements, but there may be exceptional cases that is the ordinary course of events, and provided the present arrangement works out satisfactorily, a renewal for a further period of ten years would be granted.
OTTAWA, October 11, 1941.

Hugh B. Macmillan, Esq., M.P.,
Kenora, Ontario.

I have received the following Inspector Hamilton's report on the alleged investigation I have instructed Mr. Pitts to enter into agreement with McCann to sell the property in question to the Canadian Pacific Railway Company Ltd. The property in question is considered of patent annually by reason of amount of pipeline dollars.

T.B.L. Macmillan.

C.E.R.S.
T.A.

T.R.L. MacInnes Esq.,

RE: Rent of Land to McCowan.

Dear Mr. MacInnes:

I have your letter of Oct. 10th.

Mr. McCowan and myself have drawn up the following agreement (Enclosed) and I am forwarding a copy to your office.

If the terms as set forth in this agreement meet with the approval of the Department, they will go into effect on Nov. 1st.

The agreement was not drawn up by a lawyer. You may desire this done. If so, and you agree with the terms, I shall have a lawyer draw up the agreement and we shall sign it.

Is the Revenue ($15.00 per annum) to come to the school, or should it be sent to Ottawa? As I mentioned in a previous letter, if it were to come to the school, it would help to pay the rent on some land that we must rent for our farming.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL.

Enc: AGREEMENT.
October 26, 1941.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

I have your letter of October 20 enclosing agreement between yourself and Mr. E. L. Maclean.

This agreement has been reviewed here and appears to cover the requirements. It is suggested, however, that the word "funds" be inserted after the word "school" in the second line on the 13th page of page 3 so on the copy, because although the word "school" is used elsewhere it would be better to have it more specifically stated. With this correction, it is thought that the agreement will be acceptable. It does not appear to be any need to have it redrawn by a solicitor.

It is understood that you will be responsible for the collection of the revenue to be used for the benefit of the school as mentioned in your letter.

I am returning copy of the agreement and will be obliged if you will return it again to me with your signature thereto.

If convenient you might have the witnesses attest your signature and that of Mr. Maclean, before a justice of the Indian Agent, who sign this is not necessary.

Yours very truly,

T.S.L. Maclean,
Secretary.

THIS AGREEMENT made in quadruplicate, this 17th day of October, A.D., 1941.

BETWEEN:

THE GEOILIA JEFFREY SCHOOL, KENORA, OF THE TOWNSHIP OF JAFFRAY-WELLOCK, DISTRICT OF KENORA, AS TRUSTEE OF THAT PARCEL OF LAND KNOWN AS LOT 122P CON. 5, TOWNSHIP OF JAFFRAY-WELLOCK, DISTRICT OF KENORA, HERINAFTER CALLED THE SCHOOL

AND

ERNEST L. MCCAMMON, OF THE TOWNSHIP OF JAFFRAY, DISTRICT OF KENORA, FARMER,

WHEREAS the School is trustee of a parcel of land designated as Lot 122P Con. 5, which is owned by the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, and used by the School for the purposes of General Farming;

AND WHEREAS Mr. E. McCammon has expressed a wish to lease a portion of said Lot 122P South for the purpose of using the same for a Mink Farm, or business connected therewith, the parties hereto are desirous of entering this agreement so that Mr. McCammon may use this land for this purpose upon the conditions hereinafter set out.

NOW THEREFORE THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that in consideration of the sum of fifteen Dollars ($15.00) per annum payable in advance, and starting on the 1st of November A.D. 1941, the parties hereto hereby mutually covenant and agree as follows:

The amount of land to be leased by this agreement is to consist of that portion, or parcel of land known as the
Southerly part of the South Part of Lot 122P Gps. 5, in the Township of Jeffrey-Hollis, not to exceed five (5) acres.

It is further agreed that this lease is to extend for a period not to exceed ten years in any case, unless, at the expiration of this period the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, and Mr. McCammon enter into a further agreement to so further extend it.

It is also mutually understood that this lease may be cancelled by either party only after the expiration of six months after written NOTICE OF THE DESIRE TO CANCEL has been received by the other party. (Upon the authority of a letter dated Oct. 18, 1942, a permit of occupation for a period of ten years is granted to Mr. McCammon upon payment of the agreed fifteen Dollars ($15.00) payable in advance, annually.)

It is also mutually understood that Mr. McCammon will erect any and all fencing necessary for his work, and that the School will leave the fence known as the "Line Fence" where it now stands, on or near the Southern Boundary of Lot 122P South.

It is also mutually understood that Mr. McCammon is permitted to cut these trees or "brush" locally so-called that hamper his work, but not trees. If Mr. McCammon requires to cut further quantities of trees, he will get the consent of the School before doing so.

It is also agreed that any buildings erected on this property by Mr. McCammon, are to remain his property, and are to be removed within six months after the
Expiration of the Lease.

It is also understood that any wire fence or other fence erected by Mr. McCammon is also to remain his property and be removed within six months after expiration of the lease. (This is to include a fence on the East side of the part being leased by Mr. McCammon if other livestock is kept in or pastured in this parcel.)

IN WITNESS WHEREOF both parties hereto set their signatures:

SIGNED in the presence of

[Signature]

Cecilia Jeffries [signature]

Ernest H. McCammon

KENORA · ONTARIO

Oct. 30th, 1944.

Dear Sir:

RE: ERECTION POLES, Utilities, KENORA, on school property.

The Public Utilities of Kenora and Mr. Archie Davidson, Farmer, Jaffray Township have asked me to make the following request:

A group of three neighbouring settlers are desirous of having electricity and telephone installed in their homes. The nearest outlet to the Electric System is from a line which runs through our property, (originally built by contract between the Rama Department and the Town of Kenora in 1925, and which was to revert to full ownership of the Town of Kenora after 15 years.) The nearest hook-up with the Hydro line other than from our property would be approx. one half mile further.

May request, therefore that the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, grant permission for the erection of two poles on the property of said Department.

I recommend granting this request, it to be understood that it entail no expense to us, either in erection or future upkeep. As planned, these two poles would in no way affect adversely any forseen future operation of the school. Indeed, we will be able to hook a line of our own onto the poles for extension to outbuildings. Further, it is understood that the lines be affixed before the meter.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

June 30th, 1945.

Mr. N. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ont.

RE: SALE OF LAND - Portion of South Part Lot 122P

Dear Sir:

The above noted part of the South Part of Lot 122P, Oon. 5 was leased to Mr. Ernest McCammon, by Authority of the Department in letter dated Oct. 10th, 1941, for a period of ten years.

Since that time, Mr. E. McCammon has married, and now is desirous of extending his Mink Farm and building a house. He wishes me to enquire of the department whether they would consider the sale of this property to him.

(I would refer you to agreement of that date with Diagram attached.)

Mr. McCammon would also like to purchase the additional part (other than that leased) of the Cultivated Field of Approx. 10 acres to the East, (i.e., to boundary of property) and all the south portion of this designated lot, south of the centre of the River. He states that this was surveyed and recorded in 1926 at full time. Mr. McCammon has considered purchasing this part from a previous owner of our property and the surveying was done. He states that there are approximately 40 acres in the whole parcel.

Mr. McCammon would offer $400.00 for this part of land. This figure was arrived at by an interview with the Municipal Assessor.

OUR RECOMMENDATION: As this portion of land is rather distant from the school, and partly rock, we might be in favour, but only if there would be a possibility of the school constructing a new land nearer to our buildings, at some future date. We find it necessary to rent two other farms, in order to make our farm pay. (This land which Mr. McCammon desires is much more valuable to his because of its close proximity and accessibility.)

Would you please forward the enclosed copy, with your observations and recommendations to the Department for their consideration.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

2 Copies.
Ottawa, July 17, 1945.

Mr. H. Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a communication from Mr. D. S. Pitts, with reference to the request of Mr. Ernest McCammon to purchase approximately two acres of the property forming part of the farm at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

I have discussed the letters with the Director and it has been decided that the Department is not prepared to sell any of the land belonging to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School at the present time.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, 18th September, 1945.

Mr. H. Peterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ontario.

I desire to refer to your letter of July 1st and my reply of July 17th with reference to the request of Ernest McCammon to purchase approximately two acres of property forming part of the farm at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

Mr. McCammon's father visited this office recently and discussed the matter again at that time. I promised him I would review the whole situation with the Director and I did so this afternoon. Mr. McCammon has a ten-year lease on this property effective from October 17, 1941 and while I cannot make any definite promise to that effect, it is quite likely when this lease expires it will be renewed if Mr. McCammon so desires. Consequently I feel that he would be reasonably safe in erecting what buildings he would require on this property.

I enclose a sketch which Mr. McCammon Sr. left with me. Please advise Mr. McCammon regarding the contents of this letter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, December 11, 1935.

Dear Sir:

Mrs. D. T. L. McKerroll, of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church, visited the Department recently and stated that the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School wishes to have Julia Kavanaugh admitted to that school, but that, for some reason, the admission of the girl had not been approved.

I have reviewed the file regarding admissions and discharges to the Cecilia Jeffrey School last year and cannot find any record of this girl. Please let me have your advice.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Sup't. of Indian Education.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Amora, Ont.
Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter 129-3-10 of 11th inst., you inform us you cannot find any correspondence re Julia Singleton (Kavanagh) Eagle Lake Band.

We would refer you to Departmental letters 129-3-10 of September 28th and October 16th, in which we are instructed that no grant would be allowed for this girl and that she should be returned to her home at Eagle Lake.

We have taken up this matter with the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School on numerous occasions but she has not yet been sent home. She contracted Chicken Pox at the school and naturally had to be kept for a certain time, but on discussing the matter with Dr. Ferguson the Chicken Pox subsided some time ago and the girl could have been home within the last two weeks.

We think she should be in some school, but it is a question which school she should be admitted to.

An early reply will oblige.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, January 4, 1935.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, with reference to the request for the admission of Julia Singleton to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

As you were informed in official letter of September 26, 1935, the Department considers that this girl should be returned to her father. Please inform the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School accordingly.

About the first of April, you should again interview the father and advise the Department what his wishes are regarding the religious auspices under which he desires his daughter educated.

Yours Truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division Sub-Division Detachment
"D" "D"
Province

Date

14th January, 1936

File Reference

Re:
Madison N. MILLER & Birrie TUSDAY
Truant Indian Boys, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School
Kenora, Ontario.

12-1-36

1. On the above date this detachment was notified by telephone that Madison MILLER and Birrie TUSDAY had run away from Cecilia J. DUNN Indian School, Kenora, Ont., sometime during the 12th January. This information was supplied by Mr. Myers Principal of the above mentioned school.

2. Information was received from enquiries made in Kenora, Ont., that the two boys would try and reach their home at Pearson, Lake of the Woods by the way of the winter trail across the lake. Acting on this information I started on patrol across the lake via hired auto at 12-1-36. At French Portage, Lake of the Woods the two boys were located, having walked a distance of 10 miles from Kenora, Ont., and spent the night out in the open without any shelter or blankets, the two boys were still there when they had nothing but food from the time they left Kenora, Ont., until they reached French Portage, Lake of the Woods which was some twenty hours without food.

3. I returned to the detachment at 4:45 p.m. escorting the two boys where I notified Capt. Edwards Indian Agent re: the above and was requested by him to escort the boys to Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School and hand them over to the Principal, Mr. Myers, this request was carried out and I returned to the detachment of patrol at 7:45 p.m. 13-1-36.

SIGNED

J. A. Wardle
Const.

The Officer Commanding,
Royal Canadian Mounted Police,
"D" Division, Winnipeg, Man.,
12-1-36

Province Ontario

Date February 10th, 1936

File Reference

Charlie PATOUSH - Truant Indian Boy, from
Ucilia Jeffery Indian School,
Kenora, Ontario.

2-2-36

1. Acting on instructions received from the Constable
in charge at Kenora, I left Kenora, Ont., at 10:00
p.m. this date and patrolled by Horse Auto to the Indian
Reserve at Minaki, Ont., and there
continued enquiries with a view to ascertaining if the
above mentioned truant Indian boy had been seen in
those localities in the afternoon or evening of this date.
As I was unsuccessful in obtaining any information
at Indian House or First Portage, I returned to Kenora and
continued enquiries off several Indians in town and learned
that only one taxi had been here this date to convey an
Indian, Peter HINTY, part way to miles Indian Reserve,
the home of PATOUSH, and that PATOUSH did not at that time
accompany HINTY.

3-2-36

2. On this date Capt. J. Edwards, Indian Agent at Kenora,
communicated by telegram with the Hudson's Bay Company
agent at Minaki and learned that this boy's father,
Robert Johnson PATOUSH, was on the way to Kenora. I
therefore kept a watch in town and on 4-2-36 I located
Robert Johnson PATOUSH who informed me that his boy,
Charlie had not arrived here, and that he was returning to
Minaki on 5-2-36 and would then advise Capt. Edwards if
his boy had arrived here or not.

7-2-36

3. On this date Capt. Edwards received a letter from
Robert Johnson PATOUSH advising that his boy, Charlie, had
arrived at the Dales Indian Reserve and that his face
and hands had been frostbitten. I therefore left Kenora
at 12:00 noon this date and patrolled by Dog team to the
miles Indian Reserve on arrival there to learn that
Charlie PATOUSH was at Minaki. I then returned to Kenora
arriving at 6:00 p.m.

8-2-36

4. On this date I left Kenora by Police Dog team and
patrolled to Minaki, Ont., arriving 7:30 p.m. I then located
Charlie PATOUSH and found that his face and hands had not
been badly frostbitten. I remained in Minaki overnight.

2-2-36

5. At 9:00 a.m. this date, I left Minaki with Robert
Johnson PATOUSH and his son Charlie and patrolled by Dog
Team to Kenora, Ont., arriving at Kenora at 4:30 p.m.

Dear Sir:

In September and October, last, and again last month, Mr. Agent Edwards was instructed to request you to return Julia Singleton to her father. Mr. Edwards advises that he conveyed our instructions to you, but that the girl is still in the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

The Department cannot understand why you have not complied with our request, and I would appreciate your co-operating with us by returning the girl to her father immediately on receipt of this letter. Please advise when you have carried out our wishes in this matter.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Indian Agent.

Yours truly,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

WINNIPEG, MAN., February 24th, 1936

Sir:

During my work at Kenora, the Agent showed me the correspondence in connection with Julia Singleton, a girl in the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, and referred to in Department Letter 129-3-10 dated February 10th, 1936, addressed to Indian Agent Edwards.

Julia is still in residence and Mr. Byers is of the opinion that he should not discharge the girl until instructed to do so by Mrs. McKerroll. I made it quite plain to Mr. Byers that, as far as we were concerned, our instructions were taken from the Department and that the girl should be discharged.

I think this matter should be closed definitely and at once, and I would suggest that the Department write direct to Mr. Byers, instructing him to discharge the girl and that a copy of the letter be sent to the Indian Agent.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

KENORA, ONT., Feb. 28th, 193

Mr. J.D. Sutherland,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re Letter I'9-3-IO, Feb. 17th,

Dear Sir,

Re Julia Singleton I wish to state that this child came to school in the fall in a much weakened condition and very shortly afterwards developed Pneumonia. I was discussing school matters with Mrs. McKerroll and mentioned the case of this pupil. Mrs. McKerroll said she had business in Ottawa and would take the matter up with the Dept. Following up her interview with the Dept., she wrote me stating she had had a very favourable interview with the Minister and with the Dept., and she was advised that Julia was to remain in the school for the present.

Shortly after this the Agent sent me instructions that Julia was to be sent home. I notified Mrs. McKerroll I was going to send the child home and again she notified me that she had just returned from Ottawa and that the Dept. was allowing the girl to remain in the school.

All this time I was under the impression that the Dept. approved of her remaining in the school for the present. This was what I assumed from Mrs. McKerroll's instructions.

I am sending the girl home this week or rather to her grandmother who has raised the girl. The grandmother informs me that the father takes no interest whatever in the child and that she is unable to keep her unless she receives help from the Dept. She was certainly in a run down condition when she came to school. I regret for the child's interests to see her sent back to the conditions under which she will be obliged to exist. I expect she will be leaving the school tomorrow.

Hoping I have made my position clear to you,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

[Stamp]

Dear Sir:

We are in receipt of copy of your letter 129-3-10 of 16th inst. to the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, notifying him that Stanley Benn #168 is sixteen years of age and to arrange for his discharge.

Yesterday we received a letter from Mr. A.G. Smith, Indian Agent at Birtle, which we inclose herewith.

After discussing the matter with the Principal, we would suggest the boy be kept at the school till the summer holidays and then the matter of his discharge could be discussed, as you will note from the letter Benn's father is living with a half breed and has no home for his son to go to.

The Principal has promised to write us what he thinks should be done when the pupils go on vacation.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
S/18

Birtle Manitoba
14th March 1936

Dear Sir,

Thomas Dunn of the Bird Tail Reserve was in here today, and informed me that his son Stanley is getting into a lot of trouble at the Cecilia Jefferies School, and he wants to get him home.

As a matter of fact Thomas is living on the road allowance with a half breed woman and has no home for the boy to come to, and it would be very poor policy to let the boy out simply because he is unruly, unless he is a general nuisance in the school, and shows the other children a bad example. In some cases a really bad boy is a menace to the school, and it is a good thing to let them out.

I understand that you investigated this case and would be glad to know what you think about it.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

Captain Edwards

Ottawa, April 27, 1936.

Dear Sir:

Referring to previous correspondence, regarding the application forwarded under cover of your letter of September 18, 1935, for the admission of Julia Kavanagh (or Singleton), No. 78, Eagle Lake Band, to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, I would request that you again consider the matter with the girl's father, Mr. Kavanagh definitely from him whether he desires that this girl remain at the school or be returned to her home. It is understood that the father is Roman Catholic and the mother, Pagan.

The Department has had certain pressure brought, through the authorities of the Presbyterian Church, for permission to admit this girl to the Cecilia Jeffrey School as a regular non-attending pupil. If the admission of the girl to the Cecilia Jeffrey School was approved there would, no doubt, be objections raised, on the part of the Roman Catholic Church authorities, in view of the fact that her father is stated to be Catholic. Therefore, the Department requires to receive the definite wishes of the father and also your recommendation, regarding the application for the admission of this girl to the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

I should be pleased if you would give this matter your early attention and report fully, as soon as it is possible for you to interview the girl's father.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
KESURA, ONT.
White child and at 15 he can scarcely be rated among teen age children. When he goes out at this age he becomes isolated from school influence and becomes absorbed into the reserve and much of his training is lost.

At the age of 16 or 17, she or he has acquired a certain amount of individuality and independence and at this age is in a better position to help himself and to make a living.

I would very much like to see them in school until they are at least 18.

Before the end of the term I hope to have more to report re the various pupils as I shall be in a better position to recommend the discharges.

I remain,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS OF CANADA

Cecilia Jeffrey School
Presbyterian

KENORA, ONT.—May 11th—193—

Sept. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,—Re Letter May 6th re Pupils for discharge.

No. 081 Mary Pegg. This girl has been taking a special course in Art. She has completed a commercial course in Art and is taking special lessons now. She shows ability in art and we are anxious to give her as much instruction as possible here and then the Missionary Society will undertake further training for her. If we must discharge her, her studies will be lost.

No. 023 Maud Sandy was brought back to school during the winter as she was in a badly run down condition and with the treatment received in the school she has almost recovered her normal health. Home conditions are not very good and she does not want to return home.

No. 025 Margaret Sinclair. This girl has been working in the residence and is the most reliable and clean girl in the school. She is accustomed to the duties in the residence and would be a great help there.

No. 103 Alfred Lindsey has exceptional ability in Art and we have been giving him private lessons. He is anxious to make Art his profession.

No. 115 Alex Sinclair. He is in High School and is doing well in his work. He is an intelligent boy and is well in school. His both parents are dead.

I think his discharge might be granted.

If I may be permitted to do so I would like to make a few observations from my study of the pupils. I find the results of the school work very much more worth while when the pupil is retained in school until he or she is 13 years of age or older. When they are discharged at 16 much of the school work is lost. From 16 to 13 there is such a marked development and they become so much more set in the proper outlook on life. They are more stable and more dependent upon themselves.

The Indian child does not mature as early as the average
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 27th ult #129-3-10, re children over 16 at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

Enclosed herewith letter received from the Principal. He informs me Fraser Kellick, if he completes his studies at the High School, will be there about two more years.

In addition to the children named in your letter, there are about 11 more children that will have reached the age of 16 or over by the end of the next quarter, and I have informed the Principal he should ask for their discharge or apply for permission to keep them as grant earning pupils, so as to keep things straight, this he has promised to do.

Margaret Sinclair is working in the Residence, and some of the other children are I understand working on the staff; should grant be paid for them?

The Principal is anxious to keep the pupils until they are 18 years old or even older, but is this expense justified? Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 20, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, please inform the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School that the Department is not prepared to allow per capita grant after June 30th, 1936, for the following pupils:

- No. 054 - Mary Begg,
- No. 0111 - Maud Sandy,
- No. 0128 - Margaret Sinclair,
- No. 0141 - Marie Adams,
- No. 103 - Alfred Lindsay,
- No. 135 - Alex Sinclair.

Unless the Principal is in a position to secure employment for them, they should be returned to their homes.

With reference to Fraser Kesick, No. 106, you should secure a report from the Principal of the High School regarding his progress. Possibly the Principal would report confidentially regarding whether or not he considers it would be advisable to allow this boy to continue at high school. As soon as this report is received, the Department will decide if any further assistance can be given to him.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Re: Charlie PATOUL - et al
Trust Indian Boys,

11-5-36.

1. With reference to the above I have to report that in the forenoon of this date R.J. BURS, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School here reported to this detachment that Charlie PATOUL, William HEN and Morris WILLIAMS, Indian boys, were missing from the C.J. Indian School, having left on the 12th inst.

2. Enquiries were immediately conducted in the vicinity of Kanora and it was learned from an Indian, Sam GARDINER, that these Indian boys were seen around the Indian House, about 2 miles from Kanora. In the late evening of the 12th inst., at 10:00 p.m., on the 13th, I left Kanora with Police Boat, Johnson Outboard motor Code No.7365, accompanied by S/Cst. Burns, and patrolled to Indian House, Devil's Gap and Porcupine Bay, Lake of the Woods, in search of the missing boys. From Charlie Williams, father of the missing Morris WILLIAMS, at Porcupine Bay, it was learned that the boy, Morris, had not arrived home. Charlie WILLIAMS promised to notify this detachment should he return to his home.

3. The patrol then returned to Kanora, arriving at 5:00 p.m., to learn that Mr. BURS had reported further that the missing boy William HEN had returned to the school on the 13th, inst., and advised that he had not been in the company of the other missing boys.

4. Further enquiries are being conducted in an effort to locate and return the missing boys to school.

Police Beat "Illness" - 21 miles.

FURTHER STATEMENT REQUIRED.

DEAL UNDER INVESTIGATION.

1. With reference to the above, and marginally noted report, and further to Const. Stanley's report re: the above dated at Kenora the 15-5-36, I have to report that on the above date, I left Kenora, Ont. at 1.00 p.m., with Police Beat, Johnson Outboard Motor Code No. 7365, accompanied by S/Off. J. Burns and patrolled Minaki, Ont., and there located Charlie PATOUSH one of the Truant Indian Boys.

2. Upon questioning Charlie PATOUSH about running away from school, he informed me that he had run away by himself and did not know that anyone else had run away, or could he give any information regarding the whereabouts of the other missing boy Harris WILLIAMS; he also stated that he had left school as he was tired of it, and wanted to stay at home, this being the only reason he gave for running away from school.

3. On the same date, at 7.30 I left Minaki, Ont. for Kenora, Ont. with the above mentioned boy arriving in Kenora at 9.00 p.m., at the paper mill. J.A. Reid's flat truck was hired to transport the Police transport from the paper mill to the post house.

4. At 10.00 p.m. the same date, I left via Private owned Auto for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School and handed the above mentioned boy over to the school authorities, and returned to the Detachment off patrol at 11.00 p.m. the 14-5-36.

Ottawa, June 10, 1936.

On the occasion of your recent visit to the Department, you requested further consideration to the case of Julia Lavanagh (Singisten), of the Eagle Lake Band.

The Indian Agent was written and he has replied stating that he again interviewed the father of this girl. The Agent reports that the father has always been recognized as a Roman Catholic and when the Agent recently asked him whether religious auspices he wished his girl educated, he stated definitely that he desired her placed in the Kenora R.C. Residential School. Her admission to that school is, therefore, being approved.

Kenora Public Schools,

June 15, 1935.

Capt. Edwards,
Indian agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Capt. Edwards:

We have had for the past year, in our Class, in the Kenora Public School, two Indian boys, Fraser Kesick and Jimmy Comican. In your communication of May 24th re Fraser Kesick, whether I think it advisable for the boy to continue or not school.

I have been discussing Fraser's case with Mr. Jones and Mrs. Jones, the Indians of the Indian School, and with my own staff. Fraser has not been doing very well in his studies. He is very close to passing, but I believe it might be a good idea to give him another chance. He has two or three former instructors at the Indian School apparently desire to see this boy himself for further work. This has been done with the young Indians on the reserves of Manitota and Southern Ontario.

This year has been a new experience for me. I have known for the first time about students of Anglo-Saxon parentage. He has enjoyed the year, but could have applied himself rather more diligently in studies. Another year would further the acid.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]
T. C. Keenan
Supervising Principal
Public Schools, Kenora.
Ottawa, June 27th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to two pupils of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

Jimmy Comigan is shown on the return as sixteen years of age and, while the letter from the Principal does not state so definitely, the Department understands that he has been successful in his fifth class work. He may, therefore, remain for another year.

Fraser Kesiek is now eighteen years of age and it is noted from the Principal's report that he has been unsuccessful during the past year. Our policy has been that, when an Indian pupil is unsuccessful, no further educational advantage can be given to him. The Department does not see that anything would be gained by him repeating the work next year. It is considered that he should be discharged.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Sup't of Indian Education.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

where I located Fred KELLY, Alex SIMILAR & Arnold PINEBUS,
and returned these boys to the C.J. Indian School.

3. Accompanied by S/Cst. Burns J., I then patrolled
by Private Owned Auto to the Indian House, Kenora District,
and to Redditt, Ont. conducting enquiries along the road
but without obtaining any further information regarding
the missing boys. Patrol returned to Detachment at 1.45

21-6-36

4. On this date while returning off patrol I met

were made at Minaki, Ont. with a view of locating the
other missing boys, and the following information received

Ottawa, September 18, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the enclosed applications for the admission of Donald, Sandford and Alex McDonald to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

Please let me know to what Band these Indians belong. You state "Red Lake" on the application forms but, presumably, this refers to the place where the McDonalds are living.

You should, also, state definitely whether the McDonalds are Indians or half-breeds.

On receipt of your reply, the applications will receive further consideration.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Dept. of Indian Education.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kanora, Ont.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division Sub-Division Detachment
55 "D" "004" Kenora, Ont.

Province

Date
11th September, 1936

File References

Fr
Billy Gardiner & al Truant Indian Children
Cecilia Jeffry Indian School, Kenora District,
Kenora, Ont.

10-9-36

Headquarters

1. On this date, I left on patrol via Private owned Car, accompanied by S/Cst. Burns J. for Minervia, Ont. to escort the above mentioned together with his sister Kathleen Gardiner who had not returned to School after the Summer holidays. On our arrival at Minervia, Ont. at 2:30 p.m., enquiries were made and various persons stating Billy & Kathleen Gardiner and the following information received that the above mentioned children were somewhere on the Wabigoon River with their father Bill Gardiner, returned to Dryden, Ont. and made enquiries there for Nancy Gardiner, and the following information received that Nancy Gardiner was living at home on one of the Inland's on the Wabigoon Lake 16 miles South of Dryden, Ont. at Wabigoon Lake a boat was hired from Mr. Bailey to take the patrol across the Lake to the home of Gardiner's, where Nancy Gardiner was located and brought back to Dryden, Ont. Enquiries were also made at Dryden with a view to locating Bill Gardiner and we were informed that he was on the Wabigoon River somewhere between Eagle River, Ont. and Waldhof, Ont.

2. The patrol left Dryden, Ont. for Eagle River, Ont. accompanied by Nancy Gardiner at 7:30 p.m. arriving in Eagle River at 8:30 p.m. where enquiries were made in regards to Charlie Williams and it was ascertained that this boy was living with his Sister 5 miles South of Eagle River, the patrol continued on to the home of Charlie Williams' Sister where the above mentioned boy was located. Enquiries were also made at Eagle River, Ont. with a view to locating Bill Gardiner, but no information could be obtained as to the whereabouts of this man.

3. The patrol left Eagle River, Ont. for Waldhof, Ont. accompanied by Nancy Gardiner and Charlie Williams at 10:00 p.m., arriving at Waldhof at 10:30 p.m. where enquiries were made for Bill Gardiner, and the following information received that Bill Gardiner was located at present 5 miles North Waldhof and 2 miles down the Wabigoon River. The patrol continued to the Wabigoon River where a dance was obtained to continue the rest of the way, at the camp of Bill Gardiner's, we located Billy Gardiner and Kathleen Gardiner with whom we returned to Waldhof.

4. The Patrol left Waldhof, Ont. for Kenora at 1:15 a.m. the 11-9-36 for Cecilia Jeffry Indian School, Kenora Dist. arriving at Cecilia Jeffry Indian School at 3:30 a.m. where the before mentioned children were turned over to R.V. Byrne Esq., Principal, returning to the detachment at 4:00 a.m. off patrol.

Province

25th September, 1936

Re:

The ORANGE et al., Truant Indian Children,
Cecilia Jeffery and St. Mary's (R.C.) Indian
School, Kenora, Ont.

24-9-36

1. On the morning date, I left on patrol at 8:30 a.m.
via Police Boat and Johnson (Outboard Motor Code No. 7165)
and travelled to Poplar Bay Indian Reserve, Lake of the
Bods, Kenora District, and there made enquiries for Joe
Green, Andy Green, Charlie Green and Agnes Williams
Truant Indian children from C.J. Ki-ten School, and the
following information received that Andy and Martin Joe
Green had returned to school that morning, and that Agnes
Williams had left on a hunt with her father with Charlie
Green and their parents. Circumstances were unknown to the
other Indians at the Reserve, but was also informed by the
father of Charlie CRNT that he would return his boy to
school when he arrived back off the hunt.

2. The patrol continued to Rat Portage Indian Reserve,
Lake of the Bods, Kenora District, and there enquiries
were made for Truant Indian Children from St. Mary's
(R.C.) Indian School, Kenora, Ont., and I was informed by
their father that 1936 "Bone-Treaty" that he was not
coming in, but would be back to the Reserve. At this time
two before mentioned children were somewhere they were left
with their fathers, and on the return of this patrol to
Kenora, Ont. at 1:30 p.m., this information was conveyed
to Capt. F. H. W., Indian Agent at Kenora, Ont.

SIGNED

Filing Police Beat 35 miles

The Officer Commanding
Royal Canadian Mounted Police
4th Division, Winnipeg, Man.
Sir: Forwarded 24-9-36

I have the honor to state that Mr. Edwards, Ld. Agent at Kenora
supplied the writer with a list containing the names
of 2 Indian Children who had failed to return to Indian
Schools, above mentioned, following summer holidays and
requested assistance in having such children returned to
respective schools. Further action will be taken to have
balance return to schools.

(Signed)

No. 10b-17

Assistant Deputy Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter #129-3-10 of the 16th ultimo, re: admission of Donald Sanford and Alex McDonald to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. I was abroad when the applications were sent in, but now find that these children are half-breeds. They do not live on a reserve and the "Red Lake" they come from originally is not in Canada, but in Minnesota, U.S.A.

The family are up against it, but I think we refused admission to these children to one of our schools some years ago. I therefore do not see how the department can approve their admission, although I feel sorry for them. I should be glad to receive a reply so that I can notify the principal as their present residence is at the school and are included in the September quarterly returns. I have signed the returns enclosed herewith, but do not know whether a grant will be allowed for these children.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Kenora, Ontario,
October 8, 1936.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find quarterly returns for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. Pupils No. 227, 228, and 229 are half-breeds and I doubt if their admission will be approved. The others are new children and their applications will go forward later. Pupil C210, Mary and pupil C213, Emma, are not yet of school age, but I would recommend their admission be approved as Mary has no mother and Emma, No. C213 has come to school with her sister and will shortly be of school age.

I have certified the returns, but the figures and the amount of capital grant will have to be changed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 14, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to the September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

In view of the information given in your letter, the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of Donald, Sandford and Alan MacDonald to this school. If they are in the school at the present time, they should be returned to their home.

You may, also, inform the Principal that the discharge of Sherry Esplinnesse - No. 162, is approved.

Application forms and certificates of health should be forwarded as soon as possible for the following:

No. 0808 - J. Martin
No. 250 - G. Paych
No. 255 - A. Redsky
No. 351 - H. Paych
No. 356 - J. Redsky
No. 4111 - M. Patock

I would point out that a number of these pupils have been in the school for several months. The Department cannot understand the delay in forwarding the application forms.

Please inform the Principal that the admission of Mary Veginesse, Irene Cameron and Emma Cameron is approved.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Dept. of Indian Education.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Renfrew, Ont.
Dear Sir,

Pupil #0109 Mary Green at Cecilia Jeffrey School (#51 Shoal Lake Band#39) is now attending High School in Kenora.

A short time ago her father came in and wanted her discharged as she will be 17 on November 10th. Next we phoned the Principal who informed us that the girl had written him a letter saying she wished to stay at the school and attend the High School. We asked the Principal to bring the girl down to the Office which he did about a week ago, when we asked her what she wanted to do and she told us she had promised Mr. Byers the Principal to go to High School.

On Thursday the 22nd. last, we told her father what she had said but he still maintained she wanted to get out and told us he would see her himself.

He came into the Office on Saturday with Mary who now says she wants to be discharged as she has a job to go to and wished us to wire Ottawa for her discharge.

The Principal does not wish her discharge and will not apply for it. As we do not think the High School will do her any good, but if she would stay, till the summer vacation she could be discharged then if she still wished it.

Awaiting your decision in this matter,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, October 30, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant, the Department considers that it would be in the best interests of Mary Green No. 6109, to remain at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School until June 30th, next, at which time she should be discharged.

Please inform her father and the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Gupt. of Indian Education.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division Sub-Division Detachment
Kenora, Ont.
Province Date
Ontario 06th, 23rd., 1936.

File Reference:
Joe OGDEN et al - Tyuant Indian Children,
Cecilia Jeffrey and St. Mary's (R.C.) Indian Schools,
Kenora, Ontario.

Headquarters:
With reference to the above report of the marginally noted date, and letter from Inspector in charge C.I.R. Winnipeg, under date of the 21st inst., in this connection I have to report the following:

Sub-Division:
Following the submission of report as marginally noted the writer interviewed Capt. J. Edwards, Indian Agent at Kenora and discussed with him the matter of the return of the 20 Indians children who were absent from the above mentioned schools by this Detachment. Capt. Edwards suggested that the matter be let stand for some time as he anticipated a visit to most Indian Reserves on the Lake of the Woods for the purpose of distribution of land funds and at such time would take the matter of absentee children up with parents and so perhaps have parents return such children to respective schools without the incurring of considerable expense to the Department.

Detachment:
On the 22nd inst., the writer communicated by telephone with Mr. W. Myers, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School here, to ascertain the number of Indian children at present absent from his School. Mr. Myers advised that most of the children reported absent had already returned, that some of the children now absent were old enough that he did not desire that they be returned and that he now desired the return of three children only, Irene CRAW, Henrie OHLE and Arnold PHILPOT. Mr. MYERS further advised that Charlie LEE was still absent but that this boy's father had promised to return this boy to the school in the near future.

PCR Kenora.
25-9-36.

On the 22nd inst., the writer communicated with the Principal of the St. Mary's (R.C.) Indian School here to ascertain the number of children absent at present from such school, and was advised that eight children were still absent and that their return was desired. These eight children reside in different parts of detachment area and the matter will be taken up with Capt. Edwards for his instructions with regard to their return, as soon as Capt. Edwards, who is at present absent from Kenora, returns.

In compliance with a request of the 21st inst., by Capt. Edwards, a patrol was scheduled to start to N.West Angle this date, to locate and return Henrie OHLE & Arnold PHILPOT to C.J. School, but due to the intervention of another patrol such patrol to N.West Angle had to be postponed until tomorrow. Further report will be submitted following such patrol.

TILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.

(Signed)
(S. Stanley) Reg. No. 20475
1/C Kenora Detachment.

The U.C. R.C.P.
Manitoba District

With reference to above mentioned matter and further

that at 8:30 a.m. this date, accompanied by W/Jt. Burns, J.,
I left Kenora and travelled by Police Boat Johnson (Outboard
motor Code No.756), to North East Angle on the Lake of the
woods, arriving at the latter point at 5:15 p.m.

25-10-36.

Sub-Division

During the evening of the 24th Inst., and in the
P.C.R.

Kenora

25-9-36.

Detachment

At 11:00 a.m. patrol left North East Angle and
conveyed Chief OCHIL, Bernie OCHIL, Arnold RIDGWAY and
Lyn OCHIL to Kenora, arriving at Kenora at 5:30 p.m.
At Kenora, the three Indian children, last above mentioned,
were conveyed by hired auto to Cecilia Jeffrey Indian
School and delivered to Mr. Hyre, Principal.
Chief OCHIL was then permitted to proceed to Indian House
after first being advised that he would be served at the Indian
Agent's office at 9:30 a.m. of the 26th, to answer to a
charge to be preferred under Sec.10 c.c.o.4, Ind. Acts, for
failing to return the above mentioned boys to School, age
2645 & C of crown dated, heading "William OCHIL - N/Foot Angle
Ind.Reserve, Sec.10 (4) Ind.Acts."

Present standing still leaves some children absent

Division Sub-Division Detachment
Province Province

Date Oct. 23rd, 1936.

Re: Edgar WELLS - Unitedog Indian Reserve, Ontario.
Truant Indian Boy - St. Mary's Indian School,
Kenora, Ontario.

28-10-36.

1. With reference to the above, I have to report that I left Kenora at 3:45 a.m., this date, and patrolled by hired auto to Reddiit, Ont., enroute to Valachi, Ont., to locate the above mentioned truant Indian boy and return him to St. Mary's Indian School, Kenora. I left Reddiit by C.H.R. at 5:10 a.m., and patrolled to Valachi, arriving at latter point at 9:10 a.m.

2. At Valachi I patrolled on foot into the bush for three miles and there found the above mentioned boy cutting wood and escorted him to Valachi, where I was obliged to remain until 9:00 p.m., when I left Valachi and patrolled by C.H.R. to Reddiit, arriving at latter point at 10:00 p.m. I left Reddiit immediately and patrolled by hired auto to Kenora and then to St. Mary's (N.C.) Indian School, where I handed over the boy to Father J.M. Baillargeon, Principal of the School.

Mileage - Hired Auto - 50 miles.
C.H.R. - 60 "
On Foot - 6 "

Kenora, Ont.
At 3:30 p.m., this date, Mr. H. W. Myers, Principal of the Coulson Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora, advised that Adam Johnson and Horace Phillips, pupils, had left said school in the afternoon of the 10th inst., and requested assistance in having these boys returned to school.

Enquiries were immediately conducted with a view to ascertaining where these boys might be located, and on the 12th inst., it was advised that these boys had returned to the school on such date, having been on the Winnipeg River, north of Kenora, during their absence.

In view of the above, this file is considered concluded.

No expense incurred.

1. With reference to the above, and further to reports
of the marginally noted dates, I have to report that,
acting on instructions, I left Kenora, Ont. at 2.10 p.m.,
this date, and patrolled by C.P.R. to Dinorwic, Ont.,
arriving at latter point at 5.20 p.m., remaining overnight.

Sub Division
17-11-36.

Detachment
2. From enquiries made at Dinorwic it was learned that
Albert HOFFMANN - truant Indian boy, was residing at Sandy
Lake, about 17 miles from Dinorwic. Accordingly, I left
Dinorwic, by hired auto, at 10.00 a.m. this date, and
patrolled to Sandy Lake and there located the before
mentioned truant living with Charlie CANTON. I then
conveyed said truant, by hired auto, to Dinorwic, arriving
at latter point at 3.00 p.m., where patrol was obliged
to remain until 12.50 p.m. following date for train
service.

P.C.R.
Kenora.
25-9-36.
23-10-36.
26-10-36.

18-11-36.

3. At 12.50 p.m. this date, I left Dinorwic, Ont., with
before mentioned truant, and patrolled by C.P.R. to
Eagle River, at which point I detained, leaving truant on
train enroute to Kenora; and sending a telegram, collect,
to detachment at Kenora advising of such action and
requesting that said truant be taken off train at Kenora
for delivery to St. Mary's Indian School.

4. At Eagle River I hired auto and patrolled to Eagle
River Indian Reserve and there located Mary Jane INDIAN -
truant Indian Girl from St. Mary's Indian School, and
brought her to Eagle River, arriving at latter point at
6.00 p.m.

19-11-36.

5. At 1.30 a.m. this date, I left Eagle River, with Mary
Jane INDIAN, and patrolled by C.P.R. to Kenora, Ont., arriving
at Kenora at 5.30 a.m. At Kenora I proceeded by
hired auto to St. Mary's Indian School and there handed
Mary Jane INDIAN over to Father RENLANGSON, Principal of
School, returning to Kenora at 6.15 a.m.

Ottawa, January 15, 1937.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the December quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, you may inform the Principal that the admission of Nudia Ah Quon and Ta Pee Kah Ga Gay is approved.

When pupils have been officially discharged, their names should be removed from the quarterly return. You should point out this requirement to the Principal. It would also be advisable to remind him that all columns of the return should be added. Explicit instructions regarding the preparation of the quarterly return are printed on the back of the form, and these should be carried out.

The Department has not yet received application form and certificate of health for Joyce Martin, No. 0206. This form was requested in official letter of July 8th, last.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find application form for the admission of Eliza Ochis to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

In this connection I would refer you to Department letter #129-1-10 of 31st December last; this girl had been put in the Kenora R.C. Indian School, but was then in Hospital, and on her discharge was handed over to her mother, who is now married to John Redsky of Shoal Lake Band No. 40. This apparently did not take her away, however she was placed in the Cecilia Jeffrey Presbyterian School on March 20th, without my knowledge, and today the Principal has handed me the enclosed application for her admission.

The mother Mrs John Redsky, late Mrs Albert Ochis, (nee Greta Michaud) has three children by the late Albert Ochis, and since she has married John Redsky apparently wishes to get rid of her children. One of the children she has left with a woman from Big Island Band, and the two older ones Eliza and Elvin are now at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, although no approval has been given for their admission.

The following are the children, Eliza born 23rd May 1931, Elvin born 9th Jan., 1933, and Louise born 20th March 1935.

I hesitate to make any recommendation in view of your letter of 31st Dec last, and would like to get your instructions.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 19, 1937.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the application which you have received for the admission of Elisa Oshie to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. In view of her age, the Department is not prepared to approve her admission to any Indian residential school at the present time and you should arrange to have the mother take charge of her.

With reference to the March quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, you may inform the Principal that the admission of Dolly Cameron is approved.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division Sub Division Detachment
Province Province

Kenora, Ont.

Date April 5th, 1937

File References

Res Alex McGEALD et al - Truant Indian Children - Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora, Ont.

Headquarters

1. At about 7:00 p.m. this date, Mr. L.W. Ryers, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School at Kenora reported that the following boys had left his school on this date: Alex McGEALD, Donald McGEALD, Pierre TUMAY & Petronne H. A. Accordingly, on same evening and following day inquiries were made at Kenora and Indian houses and Indians were questioned with a view to ascertaining in what direction these boys were travelling. Arrangement was made with an Indian proceeding to Shetfish Bay, Ont., a point which lay in line of route to boys' houses, to make enquiries and report any information by wire.

Sub Division

2. In the a.m. this date, Mr. Ryers advised that he was in receipt of advice from Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector for Dept. of Indian Affairs at Winnipeg to effect that these boys were being held in detention at Winnipeg. Capt. F. Edwards, Indian Agent here, was then consulted and by arrangement Mr. Ryers proceeded to Winnipeg, this date, and brought boys back to Kenora in the p.m. of April 3rd.

Detachment

3. In view of above file is being closed here.

P.C.R.

Kenora first.

Ottawa, May 28, 1937.

Dear Mrs. McFarrell:

Your letter of May 20th, addressed to Dr. McGill, who is absent from the city, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I may state that we are deeply interested in training a limited number of Indian boys and girls for service amongst their own people. This service can be rendered at Indian day or residential schools or in social service work under the direction of the churches. Our experience has taught us that the Indians need more perhaps than they need anything else, leadership, guidance and direction in their local enterprises.

The amount of money at our disposal for assistance to ex-pupils is very small. I shall be glad, however, to have the names of the two graduates to whom you refer in your communication. You might, in addition to this, let me have a brief summary of the course you have in mind and the time required to complete it. If you do this I shall be glad to recommend a grant to assist these girls to proceed with the course.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mrs. D. T. L. McFarrell,
Women's Missionary Society,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
St. Andrew's Manse,
Niagara-on-the-Lake,
Ontario.
Ottawa, June 18, 1937.

Dear Mrs. McKerroll:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, in which you supply additional information in respect to Mary Green and Mary Begg, graduates of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

The records here indicate that Mary Begg entered the school in 1921 and was 9 years old at that time. May I suggest that you consider the advisability of giving this girl a 2 year practical course, with emphasis on home-making. In view of her age and the fact that she has been for years in an educational institution, I do not think it would be at all wise to ask this girl to proceed with a 4 year course.

Mary Green was born on November 10, 1919, and I can see no serious objection to this girl proceeding with the 4 year course you have outlined, provided she is interested in her studies and makes a good showing the first year.

I regret to state that the appropriation at our disposal for assistance of this kind is very limited. The Department, however, will allow $165.00 per annum for each girl, on the understanding, of course, that we shall receive a report of their progress from year to year.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Heay,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mrs. D.T.L. McKerroll,
Women's Missionary Society,
Presbyterian Church,
Niagara-on-the-Lake,
Ontario.

KENORA, ONT., Sept. 23rd, 1937.

Hon. R.A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re Hugh McDonald Family.

Dear Sir,

I wish to call your attention to what I consider a very special case and I shall very much appreciate your worthy consideration of same.

In 1936 three children of the above family were sent to our school and the necessary application forms were forwarded to the Department for approval. Their admission was refused on the grounds that the father was not a treaty Indian.

Being late in the Fall and owing to the condition of the lake I was unable to have these children returned to their home until the following Spring. We did not receive any assistance from the Dept. for the support of these and when I sent them home I told them they were not to return after the Summer holidays.

When school opened the children returned and I did not get in touch with the parents as the children came on a boat enroute from Barrow, Minn.

Mrs. McDonald is an Indian but the father is White. They have no school available and are very anxious to have their children learn to read and write. They live as Indians on Biggy Island which is situated approximately 70 miles from Kenora and most of their associations are with the Indians.

We have the accommodation for these children and it seems a pity that they have no opportunity for receiving any education. The oldest boy has been sent to a Reformatory and will be a government charge for at least two years and if we could have these children for a few years it should be a great help to them.

A few years ago a circular letter was issued by the Dept. stating that Half-breed children living as Indians would be admitted to Residential schools if there were sufficient accommodation.

We have the accommodation and I would like to see these children have this privilege afforded them.

Thanking you in anticipation of your worthy consideration of the above,

I remain,

Yours obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa
October 5, 1937.

Dear Sirs-

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Oseilina Jeffrey Residential School, in which he states that the McDonald children have returned to the school after the summer holidays.

In connection with these children, I would refer you to your letter of October 14, 1936, and official letter of October 14, 1936, filed in my office. We are therefore not prepared to admit these children as grant earning pupils to the Oseilina Jeffrey School.

If the McDonald family is residing in Canada, the attention of the Provincial authorities should be directed to these children as their education is a Provincial responsibility.

If, however, the family is residing in the United States, action by this Department is not required.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hony,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir;

On receipt of the Quarterly Returns of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School we drew the attention of the Principal to the fact that a number of the children had reached the age limit of 16, and that no authority had been asked for the retention of these pupils in school; we have now received a letter from the Principal a copy of which is inclosed.

We will be glad if approval can be given to the discharge asked for, and permission given to keep the others in school as requested.

He Andrew Ketchen pupil 114. This boy was 16 in April 20th last but informed the Principal a short time ago that he would be returning to school, but it now looks as if he had changed his mind and does not wish to return. He is still about.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Reference the Superintendent of Welfare and Training's letter #129-3-10 of 6th instant re returning half breed children to their homes from the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

The children referred to (McDonald) were brought to this office by the Principal of the school whilst I was on vacation in England, and taken by him to the school. The application forms were later sent in but admission to the school as grant earning pupils was not approved, rightly so, as they were not Treaty Indians.

They had been refused admission by me some years ago; however the Principal admitted them.

He was informed on several occasions their admission was noted, and the Principal asked to return them to their homes, as instructed by the Department, but he kept them at the school, as could easily have found out where they lived, and in fact knew the place, but did not return them.

I enclose copy of letter written the Principal on the 13th instant, and his reply thereto, which appears rather unsatisfactory, as I consider my letter was quite polite and in good taste. I asked him to communicate his requests to the Department so that we could keep informed and clear up small matters that often can be done without referring them to Ottawa.

The Principal is very touchy, and does not like to receive instructions from me, but expects to get them direct from Ottawa; in fact he appears to think this office should not give him any instructions whatever.

The Principal admitted the children without authority, did not return them to their parents when officially requested, and now thinks the department should pay for returning them. The cost would not be very much, but in any case is, I think, a school responsibility.

I shall be glad to receive further instructions,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Agent
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find September quarterly returns for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

You will notice a large number of children did not return to school after the holidays. However most of them are now back, only three or four still absent, but these are being traced up, and will be returned as located.

We always have difficulty in getting children back to this school, and have suggested on several occasions to the Principal that if he would keep the children who do not return on time, at the school, and give them no holidays the following summer, the matter would soon be cleared up and I do not think we would have the same trouble again, but he apparently does not want to do this.

Another thing he went for his holidays immediately after the school re-opened, and of course was not at the school to see the children returned.

Yours faithfully,

Frank Edwards

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 21, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of October 15th with reference to the MacDonald children.

Please inform the Principal that the Department is not prepared to pay the transportation of these children to their home. I might point out that as these children are not wards of this Department, we would not be justified in providing their transportation from funds voted for Indian educational purposes.

It is hoped that these children will be sent home from the Cecilia Jeffrey School immediately on receipt of this letter.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Sept. of Welfare & Training.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.
Ottawa, October 21, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant enclosing the September quarter returns of the Cecelia Jeffrey Residential School, I am writing the Secretary of the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church of Canada, pointing out to her the importance of having the Principal and all members of the staff of the Cecelia Jeffrey Residential School on duty at the time the pupils return from holidays each year.

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

When you were in my office recently you brought to my attention the question of the education of the children of Hugh Macdonald.

In a letter of October 6, 1936, the Indian Agent at Kenora, Mr. Frank Edwards, explained that while he was abroad, Donald, Sanford and Alex Macdonald had been admitted to the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School. Hugh Macdonald, the father of these children, is a white man. The children there are have no Indian status and are not wards of this Department.

On October 14, 1936 the Department advised the Agent that, for the above mentioned reason, the admission of these people to the school could not be approved, and that if they were in the school at the time they should be returned to their home.

The circumstances are regrettable but it is clear that the care of these children is not the responsibility of this Department and would not be a proper charge against our appropriation for Indian education.

I am returning your memorandum herewith.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Hugh D. McKinnon, Esq., B.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Philip Boyd, #877 of the Fort Alexander Band, was in to see me a few days ago and informed me he had two boys who should be at the Elkhorn School, but that he did not wish to send them back there, as he was not satisfied with the school treatment of his boys, by not letting them have holidays, he wished to put them in the Cecilia Jeffrey School at Kenora.

I informed him the reason was probably because he was a widower, living with someone else's wife, and there was no place for the children to stay.

He asked me to write the Agent at Selkirk, which I did, and Agent Anderson replied that you please try and get Philip's boys in the school at Kenora so that there to be the only place where he is satisfied for them to go. In regard to them not having holidays, I previously informed the Principal at Elkhorn not to allow these children to go home as they had no place to go at Fort Alexander that was suitable.

I therefore enclose application for the admission of Joe to the Cecilia Jeffrey School as a transfer from Elkhorn school, and would suggest the oldest boy Charley be discharged, as he is now 16, according to his father, and is old enough to be with his father and assist him in trapping.

If you approve, please inform me, and let the Principal of the Elkhorn school know.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

At 7:00 p.m., above date the writer left Kenora, Ont., by hired auto for the purpose of locating Winnie Lahey, Elizabeth Martin, Mary Kelly, and Winnie Lahey reported as having run away from the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School on January 1st at Kenora Indian School searched vicinity without success and proceeded 2 miles on the main Kenora road without finding the above mentioned Indian girls. As it was thought possible that the girls had come to the Red Portage Indian Reserve patrol proceeded there and found Winnie Lahey and Elizabeth Martin in the Indian House at that point. These two girls informed writer that the other two girls had gone on to the First Portage and patrol proceeded there and searched the Indian shacks and located Mary Kelly and Winnie Lahey.

The four truants were then returned to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School and turned over to the Principal. Patrol returned to Detachment at 10:30 p.m.

Hired auto - 77.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from the R.C.M.P. with reference to four girls who truanted from the Anglican Jeffrey Indian Residential School on January 6th. I am pleased to note that the police were successful in locating these girls about two hours after they had left the school.

I would appreciate if you would discuss this matter with the Principal and ascertain what reason the girls gave for truancing. As you know, truancing in winter time might have very serious results to those concerned, and it is hoped that, if their action was caused by some local condition in the school, prompt steps have been taken to remedy it.

Yours truly,

R.A. Ross,
Dept. of Welfare & Training.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
KENORA, ONT. Jan. 26th, 1938

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re Four Girls Who Ran Away,
Mary Kelly
Winnie Sandy
Winnie Autakejick
Elizabeth Martin

I wish to state for your information that I have closely questioned each of the above girls and the following is the information they have given me.

I examined each one when alone and all state that Mary Kelly and Winnie Sandy planned the escape. Mary Kelly and Winnie Sandy admit this.

Upon enquiring why, Mary Kelly said the girls of the school were always bothering her. This she said was her only reason. She is one of the biggest girls in the school.

Winnie Sandy stated she went because she did not want Mary Kelly to go alone. She said she had no other reason.

Winnie Autakejick stated she did not want to stay in school in school all Winter. She said her teacher told her she never knew her memorizing which she admitted was the truth. She also stated the teacher did not punish her.

Elizabeth Martin stated she went because the others were going and she wanted to go too. She also stated that she had received no punishment within at least two weeks previous.

These are the first girls we have had run away from the school within three years, a record which few schools have. We have had very few pupils who have run away during the past year and I have talked with a number of Principals and I am convinced that we have as few as any of the schools.

The Staff is interested in the children's welfare and are kind to the children and I cannot see any valid excuse for their running away—a wild impulse to be free.

Hoping this is the information you require,

I remain,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have received the enclosed accounts from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. J. W. Stone Company $30.00
Harry Foster $25.00

These accounts are for collecting and returning pupils to school after the summer vacation.

The Department often authorizes an amount for this purpose, but did not do so for this school last summer.

Some years ago we turned over to the School, without cost, the launch they had whilst the school was at Shoal Lake, for the purpose of taking the children out on the Lake and for other purposes.

This launch, whilst still owned by the School is now being used by Harry Foster for the purpose of taking passengers out on the Lake, and for freighting, and I am unofficially informed, he pays the Principal of the School some amount for the use of the launch. The Principal once informed me that Foster had to give him the use of the boat when he required it for any purpose.

On account of complaints I had received from the other livery outfits in town, which were reported to Ottawa, the boat was transferred to the school, and I admit that if Foster did not have the boat he would have probably been on relief, but that does not appear to me to be any reason why he should be allowed to continue using it for returning children to the school from points on the Lake, when the school have a launch, given them for this purpose.

I do not wish this letter to be taken as a complaint on my part, but is only written to ascertain the wishes of the Department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa
March 6, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant in connection with the account submitted to you by the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School for returning children to the school after the summer vacation of 1937.

As the Department supplied a launch to this school for the transportation of pupils, and it is presumed that this launch is in good condition, there appears no reason why we should pay outsiders for transporting the children to and from the school. Under the circumstances we are not prepared to favourably consider payment of the account submitted by the Principal.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoy,
Dept. of Welfare & Training.
