Dear Sir,

I have received the following telegram from Head Man Albert Kent of the Inalton Band,
Captain Frank Edwards, Kemps, Ontario.

"Ted Cameron wants his daughter Mary to come home tomorrow
as her mother may die at any time please arrange."

Albert Kent

The girl referred to is Dolly Cameron, pupil
#218 at the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

This child entered the school only on the 25th
March, 1937, at the age of 11 years and 6 months, as the
father would not send her before.

On phoning Doctor Ferguson he considered the child
should go home although the mother is probably dying of
tuberculosis, he said there was no danger if she only stayed
a few days, but owing to the difficulty we had in getting
the child to school, and the expense involved in sending
her to see her mother, and the probability of not being
able to get the child back to school, and also the Principal
does not consider it well to start a precedent by permitting
the child to leave, we refused permission, and wired the
Councillor as follows:- "Councilor Albert Kent, Kinaki, Ont.
Sorry cannot allow Cameron girl to leave school without
permission from Ottawa, but am writing them tonight."

I shall be glad to know what you consider should
be done in this or similar cases, as if we let one go, we
would have many others who would want their children, when
one of the family are ill, although in this case I believe
the woman is likely to pass away very soon.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
May 7, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant with reference to the death of the mother of Dolly Cameron, No. 0816, Cecilia Jeffrey School.

It is extremely difficult for the Department to make a regulation that would cover all such cases, each of them has to be dealt with on its own merits.

I am inclined to feel that in the event of the death of a near relative of a pupil it would be advisable, on the part of the Principal, to make every effort to meet the wishes of the relatives. Otherwise, the Indians are almost certain to view the school with disfavour and, as a result, recruiting difficulties will be increased.

It is understood, of course, that we do not recommend allowing children home simply when some member of the family is ill but it is always possible to make reports regarding the seriousness of the illness and in the event of death or likelihood of it I believe that the Principal should, as pointed out above, make a real effort to allow the child to go home for a short time.

Yours truly,

F. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

File References

Re: Nella PRINCE - et al - Truante, Cecilia Jeffrey
Indian School, Kenora, Ont.

At 4:45 P.M., K. Halderson, Supervisor, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora, Ontario informed writer that about 1:00 P.M. above date, two small Indian children Nella PRINCE and Maggie WILLIAMS had run away from the school and he had trailed them into Kenora. These girls had informed other children they were going to try to get back to the Bimoroc Indian Reserve, Janowiec, Ont., to their parents.

Writer left detachment at 5:05 P.M. and checked places around Kenora where these children often have been found and then proceeded to the Indian House and First Nations Indian Reserve in the hope of finding the above mentioned girls before they started for Bimoroc. No trace of them was found around Kenora. I then patrolled to Mile 10 Mt. Frances Highway where the Aufferman Camp, etc., have a camp and where I learned that no one had seen any Indian children on the highway. Patrol then returned to Kenora.

At 8:15 P.M., K. Halderson again telephoned writer that the girls had been seen that evening around a Mr. Kersten's farm in Jeffery District. Writer then patrolled to the above mentioned farm and enquiries there revealed that the girls had passed through the farm several hours before and had continued on towards Kenora. Patrol returned to Kenora and continued the search in Kenora.

At 9:00 P.M., Capt. Hodges, Kenora Town Police informed writer that he had picked the girls up in Kenora and was holding them at the Town Police Station. Writer then escorted them to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School and turned them over to the supervisor. Patrol returned to detachment.

The Officer Commanding
Winnipeg Sub-Division
O.C. "D" Division,
R.C.M.P., Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter 129-3-10 of 20th ult., re re-admission of pupil 70178 Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, Iroquois Crew.

This girl did not return to the School after the holidays in 1936 and the Department did not consider it necessary to return her to the School.

During Annuity Payments this year we were informed that the Principal had received several letters from the girl that she was unhappy at home and being neglected and asking to return to the school.

Under the circumstances the Principal agreed to this and the girl came back. She did not wish to return to her people for the holidays this year and is still at the school, and I would recommend her re-admission as a grant earning pupil.

The Chief and Councillor have signed papers recommending her for admission to the Band, and as soon as these are completed, I will send them on with a recommendation by myself.

I shall be glad to hear if approval can be given to her re-admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of Sept. 30th re transportation of pupils by boat I wish to state that we do considerable recruiting with the school boat but under the regulations of the Marine Dept. we must have a licensed captain when we carry any passengers. This means an outlay of $25 per hr.

We also have to provide gas and oil and these raise other expenses as well.

There are also many cases where the children can not return by boat, e.g., those who live where you suggested I pay the taxi for Jim Major returning from Crow Dick Lake at a cost of $14.00. Such cases can not be taken care of by boat.

When I make a charge for the boat I charge only the actual outlay.

I do not understand that though all other schools in your agency have been provided with a boat and expenses for the upkeep and in our case we were not asked for any allowance for upkeep during the past four years, other schools are allowed a grant for returning children to the school while our request is questioned. Last year's request was refused. Last year I brought in around expense 11 children for St. Mary's school a distance of 150 miles for the round trip. This year we have brought in a number of children for the same school at our expense.

I therefore feel our making a request to cover all our returning expenses but I feel it is reasonable to expect some return for our expenses.

If the Dept. would allow us $100 each year for returning children to school we could finance more economically as we could arrange in advance to have them come in larger groups and not two or three coming by taxi and other means of transportation.

Thanking you for your attention to the above,

I remain very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Reference your letter #129-6-10 of 27th September re transportation of pupils to Indian Schools.

With particular reference to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, I took up the last part of your letter with the Principal and he has written a reply copy of which is enclosed as he made out the letter in duplicate.

In my opinion very little recruiting is done with the boat, but sometimes it is used in September to bring children from the lake back to school, but under the present regulations a licensed Captain should be got for the boat when used for this purpose, and the Principal has not been using the boat for this purpose lately.

The boat is still in operation and is used daily; I understand it is rented out to Mr. Harry Foster, and he takes tourists out and transports freight to mining properties, and I think he must have a Captains licence, or it is not likely he would be allowed to operate the way he does.

I believe he pays the school some consideration for the use of the boat, and this matter was reported to the Department some time ago, when we owned the boat, but on account of complaints that the boat was being used for other than school purposes the Department turned it over to the school.

We have paid nothing for upkeep of boats belonging to other schools, except that we did purchase a new engine for the Sioux Lookout School a few years ago.

I question if the school pays anything like $10.00 a year for returning children to this school.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Agent
Ottawa,
October 24, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with reference to transportation of pupils to and from the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

It has been decided to allow an amount not exceeding $100.00 a year for transportation of children to and from the school other than by the school boat. Payment of this amount will be made on receipt from you of properly certified accounts.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

F. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

KENORA, ONT. November 26th, 1936.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am forwarding Applications for Admission for two children, viz., Donald Allan Churchill and Harvey Frank Churchill.

These children are both under the usual age for admission but it is a very special case and I feel deserving of consideration.

The father was sent to a Sanitorium and the mother has three other children to take care of, the youngest being a baby of about six months.

The mother has never lived on a reserve being brought to school as a neglected child when quite young. She cannot possibly provide for her family. The school has been taking care of them since the father was sent away.

By being relieved of the care of the two older ones she would have a better chance to take care of the younger ones but she will also require assistance from some other source.

Hoping these applications will receive favourable consideration,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Re Former Pupil, Norbert Kelly #115.

The above noted pupil received his discharge in the month of November 1935.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find copy of a letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School re former pupil #115 Norbert Kelly.

This pupil after discharge went trapping with his father and uncle; they persuaded him to go with them into the game sanctuary and traps. He was shortly caught by the game warden; however, they sold some fur in Kenora and the boy with the money bought some of the skins, and sold them to another fur buyer. He eventually confessed and was brought up before the police magistrate yesterday, and sentenced to 6 months imprisonment, but the sentence was suspended providing the boy returned to the school, in the care of the principal.

Both the Mounted Police and the Principal think this is the best solution, and have great faith in the boy and believe he will turn out a good man after this, and as the boy is anxious to continue his studies, and the Principal says he was a very good student, I would recommend that he be accepted as a grant earning pupil for another twelve months, providing he behaves himself.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
January 17, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 10th instant the Department approves the re-admission of Norbert Kelly, No. 115, to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school. It is understood that he will remain there for another 18 months provided his conduct is good.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

F. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division Sub-Division Detachment
Province Winnipeg Kenora, Ontario
Date Jan. 19th, 1939

File Reference

Re: Maria GOPENACH - et al -
Truants from Cecilia Jeffrey Ind. School,
Kenora, Ontario.

At 12:16 A.M. above date, Z.F. Myers, Principal
of the above mentioned School called this Detachment
and informed the writer that three young Indian girls,
namely Maria Gopenach, Ada Cook and Maggie Williams,
pupils of the School, had left the School about 9:00 P.M.
that night and had not returned.

At 12:00 A.M. above date, acting on instructions
from H.C.C. I/C Detachment, I patrolled by private auto
to the Indian House and Rat Portage Indian Reserve and
conducted a thorough examination of the Reserve but
failed to locate the girls. It was suggested that they
may have gone down to the Bare Point Reserve but a
search of this Reserve also proved futile.

Patrol returned to Detachment at 3:00 P.M. and
learned that the girls had returned to the School of
their own accord shortly before.

CONCLUDED.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH
Kenora, Ontario
6th April, 1939.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find application for admission of Alexander Lund, #113 Imlington Band to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

This child is only 5 years and three months old now. His mother's widow came to Imlington the other day and brought this child with her. She had an illegitimate girl born to her on the 15th March, and as this child was neglected we got the Principal of the school to accept him, subject to the approval of the Department.

This was cheaper than putting the child in the Hospital with his mother and we had no one else to take care of him; the child was very ragged and dirty, poorly clothed, and lousy.

I did what was advisable under the circumstances and will be glad to receive approval for our file.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 13, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 6th instant the Department approves the admission of Alexander Land to the Cecilia Jeffrey residential school.

Yours truly,

April 20, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant enclosing the March quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey residential school.

In official letter of November 8, 1938, the discharge of Norbert Kelly, No. 115, was approved. The December quarter return showed that he had been discharged from the school on November 8, 1938.

In checking the March quarter return of the school it is found that this boy's name is on the return and that grant is requested for the full quarter.

No application has been received for his re-admission to the school and I should, therefore, appreciate your advising me if he is in the school at the present time and why he was returned without our authority.

You may inform the Principal that the discharge of the following pupils is approved:

- No. 135 George Morriseau
- No. 166 Charlie Mongoose
- No. 170 Joe John
- No. 180 Hector Martin
- No. 0175 Binnie Antakojick

Yours truly,

F. Edwards, K.S.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Chief, Training Division.
Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School has informed us that he does not seem to have received payment of $74.25 his account for bringing in children to his school.

This account was sent you under Voucher #9431 early in March, and we will be obliged if you investigate this matter and advise us so we can reply to The Principal.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Department of Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir:

Replying to Department letter 129-3-10 of 25th inst.

We have notified the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School of the pupils to be discharged.

Regarding Gerald Redsky Rupin, he informed me a short time ago he did not wish to return to the school but he was anxious to keep up his work in Art.

I will endeavour to see him and his father before the end of the holidays and will write you what they wish to do.

Re. Mavis Kopineese. This girl's name on the pay list is Mary or Maria Copineese also known as Mavis Na wa Kejick #25 North West Angle Band #37 and number 0121 on the school register.

She was born in 1922 and is therefore 17 now, the school registrar shows her as 18.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

12th September, 1939.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find application for admission of the following children to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School:
Jennie, Mary, Johnson and Annie Peters, children of Charlie Peters #87 Lac des Mille Lacs Band.

I had spoken to Charlie about bringing these children to school and he arrived with them on the 10th instant.

We had previously understood that this family were Roman Catholics, but as Charlie's father Fred Peters #45 is a Catholic, but Fred informs me he is not a Protestant or a Catholic, and neither he nor his wife nor any of his children have ever been baptized, and that he wished to put his children into the Cecilia Jeffrey Presbyterian School, we therefore agreed to his request, and would like to get your official approval.

All the children have been passed by the Medical Officer.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have received a letter from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School saying Kathleen Gardner pupil 10155 has successfully completed her first year in High School and is anxious to continue for another year. He says she is a very bright pupil, and has returned, and her father would like her to continue her studies. She has been under consideration by the Women's Missionary Society for special training and he would like to keep her on at the school for at least another year.

She was born in 1922, and is therefore 17 years old.

Her father is an Ex-Chief of the Wabigoon Band and a good type of Indian.

I would recommend the request be approved.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent.
Kenora, Ontario,
27th September, 1939.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School informs me that Mavis Copeman (or Marie Nawakajjak) pupil f0121, and Arnold Thomas, pupil 106, are 16 years of age and both have passed the entrance examination to High School, and are anxious to take additional education and wish to be allowed to continue in school for another year. The parents of both children are dead and they have no permanent home.

I wish the Department to authorize their readmission for another year as grant earning pupils.

During the investigation for immorality at this school a short time ago, Davis admitted intercourse with boys, but not at the school. Arnold admitted intercourse at the school.

I have looked up the ages of these pupils and find Mavis was born sometime in 1922 and Arnold on 16th July, 1922.

Under the circumstances it might probably be advisable to agree to the request, and allow them to stay providing they will give an undertaking to behave themselves and providing the Principal will give strict supervision to them.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

re Robert Kent, #179 Islington Band,
pupil #361 Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School.

The father of the above named pupil has asked for his discharge from school, as he is now 16 years old.

The boy with his father was transferred from #191 Fort Alexander Band to the Islington Band under authority of Department letter 62-129 of 27th April, 1925, and the date of birth then given me being the 9th August, 1925, (1924)

However I have a note from Canon Sanderson that the boy was born the 17th August, 1923, and baptized Anglican on the 26th August, 1923; the latter also informs me he was paid annuity by the Indian Agent for Fort Alexander Band in 1924 for this boy therefore does not seem to be any reason to doubt the fact that he is 18.

Under the circumstances, I would therefore recommend the boy be discharged to assist his father, although Mr Byers the Principal of the school does not think he should be discharged and seemed quite annoyed when I suggested the matter to him, as he thought he should be the one to say who should be discharged and not the parents of the boy or the Department.

Mr Byers claimed he assisted the father last winter with relief, but no request was received from the father to us, and I cannot see why the father of the boy cannot make a living as he is only 41 and has a young wife, and no no children at home with him. I shall be glad to receive your instructions.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
October 6, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letters of the 22nd and 29th ultimo with reference to certain pupils of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school. In view of the evidence received at the investigation held at the Cecilia Jeffrey school about two months ago the Department considers that it is undesirable at the present time to retain in the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school pupils who are over 16 years of age. Under these circumstances you may inform the Principal that the following pupils should be discharged at once:

Robert Kent No. 179
Mavis Copenace No. 0181
Arnold Penace No. 105
Kathleen Gardner No. 0155

Yours truly,

H. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Jr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Toronto, Ont.

Date: Oct. 25th, 1939
Time of day: 3 P.M.

A. J. Ferguson M.D.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find a number of applications for admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School.

A number of the applications are in order, but several require attention and approval of the Department if thought advisable.

Victor Pithenese, #70 Eagle Lake Band.
The father of this child attended the Cecilia Jeffrey Presbyterian School, but his wife, the mother of this girl, attended the Enora R. C. School. Bernard Kaplan, her brother, to this girl, by the same mother, a different father, is at present a pupil in the Catholic School. The mother died in 1934 and the father married Indian fashion, another woman who went to the Leintzah Indian Residential School.

The application is not signed by the father, but attached to the application is an affidavit duly sworn that the child is at present being educated at the Cecilia Jeffrey School and he wishes her education finished there. No permission has been given by me for the admission of this child and I informed the principal when I heard the child was there, there might be some difficulties, and the child might have to be sent to the Catholic School.

Birdie Cantin, #65 Wabigoon Band.
Peter Cantin the father of this child is a Roman Catholic, but I understand the mother and children have not been baptized. The Principal of the Presbyterian School claims the father informed him he had no religion, but according to my records he is a Roman Catholic. Attached is a declaration that the father wished the child educated in the Cecilia Jeffrey Presbyterian School.

Alex Morrisseau, Non Treaty.
William Morrisseau, Non Treaty.
Neither of the above children are in Treaty; the father is a half breed and the mother is #77 Shoal Lake Band #40. They do not live on a Reserve, but are round with the Indians a great deal. A brother Donald, was a pupil at this school but got into trouble and was discharged lately.

The above applications have not been signed by me, as I should like to get your ruling.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
halfbreeds to Indian residential schools.

As pointed out above all four children should be returned to their parents and their names should not appear on the quarterly returns.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoss,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
October 13, 1939.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant you may inform the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey residential school that the admission of the following children is approved:

Jack Chena Harvey Redsky
Beta Blackhawk James Robert
Frank Gardner Hobin Robert
Ian Redsky Alfred John

Careful consideration has been given to the information contained in your letter regarding the under-mentioned four children:

Victoria Lithness Alex Morriseau
Birdie Custin William Morriseau

These children should not have been accepted in the school by the Principal until all the facts had been laid before the Department and our decision given.

The eligibility of the first two mentioned children is doubtful on religious grounds and consequently they should be returned to their parents immediately as the Department is not prepared to consider their admission to any Indian residential school at the present time.

The two Morriseau boys are not eligible for admission under the ruling regarding the admission of

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa,
October 28, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The attached letter has just been received. Please let me have a report regarding its contents.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

KENORA, ONT., October 10th, 1939

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I wish to state for your information that this child is only four years of age, but her father was drowned a few years ago, and the mother has since remarried. Since the mother remarried the home life for this child has been very unpleasant, as the parents do not agree, and the step-father does not take very kindly to the child.

I consider it is much in the best interests of the child for her to be placed in the School where she can receive attention.

I shall appreciate your securing authority from the Department for her admission to the School as a grant earning pupil.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal

B/M

Recommended
Frank Edwards
Indian Agent

Ottawa,
October 27, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Una Wastence, No. 0206,
Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

The name of the above girl was shown on the return for the quarter ended June 30, 1939, but no grant was requested for her, nor had any grant been requested for her as far back as September, 1938.

On the second page of the girls' sheet covering the return for the quarter ended September 30, 1939, grant is requested for this girl for 95 days.

On the last page of the girls' sheet of the September return her name is shown again and grant is requested for 19 days. Opposite this entry it is stated that she entered the school on October 12, 1939 even though she did enter the school on October 12 the school would not be entitled to any grant for her for the quarter ended September 30, 1939.

In view of the fact that no grant was requested for this girl for over a year it is presumed that she was absent from the school either on account of illness or truancy. Please see the Principal and ascertain the exact date on which this girl returned to the Cecilia Jeffrey school. If the reimbursement of the September quarter grant is being withheld. Consequently it would be appreciated if you would reply to this letter at the earliest possible date.

Yours truly,

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Philip Phalen,
Chief, Training Division.
KENORA, ONT., October 17th, 1949

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Re: Pupil #258, Birdie Charlie Cantin,
Wabigoon Band.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that this child was sent to the School in company with other children from the same reserve, and none of his people accompanied him. The only thing for me to do was to take the child in charge, and to await the decision of the Department as to whether or not he would be admitted as a pupil. The application forms were completed from your office, and I thought that I was only following the usual custom of keeping the boy in School until definite arrangements were made.

I got in touch with the boy's father, and he very emphatically informed me that he was not a Catholic, that he was just of the Indian belief, and that he did not wish his boy educated in the Roman Catholic School. Further the father made an affidavit to the effect that he wanted his boy educated in the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

It has been the custom of the Department, as a rule, to authorize the admission of pupils to any School when the application was accompanied by an affidavit. This has been done in this case, and as the father is very desirous of having his boy educated in this school, it seems reasonable to expect that his application should be approved.

As our quarterly returns had already been completed and forwarded to your office, I was not in a position to make the alterations in them. Hoping this will meet with the approval of the Department, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

Cecilia Jeffrey School
PRESBYTERIAN

E W BYERS
PRINCIPAL

KENORA, ONT. October 17th, 1939

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Re: Pupil #0536, Victoria Pichenenam,
Eagle Lake Band.

Dear Sir:

I wish to state for your information that the above noted pupil came to the School by train, in company with one of the Gardner children. It was understood that the girl be taken in charge, and none of her people had accompanied her, and it has been the usual custom when new pupils arrive at the School, that we take them in charge until such time as their admission to the School has been dealt with by the Department.

I later got in touch with the father of this child, and he informed me that he had attended the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and that he was Protestant, that his child had been brought up under the care of his grandmother who was also Protestant, and he insisted that his child be brought up in the Protestant School. I might further add that the father sent instructions through me to Canon Henderson of the Anglican Church to baptize his child.

I have been informed that the mother had been Catholic, but that the mother died when the child was born, and all subsequent training of the child has been in the Protestant faith. It seemed to me a very reasonable request on the part of the father that his child should be educated in a Protestant Institution.

The father has also made an affidavit to the effect that he wishes his child educated in the Cecilia Jeffrey School. In view of all this information I hope the Department will authorize her admission to the School.
As our quarterly returns had already been completed and forwarded to your office, I was not in a position to make the alterations in them. Hoping this meets with the approval of the Department, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
Kenora, Ontario,
October 19th, 1939

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find Quarterly Returns,
for the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, I
would refer you to Departmental letter 129-3-10
of 15th inst., with particular reference to
Victoria Pitchener.

I enclose letter received from the Principal
and saw the girl's father at Eagle River yesterday
17th, and he informed me he did not mind what school
Victoria went to.

I would also refer you to my letter of 6th.
inst re this case and don't think it matters which
school the child goes to, but as she has a half brother
at the Kenora R.C. School, there might be difficulties.

The Father informs me he is not a Protestant,
but of aboriginal belief.

In view of the Principal's letter I would be glad to
receive further instructions as I feel confident the child
was never brought up in the Protestant faith.

Re. Birdie Cantin, I saw the Chief and Councilor
of the Wahigoch Band yesterday afternoon 17th, but the Father
of this child was not there.

However the Indians informed me that Cantin
was never baptized although he did previously report to me
that he was Catholic.

I do not think it makes much difference which school
the child goes to, but I enclose letter from the Principal.

I requested the Principal to omit the names of the
children from his Quarterly Returns, but you will note he
says the returns were complete and he was not in a position
to make any alteration in them. I have therefore made the
necessary alterations in red ink.
When discussing the matter with the Principal he intimated that the Catholic Schools were getting much better treatment from the Department than the Protestant.

I assured him this was not so but that they were all getting equal treatment.

Mr. Byers seems to think that anything he does as Principal, should be approved and is very sensitive to any instructions I pass on to him.

I enclose Voucher in favour of Miss Alice Bell for Nursing services at the Cecilia Jeffrey School from September 30th to October 8th, 9 days at $5.00 making a total of $45.00

I took this matter up with the Principal and he informed me that Dr. Ferguson authorized this expenditure, and when I asked why he informed me that the nurses duties had been very heavy as a lot of the children had returned from vacation with itch and scabies and then she contracted the flu and had had to go to bed. I told him I considered it should have been the School's duty to provide a nurse when the regular one could not carry on but promised him I would forward the account for your consideration.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

P.S. I have made no alterations in the quarterly returns preferring these corrections to be made in Ottawa. Several applications have been received but returned to the principal as not signed by the parents. You will notice several applications are dated after the child was admitted to the school.
Dear sir,

Capt. F. Edwards, he asks me again, that my boy, to go school, and I am not willing to go, that boy four more months he'll be 14 years old, and he work for us, and we are getting old, both of us. I am 57 years old, my wife 62, near same age, that's why I don't let that boy go. Capt. Edwards, he said to me, if you don't let that boy go, I'll send Policeman to get you and put you in jail. I wish you wrote to him not to do it.

Yours truly,

Councillor Mark Shalagway
Dinowrie Ont.
Kenora, Ontario,
31st October, 1939

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Replying to Departmental letter # 128-3-10 of 25th instant enclosing letter from Mark Shabaquay, #65 Wabigoon Band, returned herewith.

This Indian is a Councillor of the Wabigoon Band. He has three sons living one 19 last June, one 16 last September and one Jack 13 last March.

Mark has continuously refused to send his boys to school, and we consider it absolutely essential that he should be forced to send the youngest for at least a short time until he is 16, as the Indians refuse to send their children when their Councillor will not send him.

Mark has promised on numerous occasions to send this boy, and when I saw him on the 17th instant, he promised me he would send the boy to the White Bay school at Dinorwic and if they would not take him there he would send him to the Kenora School.

It would have been almost impossible for the boy to attend the white day school daily owing to the distance from the reserve, and the Secretary Treasurer of that school informs me they will not take Treaty Indians as we have schools for them unless the Indians are living in the Village and paying rent.

Under the circumstances I recommend that we send the Police for this boy unless Mark sends the boy himself otherwise we shall have trouble in making the other Indians send their children to school when of age.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 2, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 24th ultimo regarding Martha Fine has been brought to my attention.

In view of the information contained in your letter the Department approves her returning to the Cecilia Jeffrey school. You should point out to the Principal, of course, that the girl should continue her afternoon rest of at least one to two hours daily throughout the coming winter.

Provided her physical condition remains satisfactory and that she is not a menace to the health of the other pupils in the school the Department has no objection to her remaining at Cecilia Jeffrey until June 30 next.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Sept. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
KENORA, ONT.—October 30th, 1937

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Re: Pupil 0206, Una Wawance,
Islington Band, #127.

Dear Sir:

Referring to our conversation over the telephone I wish to state for your information that I have re-checked the quarterly returns, and I find that the teacher of the Primary room placed this girl's name on her quarterly return, and also the teacher in the Intermediate room had the same pupil on her return.

The above pupil went home in June, 1936, and because of ill health, and being under Doctor's instructions, she did not return to School until September 11th, 1939. The record as shown on Sheet 1 of the quarterly return for September showing 19 days is correct, and the record on Sheet 2 of the quarterly return should not appear at all.

I am sorry that this was overlooked, but the above pupil before leaving the school had been promoted to the Intermediate room, and was entered on the register of that room, but upon her return to the school, having lost one whole year, she was placed in the Beginners' room, which accounts for her name appearing in both rooms. I have asked the teachers to rectify this, and to see that her name appears only on the one register in future.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Kanora, Ontario,
November 6th, 1939

Dear Sir,

Replying to Departmental letter 129-3-10 of 17th ultimo re Una Kawance pupil #0206 Cecilia Jeffrey School.

Enclosed please find letter received from the Principal which explains that the pupil went home on June 15th in ill health and did not return till September 11th, 1939.

The record of 19 days as shown on Sheet 1 of the Quarterly Returns is correct and the record on sheet 2 should not appear at all.

I regret this was overlooked when the Quarterly Returns were checked.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 20, 1930.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 18th ultimo forwarding the September quarter return and a letter from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey residential school I would refer you to official letter of October 13 last in which you were definitely informed that the under-mentioned children should be returned to their parents:

Victoria Pitchener Alex Morriseau
Birdie Cantin William Morriseau

The Department wishes its instructions in the above regard carried out immediately and no grant is being allowed for them. On several occasions in the past very definite instructions have been sent to all principals of residential schools that children whose eligibility for admission is doubtful on any grounds must not be admitted until all the facts are placed before the Department and our decision has been given.

The admission of Baptiste Big Blood, Ella Green and Joyce Green is approved. The application forms for Marie Louise Oshie and Mabel Redsky are being returned in order that you may state the religion of these children. This information is not given on the forms. The usual application forms and certificates of health should be submitted for the following pupils:

No. 252 Napoleon Prince No. 0840 Mary McDonald
" 0233 Nancy Auteki jiek " 0841 Agnes "

Yours truly,

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir;

Reference Departmental letter #129-3-10 of 20th instant,

I have again written the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School re taking pupils not approved by the Department, and phoned him this morning, but he still contends the Department is discriminating in favour of the Roman Catholic Church, although I have assured him this is not true and that all denominations get the same treatment.

He has no excuse for keeping these children as in dealing with him, I put everything in black and white, so there will be no mistake. This is not the first case we have had, where he has been instructed to send children home, but does not carry out our wishes.

I return the applications for Marie Louise Oshie and Mabel Nedsky duly completed as requested.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 16, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to my letter of the 20th instant.

I note that you have informed the principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey residential school regarding the instructions that have been issued in connection with the 4 children mentioned in my previous letter.

You may now inform him that no grant has been allowed for these 4 pupils since October 1, 1939.

The admission of Mabel Redsky and Marie Louise Oshe is approved.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Reference Departmental letter #129-3-10 of 28th ultimo, re children at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, for whom no grant is being allowed.

I notified the Principal, who informs me that the Morrison boys have not attended the school, and their names have not been entered on the roll.

Regarding Birdie Cantin and Victoria Kitchenerese, their names were struck off the roll at the beginning of this quarter, and the parents are coming to Kemora in a few days, and he hopes to return the children to their homes when the parents are returning.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

This morning has been discharged from the Fort William Sanatorium and has returned to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

This boy was number 206 at this school, and the Principal would like authority for his re-admission, which is recommended by me as the boy is young, only born 5th May 1907.

The Medical Superintendent wrote the Principal, "we believe, however, that with a reasonable routine of rest he will get along satisfactorily at school. I would suggest that he be allowed to follow the normal routine of the school, including a certain amount of outdoor exercise, with the exception that he continue an afternoon rest hour of at least two hours daily and long hours of rest at night. We frequently find that after the lesion quietens down substantially, the change from the hospital to regular life and increased freedom of school or home is definitely beneficial. It would be wise to have this boy kept under periodical observation and x-rayed again for comparison purposes in six months' time."

I shall be glad to receive the Department's approval.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
December 18, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 9th instant the Department approves the re-admission of Jim Landorgan to the Cecilia Jeffrey residential school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
aboriginal belief. The agent, in his letter of October 4, stated that this man had been married to two women, both of whom belonged to the Roman Catholic Church, and that the mother of Victoria had attended the Kenora R. C. school. He stated, further, that the mother died in 1934 and that the father married (Indian fashion) another woman, who had also attended the McIntosh R. C. Indian residential school. It is noted that Bernard Napish, half brother to Victoria Pitchenese, son of the same mother but different father, is at present a pupil at the Cecilia Jeffrey school at Kenora.

We had nothing on file to indicate nor have we yet, that Harry Pitchenese was legally married to his first wife, the late mother of Victoria. If he was not legally married, the girl, under a ruling given by the law officers of the Crown, would be a Roman Catholic - the same religion as her mother - and would consequently be eligible for enrolment at the Kenora R. C. residential school.

A great deal of the difficulty we have experienced here and a great deal of the annoyance created locally might have been avoided if this girl's claims for admission to the school had been carefully reviewed before she entered the institution. We are today communicating with the Indian agent, asking him to secure information, if he can, with respect to the marriage of Harry Pitchenese. If this Indian was legally married prior to the birth of Victoria, the girl is eligible for admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey school, and the principal of the school will be notified to this effect.

I feel that I should, in fairness to myself, refer to the affidavit attached to the application form signed by Pitchenese, with respect to the admission of his daughter. We have learned from experience that these affidavit forms mean practically nothing. Affidavit forms have reached us on more than one occasion, signed by the same Indian parents anxious to secure admission for their children to either a Roman Catholic or a Protestant school. On such cases affidavits are frequently signed by half-breeds, whose children cannot, under any circumstances be enrolled at our residential schools. As a matter of fact, when an application form is accompanied by an affidavit, the officials become peculiarly diligent in their search for irregularities. This attitude on their part has developed as a result of experience from year to year.

Should you require additional information, I want you to feel perfectly free to communicate with me again.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, January 3, 1940.

Re - Victoria Pitcheneese

Dear Dr. Johnston:

In response to your request, I am submitting herewith information secured from the departmental files in respect to the eligibility of the above noted student for enrolment at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian residential school.

The regular admission form, signed by the father of Victoria Pitcheneese, is dated September 9, 1939. This admission form is signed by James Gardner as witness and by the medical officer, Dr. A. D. Ferguson. It is not signed, however, by the Indian agent, who invariably signs such forms before sending them forward to the Department, unless there is some dispute in respect to the religious status of the child or some dispute in respect to its racial status. On the admission form the religion of the father is given as "None," father was Indian belief; mother Roman Catholic, father attended Cecilia Jeffrey school.

Attached to this particular application form is an affidavit signed by Harry Pitcheneese, declaring that his religion is Protestant and expressing a desire to have his child educated at the Cecilia Jeffrey school. You will note, however, that this affidavit was not made out until September 25, whereas the admission form was dated September 2, 1939. This application form, along with a number of other somewhat similar application forms and all were carefully and sympathetically reviewed by the departmental officials. The admission of eight pupils, whose application forms for admission had been sent forward, was approved by the Department in a letter to the Indian agent dated October 13, 1939. It was pointed out, however, that certain pupils should not have been enrolled by the principal of the school until additional facts in respect to their parents and general history had been submitted to the Department for consideration. Two of these were declared ineligible under the new ruling, which renders half-breed children ineligible for enrolment at Indian residential schools. In the case of Victoria Pitcheneese, it was noted that her application form had not been signed by the Indian agent and was to that extent irregular and that this pupil should not have been enrolled until her case had been more fully investigated by the Department. You can readily appreciate how difficult it would be for the Department to administer residential schools if pupils were enrolled indiscriminately and the approval of the Department sought after the pupils were established in the school.

It would appear that when the Indian agent sought information from the father of Victoria Pitcheneese, the father declared that he was not a Protestant but was of aboriginal -

Reverend Robert Johnston, D.D.,
Knox Presbyterian Church,
Elgin Street, Ottawa.
Ottawa,
January 4, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of October 4 and subsequent correspondence with reference to the application for the admission of Victoria Pitchener to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

You did not state definitely in your letter whether or not this girl is legitimate or illegitimate. Please give me definite information in this regard.

In your letter of October 4 you stated that the mother died in 1934 but in Mr. Dyers' letter of October 17 which you forwarded with your letter of October 19 he stated that he had been informed that the mother died when the child was born.

Please make further inquiries and advise me which of the above statements is correct.

In either case please let me know who cared for the child from the time of the mother's death to the date on which she was sent to Cecilia Jeffrey School.

In your letter of October 19 there is the following sentence: "In view of the Principal's letter I would be glad to receive further instructions as I feel confident the child was never brought up in the Protestant faith". You should let me know your reasons for making this statement.

Yours truly,

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Replying to Departmental letter #129-3-10 of 4th instant re Victoria Pitchenese of the Eagle Lake Band.

This girl was legitimate and was born 24th May, 1928 not 1929. I have no record of any application for admission handed me by Mr. Burns, Assistant Chief, who carried this woman according to the Indian Custom on the 15th September 1927. Therefore there is no question as to legitimacy.

A letter of the 4th October states the mother died in 1934, to be exact she died the 3rd day of July, 1934 at the Reserve of Tuberculosis, and Victoria was the last child she had. The Principal is not correct when he says she died at childbirth, and in any case this child was six years old when the mother died.

After the death of the mother the child was taken care of by the Grandmother Mrs. George Habish of Eagle Lake Band. This woman is of Aboriginal belief, and she brought her up until she was taken to school.

My reason for stating "I feel confident the child was never brought into the school" is that her father although attending the Cecilia Jeffrey School, always claims he is of Indian belief, his wife the child's mother went to the Roman Catholic School and is a Catholic as well as also her son, brother of Victoria but illegitimate, at present a pupil in the Kenora R.C. School. In addition to this Harry Pitchenese is married again to a girl who is a Catholic and attended the McIntosh R.C. School.

If approval is given for the girl to attend the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I don't think there will be any objection now by any of the Indians, although her eligibility is doubtfull.

I have today seen the Chiefs of the Eagle Lake Band and he informs me the Grandmother who brought up the child belongs to the Indian Religion, according to my records this is
Dear Sir,

Reference Department letter 129-3-10 of 4th inst.

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School was refused permission to admit Victoria Pitchensese as a grant earning pupil to his school and there has been considerable correspondence in the case.

The girl's father Harry Pitchensese now writes that he is now a Protestant as is also his Mother Mrs Mary English of Eagle Lake Band and although his step-son Bernard is a pupil at the Kenora R.C. Residential School, it might be better to allow Victoria to be admitted to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, as this is now their wish and it will satisfy all concerned.

I shall be glad to receive your instructions,

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

February 6, 1840.

Dear Doctor Johnston:

The records here indicate that the Department authorized the admission of Victoria Pitchemese to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School in a letter to the Agent dated January 24, 1840. This is the pupil whose religious status was in dispute and about whom you spoke to me a few weeks ago.

In the case of the daughter of Alex Mecous of the Waynayassappo Reserve, Manitoba, I may state that the Department is in receipt of a letter dated January 5, 1840, from Inspector Hamilton which reads in part as follows:

"This child was admitted to the Pine Creek R.C. Residential School in 1839 and apparently at that time Alex Mecous, the father, was a Catholic. In October of the past year, however, I was advised by the Rev. Mr. Lockhart that Alex was baptised by him and became a member of the Presbyterian Church. Mr. Crump, the missionary on the Waynayassappo Reserve, is not a fully ordained minister. Therefore, the Rev. K.H. Lockhart supervises Mr. Crump's work and administers certain rites of the Church. The statement was prepared at the Rirtle Residential School and signed in the presence of Mr. Crump and Mary Bagg after which Alex was baptised by Mr. Lockhart.

Unfortunately there is great rivalry on this Reserve between the Presbyterian minister and Father Crump with the result that many of the Indians do not know from day to day to which Church they belong."

Rev. Dr. Robert Johnston,
Knox Presbyterian Church,
Elgin Street,
Ottawa, Ont.

Royal Canadian Mounted Police

Division "D"
Province Ontario
Sub Division Winnipeg
Detachment Kenora

Date May 13th, 1940.

Re: John James WILLIAMSON, Truant from Cecilia Jeffery Indian School, Kenora, Ontario.

May 13th, 1940

1. At 10:35 a.m. on this date Mr. F.W. Ryerson, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffery Indian School, informed this detachment that the student named Indian boy had been missing from the school since the previous day.

2. A patrol was made to the school & the boy's teacher & several of his friends were interviewed, but nothing could be learned as to where he might have gone; it was ascertained that the boy's father had called at the school on Saturday & asked for permission to take his son to the picture "Pinocchio", but this permission had been refused, & as a result the boy had been greatly disappointed. The teacher stated that the boy was very well behaved & that she had no complaints against him.

3. Numerous enquiries were made of the Indians in Kenora & at the various Indian settlements in the vicinity, but no trace of the boy could be found; as a result of these enquiries the boy himself reported at the office of the Kenora Town Police & requested them to get in touch with this office & then remained until he was picked up & escorted back to the School.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir;

Enclosed herewith please find application for admission of Emily Shirley Agnes Churchill aged 4 years and 2 months. The father of the child is a patient in the Fort William Sanatorium and the mother is with him, and staying somewhere in Fort William.

Other members of the family are in this school and although the child is not yet of school age, I would recommend that her admission as a grant earning pupil be approved as the Principal is willing to accept her, and it would relieve the family of part of their financial burden. They have been receiving relief from the school, and the Department had authorized us to give relief to the family whilst the man was in the Sanatorium to the value of $8.00 a month.

Vouchers to the value of $8.00 for the month of July and $8.00 for the month of August will be sent you in a few days; the school had supplied them with considerably more than this allowance.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find quarterly returns for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

You will notice the following pupils have not been officially approved as grant earning pupils, and we do not appear to have received any applications for their admission, but it appears to me that you will approve all the applications with the exception of possibly pupils #273 Birdie Cantin. In his case there was considerable correspondence, however I would now suggest that the application be approved as the father sent the boy back and wishes him in this school.

The following have no applications in this office:

- Edgar Sinclair
- Herbert Major
- Jim Williams
- William Cameron
- Birdie Cantin

Some of the children were admitted by the last Principal without informing us, and some of the children's application forms are completed but the new Principal is waiting for the result of the X-ray. In my opinion all the children with the possible exception of Cantin are eligible for admission to this Protestant School, and I think the grant should be paid for them all.

I have certified the returns to enable the Principal to get the grant, if they were held up until all the application

October 24, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant enclosing the September return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. Part of this return appears to have been entered by one person, part by another and a third section has been typewritten. It is felt that you should direct the attention of the new Principal to the fact that the preparation of the quarterly return is most important and consequently one person should handle it. In entering the return only one name should be shown on each line of the form. The names of the boys and girls should be entered in separate sections and in each case the names should be shown consecutively according to number.

The June quarter return showed James Highblood as No. 817 and Adam Highblood as No. 818. On the September quarter return these numbers were reversed. You should point out to the Principal that the numbers shown on the June return should be retained on future returns.

The name of Mabel Redsky, No. 0345, was shown on the June quarter return but does not appear on the September return although no application has been received for her discharge. Please advise regarding this girl.

No reply appears to have been received to my letter of April 17 regarding Jack Cheene, No. 856.

The Department is not prepared to approve the admission of Birdie Cantin, No. 273. It is considered that the instructions given some months ago to have this boy returned to his parents should have been carried out.

Mr. J. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Kenora, Ont., Oct. 9th, 1940.

REPORT FOR MONTH OF SEPTEMBER.

Most of the children returned to the residential schools about the last of September, but a number did not do so. They informed me that the late Principal, Mr. Myers, had told them they need not be back until the last of October. This caused considerable difficulty.

Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Edwards,

I have received your letter of the 15th written by Mr. Alfred, the father of the boy named [name].

I do not think I can make an exception under such special circumstances. The boy is doing well in this school and we are very pleased.

However, if the admission is not approved, and the Department still wishes, I am prepared (regretfully) to return the boy to his father. Could you, sir, give me further information? I understand that he lives in other places.

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature] J. O. Pitts,
Principal.
I therefore think the Department should now approve his admission to the Swilkin Jeffrey Residential School as the father informs me that none of the family were baptized by either of the religious faiths.

Indie Cuntin's father has left for Gold Rock, which is a considerable distance away from the railway and post office and it will be difficult to get in touch with him at the present time.

Applications for admission for all children at present in the school will be forwarded as soon as completed.

The pupils listed—Chilly, James, 269a, 271a, and 274a—were apparently in the school in 1889.

I believe the children were not shown on the register, but letters are being completed and will be forwarded, and I do not think there will be any objection to their admission.

[Signature]

Indian Agent
Dear Sir,

Replying to Departmental Letter 149-3-10 of the 24th ultimo re September returns of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. We had already taken up with the Principal the matter of having the returns made out in the proper way, and he has assured us this will be done in the future.

We also called his attention to the fact that James Bigblood was shown as No. 217, and Adam Bigblood as No. 219. This has now been corrected.

To Michel Rudzky, No. 0243. Apparently your letter is incorrect. She was shown on the March quarter. She was omitted from the June quarter, but was again shown on the September quarter. She attended school in every quarter, but there was an error in making up the returns; her name was omitted in the June return. An application was not made for grant for her for that quarter. I do not know whether the Department would now allow them the amount.

No. No. 256 Jack Ohenea. This boy died on the 25th March 1940.

No. No. 275a, Birdie Cantin. Enclosed please find copy of letter received from the Principal of the school. The late Principal, Mr. Hyers, was instructed on numerous occasions to return this boy to his parents, but was omitted to do so, and after the holidays this boy was sent back to school by his father as he wished him to be educated at the school. On the 2nd of October 1940, I met the father at Wabigoon and he informed me then that the boy was back at school, and that he wanted him to be educated at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. He did not want him sent home or sent to the Roman Catholic Residential School.
Ottawa,
November 15, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. With regard to Birdie Cantin, No. 375, he has remained in the Cecilia Jeffrey School but if there is any protest regarding his admission it should be distinctly understood that the whole matter will be reviewed.

Considerable trouble would have been saved if the Principal had carried out Departmental instructions. You should point out to the new Principal that when definite instructions are received from the Department regarding the discharge of a pupil he will be expected to comply at once.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

AURORA, Ontario,
NOVEMBER 26TH 1940.

Secretary,

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

For reference to my letter 10-13, I enclose quarterly return of the J. J. Indian Road.

For reference to the last paragraph, turning into the letter further we find that pupil No. 126, Mr. Sinclair, was one of the children admitted by the late Principal, Mr. W. Byers in 1939, and no application form was received here nor any information that he was at the school.

Mr. Putts, the new Principal, naturally included all children in his return and was endeavouring to get Mr. Sinclair's signature to the Application for admission.

Mr. Sinclair, No. 101 at Portage Road, is willing to see me. He said he did not attend the Presbyterian schools but was educated and brought up at the St. Joseph Residential School.

I shall be obliged if you will forward this original to Mr. Sinclair.

Trusting this will meet your approval,

Francis Edwards
Ottawa,
November 30, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 26th instant the Department approves the transfer of Edgar Sinclair from the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School to the Kenora Indian Residential School.

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School should show on his December return the exact date on which this boy is sent to the Kenora School. Grant was allowed for Sinclair for the September quarter and will be allowed from October 1 to the date of his transfer to the Kenora School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

RE: Annie Martin, Shoal Lake # 40
Annuity Ticket # 49
Father, Joe Martin
Born Feb. 15, 1925.

Dear Sir:

You may remember our conversation of some time ago concerning our suspicions of the state of health of this girl.

Our nurse has now definitely ascertained that this girl is pregnant.

Annie states that she lived with a man for two weeks, or thereabouts, while out picking rice, during the last of August or the first of September. She says that his name is Gordon, but she can not, or will not give his surname. She says that he comes from Pine Falls, is 19 years of age and was this summer fishing in this district. He is supposed to be an Indian. She says, of course, that he promised to marry her.

Since this girl is almost sixteen, I should like to respectfully ask the Department for her discharge. I hope that such permission is granted as soon as possible as her influence on the other girls is not good.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal
Kenora, Ontario,
13th December, 1940

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School re Annie Martin, pupil #0167, #49 Shoal Lake Band 40.

This girl is reported to be in the family way by an Indian from further West; we are not yet able to find out who he is, the intimacy is reported to have occurred whilst the Indians were out making wild rice so that apparently no blame can be attached to the School.

I would recommend the discharge be approved.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards

April 2nd, 1941.

Capt. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

RE: Leonard Churchill

Dear Capt. Edwards:

I have just received a further urgent request from Mr. and Mrs. Frank Churchill, to take their little boy Leonard into the school.

You will remember that Frank is a patient at Fort William Station, and his wife is working there. Both were pupils at this school, and worked here, (farming,) after graduation.

Two sons and the little daughter are at present pupils here.

Leonard is now three years of age. I hereby make special application to the Department to ask that Leonard be admitted to our school, and enclose the proper forms.

The mother and father had tried to make arrangements for the keep of their boy. The friends who have cared for him have now run out of relief and the Relief officer is hesitant about caring for a ward of the Government. Also, the Relief Department is planning to send this family to a distant town.

I am aware of the difficulties involved, but would ask that you would request of Ottawa that special consideration be given to this family in their present trouble.

Yours Sincerely,

[Signature]
Princoval.
Kenora, Ontario
April 25th 1934

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find letter from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School together with an Application for Admission of Leonard Howard Churchill, No. 90 Lac des Mille Lacs Band.

This boy was born on the 19th April 1931, and therefore, is only three years of age. I pointed out to the Principal that the Department's ruling is that children under school age cannot now be admitted as grant earning pupils. However, he asked me to send the application in which I do now although I have not signed it.

The Lac des Mille Lacs Band is now in the Fort Arthur Agency. The father of the children is in the Port William Sanatorium and I am given to understand that the mother is working in the institution.

All the children in the possession of this boy are now pupils at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. As the parents cannot keep him he has been left with some half-breeds in Kenora who are on Town relief and I know of nobody who can take the child, as neither the father nor the mother has lived on the reserve for very many years.

I shall be glad to receive your instructions in this case.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

P.S.
Ottawa,
April 30, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant it has been decided to approve the admission of Leonard Churchill to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

This is a special concession and should not be taken as a precedent for the future. I feel that there is a tendency to place in residential schools children of tender years. This should be discouraged as our residential schools are not primarily intended for pupils under 7 years of age.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Kenora, Ontario,
26th August, 1941.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

The Principals of both the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School and the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School have been in to see me in regard to receiving a small grant to enable them to bring the pupils back to their schools after the holidays.

There is no doubt they are put to considerable expense and a grant is usually allowed them, by doing this we have very little expense by the Mounted Police in getting truants, and I would recommend that an amount not exceeding $50.00 be authorized for each school, when Bands have a cash distribution this fall, part could be obtained as a refund from some of the Indians.

An early reply will be appreciated, as the children should return in a few days and we have received a number of letters from different points, some distance from here, in which the Indians say they have no money to return their children.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
August 28, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 26th instant the Department will allow an amount of $50.00 for transportation of pupils returning to the Kenora Indian Residential School after the summer holidays and a similar amount for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. It is understood, of course, that if possible the total amount should not be spent. Every effort should be made to have the parents return the children without cost either to the Department or the school authorities.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant the Department will allow an amount of $50.00 for transportation of pupils returning to the Kenora Indian Residential School after the summer holidays and a similar amount for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. It is understood, of course, that if possible the total amount should not be spent. Every effort should be made to have the parents return the children without cost either to the Department or the school authorities.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have received a letter from Ex-Chief William Gardner of the Wabigoon Band, he requests permission to allow his son Frank, born 3rd March 1930 to attend the White Day School at Dinorwic, where other Indian and half-breeds are attending. To do this he would have to have Frank discharged from the Cecilia Jeffrey School where he is pupil #259.

The Ex-Chief has rented a house in Dinorwic, and made arrangements with the school, where he will pay for the boy's education himself, and will also send his youngest daughter to the same school.

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School himself thinks we should make an exception in this case and allow the boy Frank to go to the white day school at Dinorwic, providing we get assurance the child attends regularly.

For your information I may say that William Gardner has made a little money by the sale of mining claims to an American Company, and receives payment in installments that will take care of his expenses for a while.

I suggest that we approve the discharge of Frank Gardner, on the above conditions and that we ask the teacher at the Dinorwic School to notify us monthly as to the attendance, and if the child does not attend regularly he is to be brought back to the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
October 4, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 30th ultimo you may inform the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School that the Department approves the discharge of Frank Gardner on the conditions mentioned in the last paragraph of your letter.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find letter from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School in which he applies for the discharge of sixteen pupils enumerated therein.

All these pupils are now at home except of one with the exception of pupil No. 02074, Velma Gardner, who is a patient in the Dynevor hospital at Selkirk, Manitoba.

I recommend the discharges be approved.

Yours Truly,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

AFFIDAVIT

I, Thomas Williamson, No. 26., Shoal Lake Band No. 39., make oath and say that I wish my boy Thomas, who was born on the 29th March 1934., educated in the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School.

Myself and my wife and all my family except Thomas are Presbyterians and my wife and the other children all went to the Cecilia Jeffrey Presbyterian School.

I know that the Kenora Indian Residential School is a Catholic school and the reason I want my boy educated at this school is because it is nearer to where I live where I am caretaker of the Indian Camp property and I have no money to pay for hire of taxi to the Cecilia Jeffrey School in order to see my boy which is about five miles or more from where I live.

My other children have been discharged from the school. Another reason is the Principal of the Presbyterian School does not help myself or my children now they have left the school and the Principal of the R. C. helps the Indians.

Another reason is there is too much T. B. at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

Sworn before me at the Indian Office this 23rd day of October 1941.

Town of Kenora, District of Kenora, Province of Ontario.

[Signature]

Indian Affairs - School Files
Vol. 19, File 6290, Pt. 1-10, part 2
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir;

The above named Indian is the caretaker of the Indian Camp property here, and I am writing to him about his boy Thomas aged 7 years and 6 months. He at first refused to send the boy to school although of school age, when I informed him we could not keep him on as caretaker of the Indian property, and that if he did not send his boy to school, action would have to be taken under section 10 of the Indian Act, he agreed to let the boy go, but wished him to go to the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School and signed the enclosed affidavit, giving reasons such as they are.

Tom Williamson did not go to school, but his wife, and all the other children went to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School (Presbyterian) and it is reported to me the whole family belong to the Presbyterian Church although they do not attend services.

There is another case of Chief Allan Payton #9 Rat Postage Bank, who has a girl aged 12 last December, and a boy aged 9 last May. The Chief himself and his wife, both went to the Cecilia Jeffrey Presbyterian School, he has three children Girl born 29th December 1928, boy born 9th May, 1932, and an infant boy born 23rd August 1941. The two oldest children both are of school age and he has been instructed on several occasions to take these children to school, but has not done so. The Chief was married legally at the Court House, Kenora, by the Reverend R. Bairn, (now deceased) he being either a Presbyterian or a Methodist Minister. It is reported that the Chief if he sends his children, wishes them to go to the Catholic School.

I hold no brief for any school, but feel that if these children are made to attend, which they should do, that they should go to the Cecilia Presbyterian School, and not the Catholic School, but I shall be glad to get your instructions.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards

Indian Agent.
District of Kenora,
Province of Ontario
Dominion of Canada.

I, Allan Paypom, #93 Rat Portage Band make oath
and say, the reason I wish to have my children
educated in the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential
School is, that at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian
Residential School there is too much tuberculosis.
It is too far from Kenora, therefore too expensive
to go to see them. They do not get fed well
enough at the Cecilia Jeffrey and the water in
the lake is dirty. My wife and I both went
to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School
but neither are baptized and are of Indian belief.
I know that the Kenora R. C. School is a Catholic
institution and that the children are brought up
in the Catholic faith.

Sworn before me at the
Town of Kenora, District
of Kenora, this 4th day of
November, 1941.

[Signature]
Chief Allan Paypom

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Chief Allan Paypam of the Rat Portage Band has two children of school age, a girl, Verma Allan born 29th December, 1928 and a boy, Russell, born 9th May, 1930. We have for some time been endeavouring to get him to put his children to school, but he would not do so until now when we threatened him with a fine or imprisonment unless he did.

Both the Chief and his wife are ex-pupils of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, but inform me they have not been baptised Presbyterians, although I believe the woman was but have no record here.

However the Chief informs me he has taken the younger girl to the Kenora Roman Catholic School, and will send the boy next year.

I informed him it was against the regulations to put the children in a different school from the parents, unless he could give good reasons, and he then made the enclosed affidavit giving his reasons. None of the reasons are of any value, as far as they go, and it is immaterial to me which school they attend, but under the circumstances I am very glad to receive your instructions as the Roman Catholic School has enough pupils for the grant, whereas the Cecilia Jeffrey School is very short of pupils.

Awaiting your instructions,

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 5th instant, enclosing affidavit from the Chief of the Rat Portage and Dalles Bands, asking that his two children be educated at the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School.

I have now received application for admission of one of the children "Veron" to the Roman Catholic School, duly signed by the Chief Allan Paypon.
