Dear Sir,

Re Thomas Williamson, #26 Shoal Lake Band #39.

I shall be glad to receive a reply to my letter of the 30th October last re the above named boy of school age. I also referred to the matter in a letter of the 24th November, but so far have received no instructions.

This boy was first placed in the R.C. Indian Residential School, and an affidavit sent in that the father of the boy wished him to go there, later the father wished the boy to go to the Presbyterian School, and you were so notified.

I would suggest that the admission of the boy be approved to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and shall be glad to get your ruling on the matter.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I shall be glad to receive a reply to my letters of the 5th and 26th ultimo re application for admission of Erna Allan Paypom, #93 Rat Portage Band.

The child is at present at the Roman Catholic School, and the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Presbyterian School, is very anxious to get this girl and her brother into his school.

If this girl has to be moved it should be done as soon as possible, as the longer she stays at the catholic school the more difficult it will be to remove her.

The application for admission was sent to you, but not signed as I am waiting for your ruling on the matter.

Yours very truly,

Frank Edwards

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letters of the 8th ultimo and the 10th instant and my reply of the 15th instant we have received other representations with reference to Verna Paypon.

It has now been decided that this girl should not be placed in any residential school at the present time but should be returned to her parents. Her case will be reconsidered before the residential schools open for the term 1942-43.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

KENORA · ONTARIO
March 25, 1942.

Capt. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario.

Re: Discharge of Children at AGE 16

Dear Captain Edwards:

Last year, sixteen of our children left school because they were, or shortly would be 16 years of age. Of that number, I can only find record of three of their wives. None went could be called "productive labour" for our Economic system. The remainder merely went home to the reserves and put in time.

May I submit for consideration the following plan: That unless the parents can show need at home for the child, or unless the child has a home to go to, which can supply gainful employment, good moral surroundings, and that amount of supervision and discipline needed for developing children, or unless there is a position open for employment of the child, (over which the principal, Indian agent or church representative could keep supervision to attend to the interests of the child),

The child should be allowed to stay in the school, at least until he or she reaches the age of seventeen. (i.e., That the age be extended to 17, and the child only be discharged if the parent can supply a better environment or a need, and not be automatically discharged at sixteen.)

This past year we have barely kept up to our quota, and for one month were below it.

The children at 16 are hardly up to the moral standard of white children of the same age. The boys have not reached their full strength and are, therefore, not able to stand right into manual labour. When they are ready and able, they have forgotten part of their training in the schools; the likewise are used to, and prefer, the lazy life on the reserve. The girls are just at the weak age of adolescence, and that the inhibitions and training of a mother which most of the white children have, are liable to, (and often do) become wrongly associated with men.

If the children could remain for one year after the legal discharge age, they might be allowed to leave the school at
March 25, 1947.

Captain F. Edwards - Cont'd.

any time that a position opened up for them. This year, I have had six requests for boys or girls, all good homes, but was forced to refuse them because, (a) children were under 16, and (b) our quota was already low. If we could let children go to these homes, and have authority to keep a watch on their interests for say, one year, I feel that this would be a good step in the "follow up" plan.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Toronto.

March 31, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. With regard to the question raised in his letter, please refer him to Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act. The Department is always prepared to consider representations from Principals or Indian Agents with regard to keeping children in Residential schools after the age of 18. However, very valid reasons must be presented before we can approve such action.

In view of the shortage of labour at the present time, I feel that no undue restrictions should be placed on boys and girls of 18 years of age obtaining employment.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,

KEWORA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of April 17

I hereby make application to the department for the discharge of pupils #197, Frank Sinclair,
#0186 Janet Mandamin,
#0239 Jessie Peters.

There are positions available in good homes for these three children and in accordance with the wish of the department that we should help during the present period of shortage of labour, and in the best interests of the children themselves, I would recommend their discharge.

With regard to pupil #26, Arthur Gardiner, I hereby make application to the department to consider his remaining in the school for the next term. He has expressed a wish to remain. His father is in the army, and both his father and mother live with another "partner". If we should be successful in getting a good home and position for this boy, I shall apply for his discharge later.

P.S.

Re: Discharge of pupils at Sun.

In accordance with previous instructions from you, we carried these children for the balance of the quarter in which they went to the Sanatorium, with remarks that they had gone and the date, and then automatically dropped them. I was under the impression that this was the usual and correct procedure. However if it is necessary to apply for their discharge, I hereby make application to the department for the discharge of these children. (This will mean their re-admission with a new number if they return from the Sun. Is that correct?)

#0196, Donna Keslok,
#0198, Maxene Pinesse,
#0225, Mary Major,
#200, Jim Macdonald,
#231, Horace Paikin,

and also, #0197, Janet Groves, who went to Dynesvor Hospital March 10, 1942 (as on the March 31 Return).

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

KENORA, Ont., Aug. 7, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Previous correspondence has been brought to my attention - including your letter of August 29, 1941, file 129-1-10, in which an amount of $50.00 was authorized for each - the St. Mary's R.C. Indian Residential School, Kenora and the Cecelia Jeffry Presbyterian Indian Residential School, Kenora, to assist with transportation costs of children returning to school after the summer holidays - whose parents were unable to pay this cost themselves.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant, the Department will allow an amount of $60.00 for transportation of pupils returning to the Kenora Residential School after the summer holidays and a similar amount for the Cecilia School at Kenora Residential School. It is understood, of course, that if possible the total amount should not be spent. Every effort should be made, both by the Principals concerned and yourself, to have the parents return the children without cost either to the Department or the school authorities.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

KATURA, Ont., Aug. 29, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Chief Charley Oshie, No. 70 North West Angle Band #37, has asked permission to transfer his children from the Cecelia Jeffry Indian Residential School Kenora to the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School at Whitefish Bay. He proposes changing his permanent residence from North West Angle Reserve No. 37 to North West Angle Reserve No. 34A which is just across a narrow body of water from the Whitefish Bay Reserve No. 32A - where the Whitefish Bay Day School is situated.

Charley Oshie's reason for wishing to make this change is that he spends too much money making periodic trips with his wife from North West Angle to Kenora during the school term to visit his children in the residential school. His present plan is to build a home on Reserve 34A so that the children may live at home and attend the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

May I be advised - prior to the opening of the Cecelia Jeffry school term on September 5th, if possible - whether this transfer would be in order.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Canada.
Dear Sir:

Re: Dora Ochlo, pupil No. 0800
Mary Ochlo: " " 0806

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 29th ultimo, written by you on behalf of the parents of the above-noted pupils.

May I point out that it is my understanding that the Whitefish Bay Day School is operated under the auspices of the Catholic Church. If such is the case, it would not be possible to transfer these children to that school. Section 10, Sub-section B, of the Act reads:

"No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school, or school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school, or school conducted under Protestant auspices."

You might discuss this matter again with the father of these children and with the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School and let me have any comments you may care to send forward.

Yours truly,

H.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. G. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

October 24, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Re: Dora Oshie, Pupil No. 0200
Mary Oshie, No. 0268
Cecelia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

Further reference is made to my letter of August 29th and your file 129-3-10 dated Ottawa, September 1, 1942, replying to same.

Chief Charles Oshie, #70 North West Angle Band #37, father of these children, was informed of the reply received from Ottawa regarding his request, some time ago, but he called at this office again today and asked if it would not be possible to make an exception to the general rule as provided for in Section 10, Sub-section 2 of the Indian Act.

He is building a home for himself on the North West Angle Band #17 Indian Reserve No. 34 A which is just across Regina Bay from the Whitefish Bay Indian Reserve No. 32 A - upon which the Whitefish Bay Day School is situated.

This is not the same situation as if Oshie were applying for transfer from one residential school to another, and if possible, I would recommend that his request be given favorable consideration.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
O. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Canada.
Ottawa,
October 27, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, in further reference to Dora and Mary Dale. As these children have no doubt returned to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I believe it would be advisable to discharge them at the present time. The matter might be taken up again at the end of the academic year; namely, June 30, 1943.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Acting Indian Agent,

- 3 -

Trusting that something can be done for this boy as soon as possible, I am,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

T. H. Wolfe,
Magistrate.
KENORA, ONT. May 26, 1943.

For the reason which I have just stated I telephoned to your agent, Mr. Swartman, at Sioux Lookout, in the hope that arrangements could be made to have this boy placed in an Indian School. Mr. Swartman informed me that although the mother was a Treaty Indian, the boy had not been entered in Treaty and therefore could not be placed in an Indian School without first having his case dealt with by the proper authorities. This I think was confirmed by you in our telephone conversation.

Rather than place this boy in the Gaol on his arrival I arranged with the Salvation Army here to take care of him for a few days until something could be done. This was on May 20th and the boy is still with the Salvation Army. As it would be unfair to ask them to keep him very long unless some way could be found to pay for his keep I would appreciate it very much if arrangements could be made within a reasonably short time to have him admitted to one of the Indian Schools. I realize that at the best this may take a little time and it has occurred to me that possibly he might be taken care of in the meantime by one of your Schools near Kenora. The boy's mother I understand is an Anglican.

From what I have seen of this boy I am of the opinion that he has no natural criminal tendencies but got himself into these difficulties as a result of being at a loose end with no supervision of any kind. He is a bright, likeable little fellow and I am convinced that with proper supervision and training he would give a very good account of himself. He is nine years old and should be attending school.
KENORA, ONT. May 26, 1943.

Inspector Hamilton,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dominion Public Bldg.,
WINNIPEG, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

As suggested in our telephone conversation yesterday I give you herewith particulars in connection with the situation of this boy.

I am informed by Provincial Constable A. Gaudry of Red Lake, that this boy lived there with his mother, grandmother and an aunt, all of whom are Treaty Indians. The boy has had no supervision and has been running more or less at large, frequently in pool rooms and generally getting himself into trouble. A few months ago the boy admitted stealing cigarettes from a small store but no charge was laid. Later on May 4th the boy admitted entering a pool room and barber shop by means of a skeleton key and stealing around $5.00 from the cash register. A charge under Section 460 of the Criminal Code of Canada was laid and upon instructions from the Crown Attorney, L. A. McLenan, he was brought to Kenora and appeared in Court on May 20th.

Ordinarily a white boy under such circumstances would be sent to a Training School, but I have considered it unwise to send the boy who appears to be a full blooded Indian to a Training School where all the other boys are white. I am afraid that it would be impossible for those in charge at the School to prevent the white boys from making it rather miserable for an Indian boy. To return the boy to Red Lake where he would continue to live under the worst possible conditions it seems to me as out of the question.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

The enclosed letter has just been received from Magistrate Wolfe of Kenora. Mr. Smartman is away on treaty so I am unable to supply any further information. Apparently the boy has not been voted into treaty but has lived the Indian mode of life along with his mother and relatives who apparently are treaty.

You will note magistrate Wolfe is anxious to dispose of the case and I would be pleased to have the Department's decision at the earliest possible date.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Enc.
Ottawa,
June 1, 1843.

Dear Sir:

Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, Man., has forwarded to me your letter of the 26th ultimo, with reference to John Redman. From the information before us we are not entirely certain that this boy is recognized as a Treaty Indian. However, our Agents who have the information are at present absent on Treaty payments and it has been decided to have the boy placed temporarily in the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. As you are aware, this school is just outside of Kenora. I am writing to the principal directing him to call for the boy and take him to the school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. T.H. Wolfe,
Registrarate,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa,
June 1, 1943.

Dear Sir:

Mr. T.H. Wolfe, Police Magistrate of Kenora, has brought to our attention the case of a boy named John Pemian from Red Lake. Apparently this boy has committed some infractions of the criminal code but the Police Magistrate considers he should be placed in an Indian residential school. At the present time he is in the Salvation Army Home in Kenora. Please interview Police Magistrate Wolfe immediately and arrange to take the boy to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. D.S. Pitts,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.

I desire to direct your special attention to pupils numbered as follows:

Nos. 0189; 0256; 204; 206; 234; and 240.

All of these are over 16 years of age, and if it is not the intention of the Principal to apply for their discharge, he should write to the Department, through your office, stating why he wishes to keep these children for another year. I would appreciate your bringing this matter to his immediate attention.

If you refer to the Acting Agent's letter of October 24, 1942, and my reply thereto, of October 27, you will note that it was intended to review the cases of Dora and Mary Oshie at the end of June. I would appreciate hearing from you regarding these children.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Kenora, Ontario.
July 19th 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa,

Would be glad to receive authority for an amount of $50.00 to be used in connection with pupils returning to school after the holidays, whose parents are unable to meet the cost themselves.

I would recommend that an amount of $50.00 be authorized the same as last year for the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School and also for the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School.

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
July 23, 1943.

Mr. N.W. Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, the Department will allow an amount of $50.00 for transportation of children returning to the Kenora Residential School after the summer holidays and a similar amount for the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. It is understood, of course, that every effort should be made, both by the Principals concerned and yourself, to have the parents return the children without cost either to the department or to the school authorities.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
July 26, 1943.

Mr. H.J. Peterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing application for the admission of Johnnie Pennion to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. While you were on a Treaty payment trip Mr. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, wrote to us about this boy, as he had received a communication from Magistrate Wall of Kenora which stated that the boy is illegitimate and has been living with his mother, but has not been receiving proper supervision. The Magistrate stated that the boy has no natural criminal tendencies, but got into difficulty as a result of lack of supervision. Under the circumstances we approve placing him in the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School temporarily and, if the information that has been supplied to us is correct, he should remain there.

Philip Nelson,
Chief, Training Division.
Cecilia Jeffrey
Presbyterian Indian Residential School
KENORA - ONTARIO

July 28, 1943.

Mr. W. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of July 6th, we would like permission to retain Nos. 01591; 0235; 204; 206; 234; and 240 for a short time, as they intimated that they would like to return to school.

Otherwise, should they not return, we will request discharge in the Sept. Returns.

The children of Chas. Oshie, this matter has not been further mentioned to us.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal

KENORA
JUL 29 1943
Kenora, Ontario,
August 6th 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dora Oahie Pupil 0200, Mary Oahie #0265

Please find attached letter from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School replying to your request contained in our 129-3-10 of the 9th ultimo. Mr Pitts was also advised of the discharge of pupils as enumerated by you.

With reference to the last paragraph covering the admittance of Dora and Mary Oahie to the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School, Mr Charles Oahie, the father of these girls has again been in to see us about this matter, and in talking to Mr Pitts relative to the case he said he would have no objection to them going to Whitefish in order that they may be near to their home and parents.

Charles Oahie has built a nice house close to the school and as he pointed out to us it will save him a considerable amount of money for his children to attend school at Whitefish and live at home.

He appears to be honest and reliable, and in view of the circumstances I would recommend his request be given favourable consideration.

Norman Peterson
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 20, 1943.

Mr. Norman Petersen, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ontario,

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, the Department approves the discharge of pupil 0080 and 0266 from the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

In view of the request from the Principal it has been decided to allow pupils 0180 and 0238 remain in the school for another year.

On reviewing our files the following information is available regarding the other four pupils whom the Principal requests be allowed to remain in the school.

No. 204 - 16½ - 8 yrs. in school
No. 206 - 16½ - 8 yrs. in school
No. 234 - 17 - 7 yrs. in school
No. 240 - 16½ - 6 yrs. in school

Some of the pupils have received a reasonable amount of institutional care, and in the case of pupil No. 234 particularly does not seem to be making any great progress in school. In view of the shortage of labour at the present time, it is felt that all of these boys could obtain employment. With this in mind the Department suggests that the Principal apply for their immediate discharge.

Philip Inglan,
Chief, Training Division.

|     | Mary Oshie         |                                             |
|     | Jim Wapay          | Over age limit                              |
|     | William Gordon Martin | Said by Father to be working.              |
|     | Robert Ronald Randy | Over age limit                             |

No. 254 Harry Tom - This boy is 17 years of age. He is a boy with a hunch-back, his mentality is approximately 10 years of age. He is an epileptic, often having as many as four attacks within 24 hours. This boy should be in a home if there were one available. He is often more like the small boys. However, as he would receive no proper treatment at home, and there does not appear to be any institution for this type of Indian, we hereby request that he be allowed to remain in Cecilia Jeffrey School.

We hereby request admission for the following pupils:

|     | Walter Prince                |
|     | William George Isaac Abraham |
|     | William Morrison             |
|     | Louis Morrison               |

Yours sincerely,

Ottawa,
October 29, 1943.

Mr. N. Palmeron, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

With reference to the September quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, the Department approves the discharge of the pupils numbered as follows:

No. 804
- 811
- 840
- 0189
- 0856

I have noted the Principal's remarks regarding Harry Tom, No. 834, and have brought this matter to the attention of the Medical Branch and a letter is being sent to the Medical Officer.

I note that you submit applications for the admission of George, William and Leslie Morrison. From the information that we have been able to secure it appears that the mother of these children is recognized as an Indian, but, as the children are non-Treaty, it is presumed that the father is a white man. If this information is correct, these children are not eligible for admission as grant-earning pupils to an Indian residential school and consequently should be discharged immediately. If you so desire, you can forward another communication to the Department giving full particulars regarding this family, as present indications are that they are not even eligible to reside on the reserve.
I also desire to refer you to a letter received from Acting Indian Agent Roberts on February 4, 1943, with regard to an application form for Mary Gardner, No. 0877 of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. We have not yet received the application form for this girl.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

REPORT ON KENORA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1947.

Schools:
Visited Cecilia Jeffrey I.R. School and made general inspection and checked over fire fighting apparatus. School well conducted - pupils well behaved and progressing very well in all branches of studies. Kenora R.C. I.R. School visited and a general inspection made. Spoke to pupils in evening and, apart from several cases of truancy, pupils were well behaved and progressing very favourably in their various classes. Made special check on a proposed Brooder House to be built, and submitted plan & tenders to Department.

Norman Paterson,
Indian Agent.

The child's parents, who are both deceased, followed the Roman Catholic Faith. Mrs. Stella McPherson, 126 Islington Band, follows the Church of England. Jennie's sister Emma, is kept by Isaac Kabeena No. 33 Shoal Lake 40, who is a Presbyterian, as bringing this child in the same Faith.

Norman Paterson
Indian Agent.
Ottawa
March 23, 1944.

Mr. H. Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 20th instant with reference to the application for the admission of Jennie McDonald to the Cecilia Jeffrey School. It is noted that both the parents of this girl were Catholics. Please let me know when the parents had and by whom she was placed with Mrs. Bolla MacDonald. Was there a legal adoption of the girl by the latter? It is generally recommended that minor children follow the religion of their parents. The girl should not be placed in any residential school until a final decision is given by this office.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, April 17, 1944.

Mr. W. Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

With reference to the March Quarterly Return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, we note that the following pupils are over sixteen years of age and should be discharged at the end of June:

No. 0198 No. 205 No. 311 No. 316 No. 320 No. 234

Departmental letter of January 20th, to the Principal approved the discharge of No. 0198, No. 0240 and No. 267. These names should be removed from future returns.

Please refer to information received in our letter of the 23rd ultimo. No reply has been received to date, yet the child is shown on the March return.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Receipt is hereby acknowledged of your 129-3-10
of March 23rd last with reference to the Application for
Admission of Jennie McDonald, 194 Iallington Band to the
Oceilla Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

I have checked further into the family history of the
girl by pursuing some old records. It appears that the
father of Jennie - Louis John McDonald and the mother - Elsie
Reid - were married Indian fashion on March 10th 1936., and
then on March 20th 1937 were married legally to Thomas
Sanderson of the Church of England. The first born of
this family was Jennie born January 12th, 1937. Elsie
Reid, the mother died on April 2nd 1939. The step-mother,
Elsie Beattie, is a Roman Catholic but is now married to
Joseph Cameron, No. 162 Iallington Band, who is shown on the
records as belonging to the Church of England.

The foregoing is submitted for your information.

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa
April 31, 1944.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 17th instant, in further reference to the application for admission of Jennie McDonald to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. In your letter of the 30th ultimo you stated that both the child's parents followed the Catholic religion. The information contained in your letter of April 17 indicates that they were members of the Church of England. The Department is at a loss to understand the divergence between these two statements and consequently I should appreciate hearing further from you in regard to the matter.

I should also like to know what relationship Mrs. Bella McDonald bears to Jennie McDonald, on whose authority was the latter placed in charge of Mrs. Bella McDonald?

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Kenora, Ontario.
April 24th 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re Jennie McDonald - 194 Islington Band

Receipt is hereby acknowledged of your 129-3-10
of the 21st instant in connection with the Application
for Admission of the above noted to the Cecilia Jeffrey
Indian Residential School.

In my letter of the 20th ultimo, it was stated that,
"The child's parents, who are both deceased, followed the
Roman Catholic Faith." This information was taken from
the Census book of the Band where it was clearly entered
as, Religion = R.C.

Upon receipt of your second communication dated
March 23rd, I rechecked as requested, and in my reply
of the 17th instant I stated that old records were found
which listed the religion as the Church of England, and
the discrepancy in the census book was corrected. In
this letter, the family history as outlined as correct
as the records here will allow. The error in showing
the parents of this child as being of the R.C. Faith has,
I admit, caused some confusion. However, this is an clear
a history as it is possible to give.

Louis John McDonald, 194 Islington, Jennie's father,
was a nephew of Jacob McDonald, 126 Islington, husband
of Mrs Bella McDonald, who was Jennie's Guardian, which would
make her an aunt by marriage. Mrs Bella McDonald has kept
Jennie since she was one year old under family agreement.

At Treaty time she was definitely given the child to
keep, as the grandmother of Jennie, Mrs Eliza Chisel, who
is a bad character, wanted to take her to Sioux Lookout.
This arrangement was agreed to by the Chief and
Councillors of the band and approved by myself.

Norma Watson
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 27, 1944.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 24th instant, in further reference to the application for the admission of Jennie McDonald to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School. You may inform the Principal that her admission is approved.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Extract from Principal's Report regarding the Cecilia Jeffrey School. Original on Annual Report of Principals of Indian Residential Schools - 1944.

We feel that the age of sixteen years is too low to send these children back to the Reserves. They are still children in every respect and no provision is made on the Reserve to guide them, direct them, or give them economic support, in establishing themselves.

Ottawa, Ontario,

Dear Sir:

RE: Pupil # Q225, Clara Williams, Wabigoon 70.

This girl is over 16 years of age and therefore ready to be discharged, but I hereby make request that permission be granted for her to remain in the school for the year 1944-45.

Her father has written to myself and also communicated with Mr. Paterson, making this request.

Her mother is dead. Her father is sick and not able to take care of her. Clara is lame and not very strong physically.

We would recommend that it is in the best interests of this girl that this request be granted.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

RE: APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION,

The above noted child was brought into this school by her father, John Tom, Assiniboia #92.

She had been taken to the St. Mary's school, by one of the Chiefs or Councillors from the Reserve. The father and mother had been separated. One of the Fathers from St. Mary's school phoned and asked if we would take the child.

It is the Father's wish that Beanie-Louisa attend this school, where her brother is now attending. His older brother graduated from here—also other cousins.

She was baptized R.C. in 1939, but we believe that she should be one of our children. (She was only 3½ years old when baptized.)

We respectfully present this information with the request that it be given special consideration in view of the wishes of the father and to keep the family together.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Certina Jeffrey
Presbyterian Indian Residential School
Kenora - Ontario

BERNIE-LOUISE TUK, Assiniboina #92.

The above noted child was brought into this school by her father, John Tom, Assiniboina #92.

She has been taken to the St. Mary's school, by one of the Chiefs or Councillors from the Reserve. The father and mother had been separated. One of the Fathers from St. Mary's school phoned and asked if we would take the child.

It is the father's wish that Bernie-Louise attend this school, where her brother is now attending. His older brother graduated from here—also other cousins.

She was baptized R.C. in 1939, but we believe that she should be one of our children. (She was only 7 years old when Baptized.)

We respectfully present this information with the request that it be given special consideration in view of the wishes of the father and to keep the family together.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Kenora, Ontario,
October 18th 1944.

Ottawa,
October 23, 1944.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the application for the admission of Dossie Louise Tom to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School. I note that this girl was first placed in the Kenora School but has now been placed in the Cecilia Jeffrey School. It would appear from the information supplied that she is eligible for admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey school and her admission to that school is approved, provided that no complaint will be made by the principal of the Kenora School. If he protests the transfer, you should communicate with me again, as the matter will have to be reviewed before a final decision can be made.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

DIVISION FILE NO.: 175
SUB-DIVISION: 175-6 DETACHMENT ABERA

PROVINCE: ONTARIO
DATE: OCTOBER 16TH, 1944

RE: Mary Ann PATOON, et al., Delton, Indian Reserve, Ontario.
Absentee from Oceola Jeffery Indian School, Ont.

I,

Relative to the above I have to report that on the 9th inst., Mr. PITT, Principal of the Oceola Jeffery Indian School Kenora, Ont., called this office and stated that several Indian girls had not returned for the fall term and had been absent since and that he wished this force to take action and bring them back. Mr. Pitt was advised that the children came to the Walker Indian Reserve north west of Kenora on the Rainy River and that it would involve considerable expense to return them to the school. It also meant the hiring of a guide and a motor boat. Mr. Pitt commented on the expenditure and suggested that it might possibly be an example to others who did not return to the school of their own accord.

The officer hired a guide and motor boat and had the letter freighted from Kenora to the Rainy River, a total mileage of 30 miles by boat was necessary to apprehend the delinquents and return them to the Oceola Indian School. The children were returned to Mr. Pitt in the P.M. of the 10th inst.

SIGNED AND DATED: OCTOBER 16TH, 1944.

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Re: JOY ARRAHAM, aged Six.

This girl is under the age for admittance, but in forwarding her application I should like to draw to your attention the following additional information.

The girls two brothers are at present in the school.

The father of the girl is outing wood, (living in a tent) just a mile from the school.

The mother of the girl was in Hospital when the father brought the girl to the school. The Mother is judged a Positive T.B. by the doctor and is supposed to be going to the Sanatorium, leaving the father with a boy 2 years and a baby 6 weeks to look after.

We feel that under these special circumstances, the department will consider with approval our accepting the little girl.

March 14th, 1945.

Mr. N. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

This letter will confirm our conversation of Friday March 9th.

As you will remember, this man wrote to both yourself and to us asking to be allowed to send his children to our school. Since we are still considerably below quota, and since by all rights and precedents, his children should go to this school, we were in favour of accepting them.

However, in order to cooperate with your wishes, we agreed to try to discourage Moses in his attempt to put his two children into the Cecilia Jeffrey School until after the present term. He evidently blames us and thinks that we do not want his children. This is not so. We would be very glad to have them.

It appears now that he has taken the two boys to the St. Mary's Indian School. In view of the above, and also the fact that the mother of the boys (the first wife to Moses), the present wife, and Moses himself are Protestant, it seems that they should not only be not admitted to St. Mary's but that further action should be taken. We believe that the boys should be forbidden to stay even as boarders, but should be admitted to the school to which they belong and to which he first intended to send them.

This case is even more outstanding than that of the Dan Kopineese children, for which there has been no action taken. We still have no reply to our letter.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch  
Dept of Mines & Resources  
Ottawa.

Kenora, Ontario  
April 6th, 1944

Re: Children of Moses Bird - #79 Whitefish Bay.

Herewith attached, please find letter from Mr. D.S. Pitts, Principal, Cecilia Jeffrey R.C. School, in connection with the above noted subject.

On December 14th, 1944, Moses Bird advised me by letter, he intended to place his two boys, Raymond and James in a Residential School in Kenora, and asked me to advise him what to do. I answered, that his boy Raymond could not be admitted to a residential school as he was already 11 years old at a day school, and that James, who is only 5 years old was under age for admission.

Bird was asked to call at the office when he was in town, to discuss this case with me. When he finally came to see me, he was advised that I would not sanction his boys' admittance to any Residential school as he had work on the reserve and the boy was doing very well there at the day school. He later moved to Kenora with his family and unknown to me, had his two boys placed in the Kenora R.C.I.R. School and not in the Cecilia Jeffrey School as he first had intended. This was done so that he could force the issue.

Mr. Pitts' letter will explain further his action in this matter. These two boys are now at the Kenora R.C. School and I am told that he now wishes to become a Catholic with his children.

It is my humble opinion, that if this man is allowed to change his spots simply to defy the regulations and to defy authority, then the Department's regulations concerning the admission of children to the different schools will mean nothing whatever to either the parents of the children involved or to the School principals. My attitude in such cases is a neutral one, but I do believe the Principals of the schools here should be given some concrete and definite instructions concerning such cases.

Attached applications have not been signed by me, and your decision in this matter will be appreciated.

Indian Agent

[Signature]

Indian Affairs Branch  
Dept of Mines & Resources  
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 11, 1945.

Reverend Sir:

On reviewing the March quarter return of the Kenora Residential School, it is noted that the names of James and Raymond Bird are shown as numbers 246 and 260, respectively. The attached application forms were also forwarded, but these were not approved by the Indian Agent and are consequently returned. No grant is being allowed for these children for the period they were in the school during the March quarter.

I may say further that I have a letter from the Indian Agent, in which he states that Moses Bird and both his first wife and second wife have always been recognised as Protestants. Bird applied to the Agent for permission to place the children in a residential school. As Bird was a Protestant, Mr. Paterson presumed that he wished to place his children in the Cecilia Jeffrey School. The Agent refused to approve of such action, as one of the boys is under school age, and besides, Bird is in a position to provide for his children. I regret very much that the children were accepted at the Kenora School, under the above circumstances and without consulting the Indian Agent, as such action undermines the agent's authority.

In government-owned Indian residential schools children do not be maintained without the approval of the Department; both of these boys should be returned to their fathers immediately, and I feel certain that you will carry out these instructions at once.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. Chas. Connon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Kenora Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, April 11, 1945.

Mr. Norman Peterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the Bird children. For your information, I enclose copy of a letter which I am forwarding to the Reverend Principal of the Kenora Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, June 13, 1948.

Mr. W. Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

I am in receipt of your telegram and also a telegram from Mr. Pitts, requesting permission to close the Cecilia Jeffrey School on June 20.

I have just discussed the contents of the telegrams with the Acting Director and both of us regret very much that the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School has made this request.

The early closing of the Kenora School is a special concession, made for this year only, in view of a celebration that the Oblate Order is holding in Winnipeg during the last week of the current month, in order to commemorate the centenary of the work of the Oblate Order in the Western Provinces. In comparable circumstances was held by the Presbyterian Church, and we granted permission to the Cecilia Jeffrey School to close early; we would certainly not expect the Kenora School to request the same privilege.

The reason the Principal gives for requesting the privilege does not appear very strong. However, it has been decided to allow the Cecilia Jeffrey School to close on June 20 this year only, and it is hoped that you will show this letter to Mr. Pitts.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

June 30th, 1945.

Mr. P. Pielen,
Chief, Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
GATANA, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Pielen:

I am very sorry that there appears to be some misunderstanding over my telegram requesting your authority for an earlier closing date for our school. The conditions under which the request was made seem much more important to us here than they evidently do to the Department in Ottawa.

Through experience of several years, it has been found advisable to allow the children to leave for the holidays from both schools on the same day. To that end, therefore, Father Gomau and I, in complete agreement, co-operate in arranging some time ahead that our day will coincide. This year that practice had been carried out.

The reason for working together is that several families or relatives or friends are intermingled in both schools. The parents sometimes send one family or hire a boat or truck to pick up the children from both schools at once. It is very unfortunate if another trip is necessary from a distance of 50 to 70 miles because one school is not ready. At the same time, we have found that if a few children are let out ahead, the others become restless and think they should be allowed to go. Considerable ill-feeling may be aroused among parents or bands.

Our policy has also been to set as "closing dates" the earliest possible day when children may leave. They may leave any day after the set date but not before. We set that day as Graduation Day with a Service and Prize Day.

Our reasons had nothing whatever to do with the Religious significance but were only realistic. If we had known some time ahead we might have written and Mr. Paterson could have explained the matter at treaty.

As it was, the early closing was a problem for the school staff, not any particular advantage. We had to revise our plans, rush Graduation, and engage extra help to take care of the period before July. However we felt it was worth-while in keeping peace among our Indians.

We hope that this explanation may clear up the situation.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, July 9, 1945.

Mr. H. Patterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Ottawa, September 22, 1948.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School:

Simon McDonald,
Maria Hunter,
John Robert Boyd,
Stephen Cameron,
William Mandamin (or Nejick)
Percy Carpenter,
Roy MacDonald,
Dora Starr,
Betty Starr,
George Arkinson.

I am returning the application form for John Richard Starr, in order that you may answer the question regarding his religion.

With reference to the application for Archie Queweyanse, I note the information you give regarding his religion. I think further enquiry should be made before admitting him to the Cecilia Jeffrey School, in order to make certain that we will not have any protest in the future.

Encl.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, 10th October, 1945.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, the admission of John Richard Starr to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School is approved.

With reference to the application form of Archie Queweyansse, a letter has been received protesting against his admission to this school. I am informed that the father phoned the Principal of the Reserve School and requested that he be placed in that institution. Until this boy's religious status is definitely settled, we are not prepared to approve his admission.

The Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School should be aware that when there is any doubt regarding a child's eligibility, such child should not be accepted until final decision has been made by this Department. I trust it will not be again necessary to direct Mr. Pitts' attention to this regulation which has been in effect for many years at all Residential Schools.

It is not necessary for Mr. Pitts to consult other Indians. All the facts should be sent to us through your office. Please show Mr. Pitts this letter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, 10th October, 1963.

Dear Father Comeau:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant with reference to Archie Queweymane. It has been stated that the Mother agrees to the boy being enrolled at Cecilia Jeffrey School, although from information contained in your letter regarding this matter, I would presume that she prefers Kenora Residential School.

I feel that you should discuss this case with Indian Agent Paterson whom I feel wishes to be fair.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. C.F. Comeau, O.M.I.,
Principal,
St. Mary's Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ontario.
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

Receipt is acknowledged of your 129-3-10 dated the 10th instant in connection with the above noted.

I have been informed by Chief Horace Spence of the Selkirk Band, that the parents of Archie, have moved into their trapping grounds, north of One Man Lake, and that they cannot be contacted at present. They will be coming to Kenora at Christmas time and the matter of Archie's religious status will be taken up with them at that time.

This boy is still at the School as it would entail some hardship to have him returned to his parents. I would recommend that he be kept at the School until such time as this whole matter can be definitely cleared up.

Norman Patterson
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 2nd November, 1945.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ontario.

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to Archie Newsonance. It is noted that you cannot obtain at the present time any further information regarding his religious status and that it would be a hardship to return him to his parents. Under the circumstances he may remain at the Cecilia Jeffrey School until Christmas but the Principal of that school should understand definitely that the Department has not yet made any decision regarding the eligibility of this boy for admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

This difficulty could easily have been avoided if the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School had carried out the instructions given on several occasions to the effect that any child whose eligibility is doubtful on any grounds should not be admitted to any school until all facts have been placed before the Department and our decision has been given.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

October 31, 1945.

Re 315 - Archie Quebsance (Full letter following). As we accepted this boy in good faith, and after a proper investigation, we request the department to accept him as a grant-paying pupil for this quarter. (We did not receive word of any question of his status until after the end of the quarter).

ENCLOSED WITH:
Quarterly returns, September 1945.
October 31, 1945.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario,

Re: Quarterly Returns - Sept., 1945.

Dear Sir:

Because of a Diphtheria Epidemic, brought in by some of our pupils, it was necessary to quarantine the school, and dispense with the regular classes from September to October 16th. (Quarantine card lifted on October 22nd.)

Several of the children were held back from re-admission to school from holidays, for the quarantine. We lose their grant.

Re Discharge letter 108:138 of July 12th, 1945 on following pupils: 0206, 0211, 0216, 0220, 0222, 0224, 0225, 0244, 239, 249, 271, and 266. These were all graduates, and it has been the custom to ask for and receive the grant on graduates for July end August—62 days. By error on my part, their discharge was requested on the June Returns, instead of on these September Returns. We, therefore, now request that they may be granted number of days as shown.

Re 294, Johnnie Pemmican, whose admission had been requested by Magistrate Wolfe of the Juvenile Court, this child was a truant through school year Sept./44 to June/45, but was placed in my charge in July/45, after again being before the magistrate. At that time, the Magistrate requested his transfer to Pelican Lake School, Sioux Lookout, the home of Johnnie's Mother. We therefore request his discharge.

We also request the discharge of 0237, Annie Peters, and 0258, Rosie Peters. Their father, having resigned from O.F.R. lost the privilege of a "pass" for the children. He has placed them in a Day School, near their home.

KENORA - ONTARIO

Nov. 5th, 1945.

Mr. H. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: PROTEST, Admission of children of Tom Shabagaset, Sesabamaka #161 into R.O.School, at Fort Frances.

It is understood by us that the above noted children have been recently admitted into the Roman Catholic School at Fort Frances, Ontario.

The Father, Thomas Shabagaset, was a pupil of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and became a member of the Presbyterian Church on June 19th, 1935. (Agency records.) The children of his two brothers were, or are still pupils here.

We request that you will forward this protest to the Department. In view of their recent attitude on such matters, it is almost inconceivable that such should be allowed.

We also again wish to draw to your attention the unusual activity of Father "Smalls" of St. Mary's School, in his efforts to persuade our people to leave us and join their (apparently) overcrowded school.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

The attached letter, received from Mr. D.S. Pitte, Principal, Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, is submitted for your information.

Ottawa, January 7, 1946.

Dear Father Comeau,

With reference to your letter of October 3 and my reply of October 10, regarding Archie Queuesance, we have now received the following statement, signed by the parents of the boy:

"To: Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

"I, Queuesance, No. 180, Islington, and
"I, Mary Queuesance, .... parents of Archie
Queuesance, do hereby make known our desire to have
our son admitted to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian
Residential School at Kenora. Only Archie has not been
baptized and follows the Indian belief and we have
mutually agreed that he should attend the Cecilia
Jeffrey I.R. School.

(Sgd.) - Father = Queuesance
Mother = Mary Queuesance

Witnesses:

"Horace Spence
Kenora Indian Agency, December 20th, 1945.
"Norman Paterson, Indian Agent."

It would appear that we will be obliged
to approve his admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

KENORA - ONTARIO

Jan. 26th, 1940

Mr. E. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

When accepting this child for admission, (Subject to approval by the Department,) I was given to understand that her name was Elsie and her Birth Date Aug. 3rd, 1939. Since our telephone conversation of yesterday, I now understand her to be named Mary Nancy, and her requested Birth Date to be Aug. 3rd, 1940. This makes her one year younger.

I hereby present further information, with the request that you will forward this to the Department for their consideration, (as a Grant Earning Pupil.)

(1) There is a large family, with several small children at home. (2) We have two big sisters here, Mary Agamere, aged 15, and Alice Agamere, aged 13. These two sisters are very good and can look after the little new girl considerably better here than the mother could at home. (3) We are willing to accept her, if the Department is willing to pay the Grant. (4) It has taken a good deal of persuasion to get the people of this Reserve to allow their children to come to school, some just coming in this year at 13 years of age. If we refuse a child, they may use it for further excuses.

Under above noted circumstances, we request her acceptance by the Department.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
Kenora, Ontario,
January 31st 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

KENORA - ONTARIO

April 12th, 1946.

Mr. H. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: Application for Admission of children of Robert Michaud, Yalington 191.

The above noted, Robert Michaud, is at present in my office.

He stated that he and his wife had planned to put their two girls into this school and came to Kenora for that purpose.

However his wife took the two girls to the St. Mary's school and they have made out applications (and signed them) for admission to St. Mary's School.

Now the two girls are anxious to come to Cecilia Jeffrey. The Father is desirous of having them here. He attended the old Cecilia Jeffrey School for 14 years and was a member of the Presbyterian Church. He and his wife were married by Canon Sanderson of the Church of England, but were again married by the Roman Catholic Priest, although Robert has never become a Roman Catholic (his statement) although his wife is R.C.

The chief, Chief Morase Spence, had told us when we visited the Reserve in February that he thought the Michaud's would rather "return" to the Church of England.

Under these above noted circumstances, I am therefore forwarding to your office application forms for these two girls, signed by the father. I feel that this case deserves special consideration, inasmuch as the father's desire appears to be so strongly in favour of attending the school to which he himself belongs.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Kanora, Ontario,
April 16, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: Admission of Children of
Herbert Michaud - #191 Islington

Herbert Michaud called at this office yesterday with his wife and informed me that his wife had left his two daughters, Josephine and Mary Louise, at the Kanora R.C.I.R. School, and intimated that he would rather have them in the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School. After Michaud left the office, an Application for Admission of these two girls was left in the office by Reverend Father A. Lacelle, O.M.I., of the Kanora R.C.I.R. School.

Herbert Michaud is shown in our census book as a Roman Catholic. His father, a Roman Catholic, died when he was four years of age. Herbert later was educated at the Cecilia Jeffery School at Shoal Lake and attended there for fourteen years and he has since then never followed the Roman Catholic faith. His wife, Melvina Cantin, is Roman Catholic. They were married on the Wahigen Reserve by Canon Sanderson, Church of England Missionary, on May 29th, 1934, and later, the marriage was blessed by Reverend Father Lemire at Wahigen, June 4th, 1935. There are two boys and three girls in the family who, I am told, were all baptised Roman Catholic.

Mrs. Michaud stated to the writer that she would prefer having her children sent to the Cecilia Jeffery I.R. School, her main reason being that most of the Islington children are still there and that her children did not know anyone at the Kanora R.C. School. Mrs. Michaud visited the Cecilia Jeffery Indian Residential School on the eleventh instant, but did not see the Principal, Mr. D.S. Pitts. She then called at the R.C.I.R. School with her husband and children and asked Reverend Father A. Lacelle to admit the children. Application Forms were signed by the Father and the children were examined by the Doctor, A.D. Ferriar.

Attached to the enclosed Application for Admission form from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffery School, is a letter from the Principal, Mr. D.S. Pitts, which is self explanatory.

The attached Application Forms from both schools, have not been signed or recommended by the writer, as a decision rendered by the Department in matters of this kind, is desirable.

[Signature]
Indian agent.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

Graduation Diplomas

When I visited your school recently, I discussed the question of providing students who are completing their studies with a suitable graduation diploma.

KENORA ONTARIO

Sept. 30th, 1946.

Mr. H. Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA Ont.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: Application for admission,
Children of Alex Morrison.

Could you please forward to the department the enclosed Application forms for the children of above noted.

The mother and father have again approached me asking to have their children admitted to school. (Please note previous applications, Oct. 2nd 1939 and Sept. 24th, 1943.)

We now request Reconsideration by the department—

1. The boys are not receiving any education whatsoever.
2. As date of writing, our school has only 114 children re-admitted after holidays. We are afraid that we will not have enough children to fill our quota.

As previously stated—

1. The family lives with and like the other Indians (Nomadic etc.)
2. The mother was a Treaty Indian, entitled to the Treaty Privileges, etc.
3. The same name of Alex Morrison (or Morriseau) were by previous marriage, were all admitted by the department to our school i.e., Daniel (or Donald) and Wilfred July 10th, 1979, by Department letter '106-17'.

We trust that you will enclose one copy of this letter to the Department with the applications and your recommendations.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal
Kenora, Ontario,
October 16th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

Re: Admission to Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.School
of George, William & Louis Morrison (Non-Treaty)

A letter has been received from Mr. D.B. Pitts,
Principal, Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.School, in connection with
the admission of the above noted children.

A copy of Mr. Pitts' letter, with Applications
for Admission, are hereto attached for your information.

These Applications have not been signed by the
writer. Further, to Mr. Pitts' remarks relative to this
family, I would like to add, that Alex Morrison has at times
given considerable trouble on the Shoal Lake Reserve and at
the blueberry camps. He works occasionally for Camp Out-
fitters and other Whitesmen but it has been reported to me that
he is not reliable. He has also been warned to stay away
from the Reserves, as several Chiefs were complaining about
his behaviour.

Please also be referred to your No. 129-3-10,
dated October 29th, 1943, in which you advised to discharge
these children, as they were non-treaty.

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 24 October 1946.

Mr. N. Peterson, Indian Agent,
KINORA, Ontario.

We have your letter enclosing letter from the Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey School with reference to the three Morrison children.

The Department's position regarding these children was fully outlined in our letter of October 29, 1943. We do not consider the children eligible for admission to any Indian Residential School and therefore cannot approve their admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
7-10-46

1. A request was received this A.M. from Indian Agent Mr. Paterson, age 25, Kenora, Ont., to locate, arrest and return to the Cecilia Jaffray Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ont., the following Treaty Indian pupils, who had escaped the day previous, all members of the Irlington Band of Indians:

   - Band No. 125 Robert CAMMUS, age 12 yrs.
   - Band No. 117 Joseph HANNAH, age 13 yrs.
   - Band No. 140 Archie QUINNADAM, age 14 yrs.

2. A patrol was made by P.C. 8557 and hired canoe, with Indian Robert JAMES to the Irlington Indian Reserve at Kenora, where the three pupils were located and returned to the school, they were handed over to Mr. U. HULSEN, Boy's Supervisor, in the absence of the Principal.

KENORA, October 10th, 1946

Ottawa, November 16, 1946.

Mr. H. Paterson, Indian Agent, Kemora, Ontario,

With reference to your letter of November 7th, the Department approves the admission of the following pupils to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School:

Ella Mandan,
Mary Ann Williamson,
Kenneth Redsky,
George Green,
Cecil Sam Green,
Harvey A. Redsky.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, November 26, 1946.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

Christmas Holidays for Residential Schools

Reference your letter of November 22.

There have been several similar requests received concerning this question of allowing Christmas holidays for children of residential schools.

There are many aspects to this problem, especially the financial and hygienic. In fact it is one which will probably receive serious consideration from the Joint Committee of Parliament and the Senate when they come to that phase of their investigation dealing with Residential Schools.

Rather than depart from the Department's previous policy in this regard, the minister has decided to defer any such change until the Joint Committee has deliberated upon this problem and has made a definite recommendation thereto.

Yours sincerely,

Director.

Mr. Douglas B. Pitts,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School,
Keepeez, Ontario.

Ottawa, October 18, 1947.

Mr. H. Peterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ontario.

Robert Scott's Children, Ialington Band
Application for admission to Residential School.

Our records show that pupil No. C316 Victoria Scott was officially admitted on June 1, 1947 to the Cecilia Jeffery Residential School. The application form shows her religion as Church of England. We did not receive an application form for her brother Eddy Scott.

Once a child is admitted to a Residential School upon a regular application form, it is not the policy of the Department to transfer the child to another Residential School conducted by a different denomination unless the father submits an affidavit testifying to the change in religion.

Therefore, the Department can not approve the admission of Victoria Scott and Eddy Scott to the Kenora Residential School (R.C.).

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

KENORA • ONTARIO

Oct. 9th, 1947.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

LITTLE CAROL ROSS MARTIN,
Daughter of Henry Martin, Shoal Lake No. 99.

Little Carol Ross was brought to the school by her Mother Helen Ross and her Grandmother, Mrs. Billy Ross.

The above noted Henry Martin, Shoal Lake Band, signed the attached application form and was very glad that we had taken in his little daughter,

Although the mother is not a Treaty Indian, the father is still a Treaty Indian. Since he admits being the father, (and is proud of it) we would request that the Department will admit this girl as a Grant Learning Pupil, and therefore forward her application in the usual manner.

The mother and father are separated and although the little girl is slightly under age, it would appear that she could be admitted on compassionate grounds, as the mother can not support Carol and her other little child.

Further, since our attendance is still below the quota allowed, it could not deprive any other child of the shelter of the school.

Will you please further this request, with your own recommendation to the Department.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Res Application for Admission,
Carl Martin

A letter has been received from Mr. D.S. Pitts, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario, requesting that I forward the Application for Admission for the above noted.

Mr. Pitts' letter advising of the Application for Admission is hereto attached for your information.

Carl Martin is the son of Harry Martin, No. 93 Shoal Lake Band 40, and Helen Ross, the daughter of Billy Ross No. 64 Shoal Lake Band 40. Helen Ross, a half breed, lived with Henry Martin off and on for a year or more, and were never legally married. They have not been living together since the Spring of 1944.

As it would appear this child is not eligible for admission, I respectfully refer you to your letter 129-3-10 dated Ottawa, October 29th, 1943 relative to the Alex Morrison children, who were refused admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School.

Your comments and advice covering this case will be appreciated.

Norman Paterson,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 27, 1947.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant, regarding the application for the admission of Carol Martin to the Cecilia Jeffrey residential school. Please obtain from Harry Martin a written declaration to the fact that he acknowledges paternity of this child.

With reference to your second letter of the 14th instant, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Cecilia Jeffrey School:

Doris Henry
Elizabeth Sandy
Lillian Sandy
Stanley Prince
Victoria Adams.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

KENORA - ONTARIO

Nov. 16th, 1947.

Mr. Norman Paterson,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: APPLICATION - Joseph Morrison.

In reply to your request of Nov. 5th., I herewith outline further particulars on application for admission of above noted pupil. (Most of this information is included in abbreviated form on the application.)

The Mother, Ada Crow, (or Norah Crow,) was legally married to Donald Morrison, (or Daniel Morrison.)

The mother a Treaty Indian, No. 129 Big Island, has been committed to the Sanatorium at Fort William and therefore is not able to care for this boy.

The Father, Donald Morrison, attended our school as a grant earning pupil under the name of Daniel Morrison, and was numbered 130 on School Quarterly Returns. He served in the Canadian Army as a Volunteer, was wounded, and later Honourably discharged. He brought his little son to the school and asked that we would care for little Joseph.

At the time of the marriage, we encouraged these two young people to be legally married. If they had not been legally married, the mother would probably still be claimed as Treaty Indian and the boy would be a Treaty Indian. Therefore we feel that they should not be penalized for doing what is right. They are a fine young couple. The boy is quite promising. We feel that he should be given every opportunity.

We still have room in the school for extra pupils. (He would not be crowding out a Treaty child.)

Therefore we request that the department will give favourable consideration to this application.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Kenora, Ontario,
November 21st, 1947

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, you will recall that several months ago we considered the applications for admission of the Morrison children to the Cecilia Jeffrey School.

According to our present regulations, Joseph Morrison is not eligible for admission and we are not prepared to make any exception in his case.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

P/I/30
Although the Shal Lake Bands were exceptionally prompt in returning all of their children to school on the proper day, this one member Kay Williamson and his younger brother Tommy (staying with father Tom Williamson, at Indian House) defied the Agent and myself by refusing to return to school.

Several times I saw Kay and asked when he would return the girls. Later I went three times to his tent to ask him to bring them back.

When I reported the matter to the agent, Mr. Paterson, asking for him to use his authority, he said that the Principal must use every effort first. I pointed out that I had done everything humanly possible, short of carrying the girls bodily—which I was not prepared to do.

I do feel that the agent was largely responsible for the break-down in the authority in not insisting on the return of these children. When I protested to him on the phone and in his office he only said that "my had promised to bring the girls back."

Finally I told the father that I would not bother him any more. It was up to the agent and if necessary to use the Moundzor R.C.M.P.

I feel that the agent should have used some pressure—as he was later forced to do with some of the Illington Band, with excellent results.

Now that these children were ignored by us, they have taken them to St. Mary's School. We feel that this should not be allowed and that these children should be ordered forthwith to be removed from St. Mary's School and returned to O.J. School.

I have told the agent that this matter should be referred to you and that they should be returned. As I can get no co-operation (in this one incident) I am taking the matter up with you direct.

There is also the matter of the Scott children who are still at St. Mary's. The Missionary, Father Macelles says that they have no intention of letting them return to us.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal
Cecilie Jeffrey
Presbyterian Indian Residential School
Kenora - Ontario

Dec. 2nd, 1947.

Col. B.F. Henry,
Superintendent, Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Col. Henry:

RE: CHILDREN OF KAY WILLIAMSON,
Shoal Lake 34-69.

The two daughters of above noted Kay Williamson, have not returned to the O.J. School after the summer holidays. I am informed that they are in the St. Mary's Indian School.

The father and whole family were in the O. J. School. (The Paternal Grandparents were among the first pupils.) The father had at least part of a year at High School.

The Two Girls, Bertha and Muriel, were both accepted into O.J. School; Bertha Williamson, Authority: Nov. 6/44, File No. 129-3-10; and Mary Ann Williamson, Nov. 15/46, File No. 129-3-10 (WT7).

The mother had tried once before to put the children into St. Mary's but the father had taken them out and brought her over here, where she should be.

Last summer, the father and mother were apparently looking for something which they could blame. Consequently we had both children carefully examined by Dr. Ferguson before allowing them home for the summer. (The father was with the girls.) Later he wrote to the agent saying the children had contacted scabies and given it to a younger child. We found in our nurses' records when the mother had brought this baby to the school for advice for scabies early in the spring. I told him that he could not blame the school but his own living conditions.

He still has no house for his family. They spend most of the time in tents, even through part of the winter.
Ottawa, December 9th, 1947.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

We have received your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the children of Kay Williamson.

In view of the fact that we have received definite information from Indian Agent Paterson that both Mr. and Mrs. Williamson are now recognized as Roman Catholics, their children are therefore eligible under Sub Section 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act to be admitted as grant earning pupils to the Kenora Residential School.

Their admission to that school has been approved.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Heary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. D.S. Pitts, B.A.,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res. School,
Kenora, Ontario.

PP/LED
Cecilia Jeffrey
Presbyterian Indian Residential School
Kenora - Ontario

Dec. 13th, 1947.

Mr. Philip Reelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

RE: Bertha and Mildred Williamson.

I am informed by the Agent, Mr. E. Paterson, that you have approved of the admission of these two girls to the St. Mary's Indian School, (Roman Catholic).

Some time ago, when we asked for a similar transfer of children whose mother had taken the girls to the wrong school, and both father and mother were Presbyterians, you said that it was not possible to let them in one school and then change to another. (Children of Norman Michaud, Kelvington.)

The agent only told you on information from the R.O. missionary that Kay Williamson was now recognized as R.O. On Saturday the mother denied this. (This is the same Father Lascelles who decides all the policy as to Christmas Holidays, has on several occasions baptized children whom he knows to be Presbyterian, - Ex. Morrison children - and takes advantage of our Protestant people when they are ill in the St. Joseph's Hospital.)

Why is the Department allowing all these "One-way Transfers" at this time?

As outlined some time ago, the problem with the Williamson children was entirely lack of enforcing the rules, by the local Agent. My letter must be in your hands, however as yet I have not received any answer.

May we request immediate reconsideration of this case.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Cecilia Jeffrey
Presbyterian Indian Residential School
Kenora - Ontario

Dec. 10th, 1947.

Philip Phelan Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Mr. Paterson, the local Agent informs me that he has received a letter from you refusing to admit the above noted boy.

We had written full particulars about this case to Mr. Paterson, on his request, enclosing a duplicate of our letter so that the Department might receive a copy. We wonder now if you received this duplicate.

Reference is made to several months ago we considered the application of the Morrison children to the Cecilia Jeffrey School. I should like to point out that evidently on the agent's advice, you consider this the same case. It is not. This is a different family.

The mother is a Treaty Indian, receiving both Treaty and Interest payments. She is at present in the Sanatorium, and therefore unable to take care of the boy.

The Father was a pupil of this school. Further he was wounded overseas.

Surely with both parents former pupils, and the mother in the sanatorium, a decision might be made. I realize that the policy is not to deprive children of Treaty parents of an opportunity to receive an education. However, we have not enough children to meet the quota. In some cases the Agent is definitely not co-operating.

May I request acknowledgement of this letter.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Ottawa, December 13, 1947.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

We have your letter of the 10th instant with further reference to Joseph Morrison.

We are quite prepared to agree that it is unfortunate for the boy that his mother is suffering from T.B. and consequently is confined to hospital.

However, the fact still remains that the father is not a Treaty Indian. For your information I enclose a copy of circular letter which was issued some years ago in which is still in effect. Possibly you have one of these circulars in your school. However, I would point out that the definite ruling was made at that time and consequently Joseph Morrison is not eligible for admission as a grant earning pupil to an Indian residential school.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. D.S. Pitts,
Principal,
Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Res.School,
Kenora, Ontario.

January 28, 1948.

Mr. H. Paterson, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Kenora, Ontario,

With reference to the October quarter return of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, you may inform the principal that the Department approves the discharge of pupils numbered as follows:

0259; 273; 295; 344;

It is noted that in the case of three of them the reason for discharge is stated to be the fact that they have reached the age limit of sixteen. It is not the usual practice to discharge pupils simply because they have reached the age of sixteen. If they reach that age during the academic year, the regular practice is to retain them until the end of the regular academic year, June 30th. You may so inform the principal.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

March 27th, 1945

TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN:

I James Petawanaquib, of the Rat Portage Indian Band, of Kenora Agency, do hereby swear that I do want my children to be in the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and to be brought up as Presbyterians.

I have not been, nor am now a Roman Catholic.

My wife, Mary Mongoose was formerly a pupil in the O.J. School and was a Presbyterian.

WITNESSES:

Margaret Douglas
Mrs. W. Douglas

Stella Petawanaquib

Jim Petawanaquib

Mary Mongoose
Mary (Mongoose) Petawanaquib

D.S. Pitta

Stella Petawanaquib
March 11th, 1948.

Mr. H. Paterson,
Superintendent,
Kenora Indian Agency,
KENORA, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Please find enclosed the two application forms covering the application for admission to the Cecilia Jeffrey school of Stella Margaret Petawankweb and her brother Victor Petawankweb, children of Jim Petawankweb and his wife Mary Mongoose Petawankweb.

The father is Indian belief. The mother is Presbyterian having been a pupil at the Cecilia Jeffrey School. They both now desire that their children attend our school, and have decided to join the Presbyterian Church.

Although the girl Stella, was formerly a pupil at St. Mary's School, her father would not return her there because he desired that she and her brother enter our school.

We trust that the department will approve of this admission. (They already have formed a precedent in the case of Kay Williamson's children and others.)

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

2 copies.
Kenora, April 3rd, 1948

May 4, 1948.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Kenora, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 3rd ultimo, file 106-12 (129) with reference to the Petawanaquib children. These children should not have been admitted to the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School until all the facts had been placed before the Department and our decision given.

We note that Stella Petawanaquib attended the Kenora School for three years. Please let me know on what grounds she was discharged from that school. We would also like to know what year she was at the school in order that we can check the Kenora returns.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.
